TALK.START.PARA: took the chair at 9 a.m., and—by leave—read prayers.

Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PARA.TAB: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had disagreed to the amendment made by the Senate and desired the reconsideration and concurrence of the bill by the Senate.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That consideration of the message in committee of the whole be an order of the day for a later hour of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —We disagree with that motion. Why should it not be dealt with now? The government wants to push these important issues and this important bill down until after consideration of the Native Title Bill and presumably after the social security legislation; so it will not be dealt with at all. What is the message from the House of Representatives?
—There is disagreement to the amendment to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill.
—Why do we not have that debate now?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Mr President, there will be time for that matter to be debated—
—When?

—After we conclude the Mabo legislation and it is sent across to the House of Representatives. There are some outstanding matters of the nine legislative packages which we did not quite complete. They will need to be completed. That will be an appropriate opportunity to debate this matter. I do wish to proceed with the committee stage debate.
—by leave—I wish to speak further to this.
—What have you got to say?

—We all know what will happen. The government will get the numbers for the gag. After the Mabo legislation is passed, the government, the Democrats and the Greens will agree it is time to go home. What is the Leader of the Government in the Senate shaking his head for? He does this at the end of every session. The government will get the numbers for the gag. The gag will be put on and a vitally important issue to the veterans of Australia will not be properly dealt with by this chamber. It is just another application of the mismanagement of the process. What a nerve the Leader of the Government has to stand up and say that that will be dealt with sensibly after the Mabo debate. He does not seem to understand that Christmas is just about here. His crowd does not want to come back next week. When will it be debated? The government is not worried about the workers or the veterans.
—Are you?

—Yes. All the government is worried about is its fragile consensus for the Mabo legislation. It is looking more fragile every day. That is the big worry. I think the veterans legislation ought to be dealt with first. I cannot see any reason why it should not be. The Mabo debate can go for a long time. There are over 200 amendments. It is very complex and very difficult.
—There are 35 remaining debates.

—Senator Evans says that there are only 35 major subject matters for debate. That is not 35 clauses; that is 35 substantial areas of debate. We have a normal week's work for the Senate to go. I know and Senator Evans knows that the only way the veterans legislation will be properly dealt with is if it is dealt with now. That is why we oppose this motion that the debate be put off. We believe it ought to be dealt with now.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PARA.TAB: The following bill was returned from the House of Representatives without amendment:
Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill 1993
Consideration resumed.
Question put:
That clause 10, as amended, be agreed to.
Senator Harradine—Mr Chairman, on a point of explanation: I wish to make the statement that I understand now that this is not the vote on Senator Kernot's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The vote is on the question that the clause, as amended, stand as printed.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine—As I said last night, I support clause 10 and I should be voting on the other side. I seek the leave of the committee to have my name so recorded.
Leave granted.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clause 11.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I indicate that, although an amendment has been circulated in the government's name as amendment No. 4 in relation to clause 11, I now propose not to proceed with that amendment. The question of the clause dealing with laws of general application will be addressed in a further proposed amendment of proposed new 196A that has been circulated and that is on the running sheet. There is no need accordingly under those circumstances to proceed with this.

—I am wondering whether the minister can give an explanation as to why the government has chosen to drop this particular amendment and proceed with some other one. Perhaps if I give him the opportunity to answer that question, rather than tell him what I think has been done wrong, we might shorten the debate.

—I have just indicated that the policy objectives that we sought to achieve with the amendment we think are better achieved by the proposed new 196A amendment, which has been previously circulated in a draft form as amendment 33(a) but I think there is a revised version of that.
—The minister says, `Oh well, it was this, it was that'. Perhaps we could get a copy of exactly what it is he is talking about.

—I do not think Senator Vanstone needs to trouble herself about it since she is not proposing to move any amendments herself. All I am doing is advising the Senate, as a matter of courtesy, that a possible amendment that was circulated and notified will not be proceeded with. The policy issues surrounding this clause can be better debated when we get to the subsequent proposed amendment, which is a long way away.

—I will come back to that. Has the minister had any advice from within the Attorney-General's Department or elsewhere as to whether the Commonwealth has the capacity, by such a simple but sweeping clause as clause 11, to adopt the common law as a law of the Commonwealth, attempting therefore by section 109 to simply block out the states?
—Yes.
—Will the minister make that advice available?

—No. I think it has essentially been oral advice. I am not aware of any actual written paper advice, but this has obviously been the subject of discussion at various stages in the preparation of the bill. Innumerable legal matters are in issue here. That is one of them. The government is confident that this is sustainable.

—The government has been confident before and been wrong. It was confident in relation to some regulations on advice from the Solicitor-General, I think it was. It was confident on the advertisement bans that it was right, and it was clearly wrong. It was confident on the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3). The government's own members of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs agreed that there was sufficient risk that the government was wrong and that we ought not to proceed.

PARA.TAB: The reason that I intend to pursue this matter is that the question of whether the government can do this—adopt, through statute, the common law and cover the field under section 109 and thereby lock out the states—is one of the fundamental constitutional issues surrounding this bill. If the minister's flippant `we're confident we're right' in fact turns out to be wrong, the government loses. Then the Democrats, the Greens and all the people who are agreeing to the processes of this place and who are simply being simply trodden on for the purpose of getting this bill through, come to nothing because the government got bad advice. Is the minister honestly saying that, in relation to such an important bill and an obvious question of doubt that would be raised as to constitutional validity, he has not bothered to get any written advice? Is that what he is saying?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will treat that as a rhetorical question.

—It was not a rhetorical question—not rhetorical at all. Section 109 may well go to the constitutional validity of this entire bill. For the minister to be saying, `Look, do not worry about it; I have got it right', when his record and his government's record of getting it wrong is so lengthy, is almost breathtaking in its arrogance—for which of course he is well known. Perhaps we could just come back to the issue. We do not intend to leave it just because the minister thinks it is okay. Incidentally, the amendment he refers to is not available from the clerks.

PARA.TAB: There are questions as to the operation of state law, the extent to which state law survives. The government may have been dealing with it incorrectly—in fact, I am quite sure it was by this amendment. But for the minister to say, `Oh, well, we will deal with it later', the government might pull off that amendment and then we will not be able to have the debate, not only as to whether the government can adopt the common law and, through section 109, block out the states but, in doing that, what the consequences are, for example, for the laws of general application. The minister says it is dealt with in some other way, but I have just been given a note saying the amendment he refers to is not available from the clerks. Government members are the ones who say that we should get our act together and that this is all quite simple. Why do they not get their act together? We will proceed with the debate in an orderly fashion when they have.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has been circulated that bears upon 196A is amendment No. 33 in the Greens' master sheet. It is proposed that there be some modifications of that. It will be circulated later in the day with the notation 33(a) or 33(b) to clarify that it does represent a redrafting. The essential intent is perfectly clear. I will foreshadow—
—The intention is not relevant, as you know. You have got to get it right.

—I am indebted to Senator Vanstone for that advice, just as I am indebted to her for the flattery early on in her remarks. It will get her everywhere. The point is that we do want to preserve so much as is humanly possible state laws and territory laws of general application. It is not the intent of the Commonwealth native title legislation to cut across those.

PARA.TAB: However, from time to time, there are instances where state laws of general application impinge upon the exercise of some possible area of native title—perhaps hunting, gathering or fishing entitlements—and do so in a way which would operate to prohibit the enjoyment of the native title right but in circumstances where the native title right could be enjoyed without in turn, as a practical matter, inhibiting the effectiveness of the law of general application. It is a matter of steering a course through this and trying to identify some circumstances where it would be appropriate for the native title to be able to be exercised notwithstanding state and territory laws of general application—whether they be laws relating to conservation, commercial fishery, gun licences or hunting.

That is what the 196A exercise is all about. I think honourable senators can see that from the terms of amendment No. 33 in the Greens' list. We think we can improve the drafting of that and there has been discussion going on about that in the last 24 hours. Although it will be a long while yet before we reach it in the debate, I hope to be able to circulate the proposed variation on amendment 33 quite soon.

That is the basic framework within which we are operating and I hope that will be better understood when we get to the debate on that clause later. But, for the moment, we are comfortable with the language of clause 11 as it now stands.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand why Senator Gareth Evans looks so embarrassed this morning. I also understand why he has withdrawn the amendment and wants to deal with it later. The original amendment was trying in effect to amend the constitution by legislation, which Senator Evans cannot do and knows he cannot do. He is desperately trying to get some time for people to go away and try to find some way to retain the application of state laws without having to amend the constitution. He cannot do it. Let me tell him why not.

PARA.TAB: Senator Gareth Evans says that the common law shall have the force of a law of the Commonwealth, thereby lifting the words from section 109. That should fail for uncertainty because the common law is unknown in its entirety; it is not written down, as he full well knows. By using that form of words, he is attempting to exclude the operation of all state acts.

Let me give him an example. It is one that has been given to me and is a very good example. Hunting and gathering rights of Aboriginal people include the following: the method of hunting can be to set fire to the bushland so that the animals can run out and be killed. There are laws of the state which prevent and outlaw setting fire to the bush, for very good reasons. If this prevails, the state law banning setting fire to the bushland would be an invalid law, because Senator Evans's legislation purports to cover the field and it would be struck down. So there would be an apartheid situation where one section of Australia is subject to one set of laws and those subject to Aboriginal and native title would be subject to an entirely separate application of laws. It would be true apartheid.

When one takes into account that Senator Evans has withdrawn the amendment knowing full well that he cannot then say that we are going to change the constitution in its application, he knows that that amendment would fail. Senator Evans can take all the time he likes to try to come up with a solution to that problem, but he will fail. That is why he has failed to answer Senate Vanstone's question as to where the written advice on these highly complex constitutional points is, so that the people of Australia can listen to fair and reasoned debate. Where is the written advice? Senate Vanstone deserves an answer just as I deserve an answer to my question: is the reason why Senator Evans has withdrawn the amendment that he knows it is effectively trying to amend the constitution, and he may not do that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps we could take this matter in an orderly fashion, as Senator Evans indicated last night he wants to. Could he indicate what written legal advice he has with respect to clause 11. He may not have sought advice as to whether the Commonwealth can use section 109 and, by statute, adopt the common law to lock out the states. There may be some other aspect on which he has sought advice—for example, how to do that, if that is what he wants to achieve.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Hill said to him this morning, `You've got 39 things to get done', Senator Evans said, `It's so easy; they've all been grouped into these 39 sections. There are not 205 amendments; it is not complicated at all. We can deal with this, subject area by subject area'. We are now on the third or fourth subject area: laws of general application. This is where the minister has indicated that he wants to deal with this matter. When we try to follow the government's running sheet and its suggestion of where to deal with this, namely as the fourth item—clause 11 amendment 4, or clause 11 in general—he is not ready to do so. The minister has had one amendment, he announced this morning that it had been pulled off. He could have told people last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has probably only just found out about it.

—As Senator Bishop says, he has probably only just realised that it was not possible. Somebody has probably tipped him off to the questioning that he was going to be subjected to this morning. It simply is not adequate. We are trying to follow the government's sheet. Let us not have any bad faith about this. The government grouped these things in this order. Senator Evans said, `This is where laws of general application should now be dealt with'. We are now ready to do that, and he walks in and says, `I want to pull this amendment off'. He pretends that he is organised, then he rattles off a number of other amendments and finally says that it was not one of his after all, it was one of Senator Chamarette's amendments. We want to try to deal with this fully and properly, yes, but in an orderly fashion. Senator Evans is the one who set this schedule. Perhaps he could now indicate when he thinks he will be ready to deal with subject area D.

PARA.TAB: I have a few other questions after that, but perhaps that is the first one that the minister ought to answer. When he does so, will he indicate what legal advice he does have with respect to this general area; or has he none? Is he sailing on his own brains?

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I was reluctant to rise to my feet earlier was simply that it seemed to me that Senator Bishop was erecting a straw man. She built her whole contribution around `if this amendment had been proceeded with, then these various dire consequences would follow'. Since we were not proceeding with that amendment, it did not seem appropriate to ponder further the alleged dire consequences.

PARA.TAB: But let me respond specifically to Senator Vanstone's queries. The business of incorporating particular parts of the common law as the law of the Commonwealth is something that has had ample precedent over the years. For example, there are a number of slabs of the Crimes Act which explicitly pick up and treat as Commonwealth law, for the purposes of the exercise of federal jurisdiction, particular identified areas of the common law.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they do it in a codified manner.

—No, it is not a matter of restating a statute law; it is a matter of overtly recognising that common law can be picked up in appropriate context. If there is otherwise a head of power to support the legislation in question, then one way of defining a subject area of Commonwealth law is to do so by reference to the common law on that subject. That has the effect of giving the federal courts the jurisdiction to deal with the common law area in question in a way that might not otherwise be possible, unless they were expressly vested with that jurisdiction by statutory provision of this kind. So there is no doubt that there is ample precedent over the course of this century for that being done from time to time.
—Not in this way.

—Senator Bishop, please. I understand that Mr Orr from the Attorney-General's Department wrote a letter to the Senate committee addressing this issue in response to a query giving some examples of this kind. We simply do not believe that there is any constitutional problem involved in picking up by reference, as it were, a body of law in this way and making it part of the Commonwealth law. The only constitutional question then becomes the general constitutional question that underlies the whole legislation and that is the extent to which the race power does in fact allow the native title issue to be addressed by Commonwealth legislation. As we have said on numerous occasions, we do not believe that there is any doubt at all about that. So really that is where it stands.

PARA.TAB: As to the treatment of this in the amendments, we do not think that this issue is best addressed, on reflection, at this stage of the legislation. It is better addressed by a specific provision later. The provision that is flagged in this respect is proposed new section 196A, and that will have the effect that I indicated previously. Perhaps we can address larger questions of the co-existence of state laws general application with this legislation in that context when we have something specific to bite upon, rather than just a general clause here which does not deal explicitly with this issue.

Might I say further that, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) indicated in his second reading speech, the whole question of the applicability of state and territory laws of general application to areas of native title really does need some extensive review on a case by case basis. I do not think that it would be appropriate to try to legislate to cover the whole spectrum of such potential conflict in its resolution in legislation of this kind. It may, however, be appropriate—and this is what we will try to do with 196A on a cooperative basis—to identify some relatively limited areas where it would be appropriate to identify those areas where native title can be exercised, notwithstanding the existence of a state law of general application. I am trying to respond in as detailed and constructive way as I can to legitimate queries, but I think that that is as much as I can sensibly say at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the minister could circulate the letter that Mr Orr wrote so that senators can see whether among those examples there is an example relating to clause 11 which contains one line which says that the common law with respect to one matter is a law of the Commonwealth. That provision tries to exclude the states.

PARA.TAB: I would be grateful if that letter could be distributed so other interested senators such as Senator Alston, Senator Bishop, Senator Kemp and Senator Minchin will have an opportunity to ascertain the veracity of the arguments he put. It is all very well for Mr Orr to have written a letter to the legal and constitutional affairs committee. As we know, that committee had hardly any time to take evidence and consider it. It would be helpful if he could do that.

I also want to raise with the minister the question of the legal advice he sought on this matter. He keeps offering a range of responses to the simple question that has been put: what written advice does he have with respect to this matter, and will he table it? He keeps ignoring that question. I would be grateful if he answered it.

He says we will deal with the question of any state laws at another time but he does not say why he wants to list on the schedule as item D clauses of general application which are affected by clause 11. That is what it is all about. He wants to deal with fixing that problem somewhere else. He has not answered the logical question. The minister set out this allegedly logical formula to proceed with this legislation and does not offer a reason, other than his own incompetence at not having the amendment already, as to why we should not deal with those matters now. If the minister says that clause 196(a) will fix whatever problem there is, why do we not deal with it now? Perhaps he will give an explanation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or defer it.

—Or we could defer the consideration of clause 11—the whole area—until the minister is ready, if he is having some difficulty. Perhaps he could answer those matters first and we can proceed in an orderly fashion. If he is not ready, we are quite amenable. We will shift discussion of the laws of general application to another time, when he is ready.

—The first point is that Mr Orr's letter is not to hand at the moment but it can be obtained and circulated. We will do that. The second point is that I am advised—and we are checking this now—that the expression `adopting some area of common law' as Commonwealth law does have explicit statutory precedence in various places, including in the Crimes Act. We will seek to find an example of some such clause and give it to you in a moment.

PARA.TAB: The third matter is about the advice. There is a misunderstanding about the nature of the process involved in drafting legislation of this kind. Those opposite seem to work on the assumption that there are formal written advices prepared in the Attorney-General's Department or elsewhere and which lie behind consideration of each clause. If something is settled and understood doctrine, theoretically and conceptually sound, the notion of picking up a subject area that is otherwise within the Commonwealth's competence and giving it statutory force simply by it being described as `an area of common law'—and if there are precedents for this, it is part of the practice of the Commonwealth over a long period and has not previously been the subject of challenge or assumed difficulty—is not the sort of thing on which we would seek formal written advice. There may be some oral discussion about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying there has been none?

—Without going back and checking the archives—that is very detailed—no-one can recall any advice being specifically written on this subject simply because there is no need to in an area in which, for all the reasons I have described, there is no reason to assume there is a constitutional problem. What matters is that the race powers have sufficient vitality to enable the Commonwealth to legislate generally for this area of native title. That is the theory that underlies the whole of this legislation. This is just one other application of that general theory.

—Senator Gareth Evans has just put forth the most appalling defence of the indefensible. It is the defence put forward by incompetence and those who are incompetent. We are dealing with the rights and property rights of individual Australians. We are dealing, potentially, with the question of sovereignty of large sections of Australia. Yet the minister says he did not bother to get any advice because it is all okay in his competency.

PARA.TAB: We are dealing with a fundamental question of the underlying basis of a federation of Australia: in what areas does the Commonwealth have power and in what areas does it not have power? Are state laws able to be exercised in all parts of the jurisdiction or not?

Senator Evans raised the issue of criminal law. He raised the question of the exercise of the criminal law. Let us take a look at what this proposed piece of legislation does to the exercise of the criminal law in a state where there is state legislation. Where there is established native title according to this legislation, common law rights of the Aboriginal people may well be such that they are entitled to spear people for certain offences within Aboriginal customary law.

Under clause 11 of this legislation, because Senator Evans is happy with the clause—and we do not know what qualification is going to be put on it later because, as I said before, we cannot legislate to change the constitution—a policeman of a state would not be entitled to enforce the state law, the crimes act of that state, on areas of land which are designated `native title'.

That is what this legislation is doing to the fabric of our very society and you say that you do not need any written advice. You say that it is not a question that has to be examined. You say that you do not care because you are content in your mind to ram this bill down the throats of Australians without proper consideration and without proper debate. You have not even got the courage to answer Senator Vanstone's question: have you taken any written advice? You do not even have the courage to say no. You give the spurious answer: `I would have to go through the archives. I do not recall any'. Have the courage at least, minister, to say no.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—Order! Senator Bishop, would you address your remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would Senator Evans have the courage to admit that he has failed in his duty as a minister? Would he have the courage to say that he does not have the interests of all Australians at heart? Would he have the courage to say that it is only the aim of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to ram this bill down the throats of Australians in this short, nonsensical pre-Christmas period?
—How many hours have we been here?

—How many hours have been wasted by this government's not bringing on the bill earlier? How many hours have been wasted by the Democrats in their obfuscations of this matter? The minister should not turn around and say that this matter cannot be properly debated. A fundamental issue of our constitution, the existence of states and the operation of state law throughout those states, is at stake under this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans's use of circular language, obfuscations, and his insulting other senators simply will not answer the fundamental question of why he has not done his job properly. On a question as pivotal as this to the operation of state and federal law, he has not even bothered to get written advice as to whether or not this is constitutional. Senator Vanstone deserves an answer to her question. Why did the minister not get written advice, if he did not? Will he table whatever it is that he has got for the Senate and for the rest of Australia to have a look at?

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that Senator Bishop's question has not been responded to, but I wonder whether I could ease the passage of this particular clause somewhat. Prior to doing that, I have certain questions. Is it not appropriate that this bill contain this clause? Is that not the most appropriate response the Commonwealth government could have made to the High Court decision? Is it not also correct that, in order to preserve native title as a Commonwealth function, the date it should be referring to is 30 June 1992? The protection of native title would have been most appropriately taken on by the Commonwealth at the point in time when the High Court decision reflected and recognised the existence of that native title.

PARA.TAB: As the amendment that is under consideration here has not been circulated, I also request that the minister defer consideration of this item until we have been able to see it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the argument. I think that matter D, laws of general application, should be deferred. As we have asked—and Senator Chamarette has indicated that she agrees—
—I am happy to do that. May I respond to that?

—I might be able to assist Senator Evans. He has made one fundamental error already. How do I know, if I do not tell him now what he should look at, that he will not come back later and make the same mistake? I am only trying to be helpful in that respect.

PARA.TAB: This wholesale adoption of clause 11 has consequences. Obviously Senator Evans realises that. That is why he was going to move amendment No.4 to clause 11: there are elements of the otherwise prevailing law that he wants to survive. He has withdrawn that and said, `We will deal with it by way of another clause'. That indicates that clause 11, simple as it is with its one line, has a very fundamental and far-reaching effect, the consequences of which we are clearly not all aware.

I do not mean to imply that Senator Evans should personally take responsibility and know the answer, but we should know the answer before we proceed with clause 11, otherwise we do not know whether we can deal with the consequences of such a clause in some other way in the bill. Senator Evans obviously realises that. That is why he had that amendment, and that is why he now says, `That problem'—only two words to describe what could be a massive problem—`will be dealt with later'.

The Commonwealth government is trying to cover the complete field, and that might lock out a great number of state laws. Senator Evans might not be in a position at this time to tell us the complete effect of such an adoption. There might be a whole range of state laws that are locked out. Senator Bishop raised the question of state criminal laws and their application in native title areas. I do not know whether that is an appropriate example, but I am sure that there are plenty of examples. So are you, otherwise you would not have bothered with this amendment and you would not be suggesting to go to Senator Chamarette's—
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—Order! Senator Vanstone, please address your remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not remember when the minister was Attorney-General, but perhaps he could take his mind back to the Racial Discrimination Act, which he says he almost completely wrote.
—That was back in 1973, in another incarnation.

—He might have been there to make the amendments and fix up the errors he made in 1973. I ask the minister whether the case of Viskowskas rings a bell. In that case, the New South Wales Racial Discrimination Act was held to be invalid because the Commonwealth had covered the field by virtue of section 109. The government passed some legislation covering the field and in doing so made the state Racial Discrimination Act invalid.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Evans was in another incarnation, as he says, in 1973, he obviously did not realise the consequences. By that I do not mean that he was stupid; they were just unforeseen. The full impact of section 109 did not even dawn on him at the time—and, in his own words, he wrote the thing. Quite clearly, it had to be amended because people did not realise the full impact of section 109.

The case of Viskowskas and Niland trips the minister into an interesting debate on which, presumably, he would have obtained some legal advice—or should have. Having made this error with the Racial Discrimination Act and having covered the field, and therefore invalidating state laws that were trying to do the same thing, he tried to fix it up. This is what he tried to say: `Look, we didn't want to cut out the state law, so we're going to pass an amendment and say that, retrospectively, we haven't invalidated state law by covering the field'.

If the minister has not turned his mind to it recently, he might look to the case of Metwally and the University of Wollongong. In that case, not only was he mistaken when he covered the field, thereby locking out New South Wales legislation, but when he tried to fix it up, he botched it. He could not even fix that up properly because, as the High Court told him in that respect, `Look, this document'—the constitution—`is not something that ministers can amend by statute to fix up their own boo-boos'. That is what he tried to do with the Racial Discrimination Act.

He tried to say, `Oh, we're covering the field. Whoops, we did not want to rule out the New South Wales legislation in that respect, and the constitution says we had. Oh well, we will just pass a little statute and say that we did not do that'. When that matter was litigated—Metwally v. the University of Wollongong—Senator Evans found out—a big surprise for someone with his legal knowledge—that he could not amend the impact of the constitution by some simple piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Retrospectively.

—Retrospectively or otherwise. That is the situation the government is faced with now. We are in exactly the same sort of situation Senator Evans faced with the Racial Discrimination Act. The amendment which Senator Evans foreshadowed clearly indicates that he has not learnt properly from that lesson; his government has not learnt; his legal advisers have not learnt. We are in the same situation.

PARA.TAB: We have the Commonwealth purporting to cover the field. When it covers the field, it is overriding state legislation. The question is: how broad is the field that the government is covering? How much state legislation is it cutting out? How much state legislation is it rendering invalid? Senator Evans ought to know the answer to that. He did not know them when the government did the Racial Discrimination Act. It did not even understand it properly when he tried to fix it up. Hopefully, with a couple of bites at that cherry, he has learnt something, one would have thought. We see by this amendment, for reasons that might now be obvious to Senator Evans if he has turned his mind to it, that he has not properly figured out how to fix it up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I speak—

—You can. The minister puts on this mournfully frustrated face when people want to speak. But unless this matter had been pursued by me and by Senator Bishop, unless we had pressed the point with Senator Evans, we would have slipped past this area as though it was nothing. It is an important point. Senator Chamarette understands that. I repeat to Senator Evans: everybody wants to get this legislation as right as possible. But we are not going to be able to do so if, every time someone raises a point, he shakes his head and says, `Oh, you do not understand'. When we finally pursue the point, in frustration he says, `All right, we will postpone it and get some better advice'. Why does he not try to get it right the first time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was saying to Senator Vanstone that perhaps she and others are tending to under-acknowledge the effect in all of this debate of clause 7, which we have already passed. As a reminder, it says:

PARA.TAB: This Act is not intended to affect the operation of any law of a State or a Territory that is capable of operating concurrently with this Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I think any impact of clause 11 should be read alongside the preserving impact of clause 7. There is still a case for spelling out, in a bit more detail, how this business of concurrent operation might work. That will be the point of the discussion on proposed new clause 196A, when we get to it, in order to spell out for the sake of clarity how this might work in a couple of important areas—hunting, fishing, gathering and so on.

PARA.TAB: If the chamber is concerned to debate these clauses together, I am not unhappy about deferring them. I said at the outset of the debate that, if there is a reasonable request to defer the consideration of some clause until the subject matter arises again or for some other good reason, I am happy to do that as long as the exercise is done in good faith and is not just another delaying tactic of some kind. But I am prepared to accept that there are real questions here that need to be debated. I do not mind dealing with it later with Senator Chamarette's clause when we get to it.

Let me say a couple more things for the record about this. As to the question of whether there are any statutory precedents for a clause of this general kind, giving the common law of Australia in respect of some subject matter the force of law of the Commonwealth, as I indicated, there are quite a number of precedents. Let me just give two that my advisers have quickly pulled out in the last few minutes. Section 80 of the Judiciary Act 1903—going right back to the beginning of the century—states:

SPEECH.PARA: So far as the laws of the Commonwealth are not applicable or so far as their provisions are insufficient to carry them into effect, or to provide adequate remedies or punishment, the common law in Australia as modified by the Constitution and by the statute law in force in the State or Territory in which the Court in which the jurisdiction has exercised is held shall, so far as it is applicable and not inconsistent with the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth, govern all Courts exercising federal jurisdiction in the exercise of their jurisdiction in civil and criminal matters.

That is a general lifting up of that applicable body of common law and making it part of the law of the Commonwealth so far as the exercise of federal jurisdiction by these Commonwealth courts being created by this proposed act is concerned. Another example is section 4 of the Crimes Act 1914, as subsequently amended, which states:
The principles of the common law with respect to criminal liability shall, subject to this Act, apply in relation to offences against this Act.

We could hardly find a much more general provision than that lifting up a whole body of common law and giving it the force and effect of Commonwealth statute law for the purposes of the exercise of a particular area of Commonwealth authority. So that is a sufficient answer to the point that has been raised about the apparent oddity or novelty of clause 11 in that respect. It is not novel; there is a body of Commonwealth precedent to support it.

PARA.TAB: If one is looking for an academic analysis of these sorts of issues and the received body of wisdom on these matters, one can see that page 691 of the second edition of Pat Lane's book The Australian Federal System—an authority much quoted in years gone by in various contexts by the opposition; Professor Lane is certainly a very respectable constitutional lawyer—addresses quite succinctly in half a page of discussion just this kind of point. I will not seek to incorporate it in Hansard or read it to the committee. The point I am trying to make, for constitutional support of this kind of provision, is that there is a body of accepted law understanding about this sort of thing which does not require such formal advice to be given for us to be confident of our capacity to pass laws of this kind.

Senator Chamarette asked me about the reason for this date being as it is. The operative effect of this whole legislation in terms of Commonwealth machinery, Commonwealth rules and, to some extent, Commonwealth overriding provisions is only intended, in effect, to have operation from 1 July this year. We always want to minimise the retrospective impact of legislation. But there are very good reasons, which have been previously debated, for having various provisions of this legislation in force and in effect from that date. We do not think any additional substantive purpose would have been served by purporting to extend this back earlier to 1992, although I can understand the point that Senator Chamarette is making about the significance of the 1992 date when the Mabo decision came down. The provisions of the bill, once enacted, will only have bite from 1 July onwards. That is why the date is expressed in these terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for those examples, but I was wondering whether the minister could indicate whether those examples purport to cover the field in section 109? I do not think there is much question about what they do.

—I forgot to answer that question. It was not a deliberate decision; it was just inadvertence. Life is a learning experience and the law is elsewhere. Whether a court will apply a covering the field test in order to determine incompatibility between a Commonwealth law and a state law on the same subject matter or whether it will employ a line by line inconsistency test is a matter about which there was a degree of uncertainty until we got to the Grzauskas case and the Metwally case. That was part of the evolving body of law as to the way in which section 109 inconsistency issues would be determined by the court. I think, with the knowledge of that case law behind us, the draftsmen can be a bit more confident about the way in which they draft these provisions and a bit more confident in understanding how the High Court is likely to react in applying inconsistency tests for the future. We could get into a long discussion about those individual cases but I think that is the only point that I would wish to make.

—The minister has not yet explained the difference between the judiciary provision that talks about adopting the common law except as modified by the statute, which is a crucial limitation, and the Crimes Act which says that the common law shall merely apply. That is alongside the government's provision which says that it shall have the force of a law of the Commonwealth. If that is the case, and even picking up the minister's point about how the law continues to evolve and the fact that the government would hope that it would reach a position of certainty, there have been a number of examples in recent years of the High Court standing conventional wisdom on its head and suddenly finding that section 92 does not mean what 150 cases before it had said it meant.

PARA.TAB: I would like the minister to tell us whether he has any advice on the significance of using the expression `the force of a law of the Commonwealth', as opposed to a much lesser form of adoption in other statutes. Could the minister also explain to me what the situation would be if at least part of the Western Australian legislation were to survive and case law arise out of it? Would that mean that that case law of a state would then become part of the law of the Commonwealth under this provision?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure I understood the last question. Was the question: what kind of case law applicable to native title is likely to evolve in Western Australia if the Western Australian law survives intact? What the Western Australian law does, in effect, is extinguish all forms of native title and substitute a form of statutory title. I find it difficult to imagine that there would be much scope for the courts in Western Australia or elsewhere to evolve detailed concepts of the content of native title if it has been effectively extinguished by the operation of state law. If Senator Alston can clarify the question, I might be able to answer it.

—The government's legislation attempts to regard other forms of native title, such as traditional usage or anything else, as native title. In those circumstances I would have thought that case law that bears on that which the minister would regard as native title then becomes part of the common law of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I also ask the minister what is meant by the common law of Australia. Presumably, it is not simply a matter of looking at Mabo and identifying what four different judgments had to say about the body of case law that ought to apply in a very narrow situation. All that the High Court was presumably doing was applying the body of common law principles. But what are those principles and how could any lawyer or layman explain what is meant by the common law of Australia for the purposes of clause 11?

TALK.START.PARA: —The expression `common law of Australia' is to distinguish it from the common law of Canada or the common law of other possibly relevant jurisdictions where native title matters have been in issue. It is not a reference to anything else and I would have thought that—
—Forget `Australia'. What does `common law' mean?
—Common law is in a process of evolution as it affects native title. As the High Court itself said—
—So that you will have a statutory—

—With respect, Senator Alston should not carry on in this naive fashion when he knows, and I know, that the High Court said that, as a matter of common law principles, native title is part of the law of Australia—hitherto unrecognised and unacknowledged, but now it is. The High Court said that the content of that native title would be a matter for case by case determination, depending on the particular history of the land in question, the connection of individuals with it and all the rest of it. That is reflected in the definitions of native title that are employed in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: We are not attempting to define with precision the extent and incidence of native title. That will be a matter still for case by case determination through tribunal processes and so on. The crucial element of the common law is the fact that native title as such, as a proprietary right capable of being recognised and enjoyed, and excluding other competing forms of proprietary claim, is recognised as part of the common law of the country, and I think Senator Alston understands that just as well as I do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely we can have a situation where a state might introduce native title legislation and not purport to extinguish. There would then be state common law, or common law principles arising out of state legislation. What the minister has just said suggests to me that he is, in effect, codifying uncertainty. The minister cannot identify what the common law of native title is at any particular point in time because he concedes it evolves, and yet he tries to mandate uncertainty which the courts would have difficulty in applying other than by reference to the common law. So why not let the common law stand alone, and not purport to cover the field?
—I do not want to turn this into a jurisprudence seminar, but if the state were to—
—Which is suggesting that you are capable.
—I am touched again by that bit of flattery from Senator Vanstone. I suggest it is unnecessary—
—So were your insults during the week.

—I am just saying that I do not think anyone in the chamber wants to get into a detailed discussion of the theory and nature of common law versus statute law interpretation and so on. To the extent that I have been asked this question, an evolving body of state court interpretation of state statutory law is manifestly what is not intended to be subsumed by the expression `common law of Australia' in relation to native title. It is a completely different concept that has been introduced by the Western Australian legislation. It is a statutory right based on traditional usage. It has nothing to do with common law native title. As I understand it, the whole point of the Western Australian legislation is to sweep away the Mabo common law native title. (Quorum formed)

PARA.TAB: I think I have said what I needed to say. I have tried to answer Senator Alston's point that the intention here is to refer to the common law of Australia relating to native title as it has now been articulated by the High Court in Mabo and as it subsequently develops. The whole point of this particular clause is simply to ensure that federal courts and federal tribunals are vested with the authority to make these determinations and to move this forward. Of course, we are perfectly happy for state machinery, state tribunals, to perform those same functions simultaneously. There is no reason whatsoever why simultaneous jurisdiction cannot be exercised in this respect. That is the intention that runs through the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If what the minister is now conceding is that this clause is only intended to apply to Commonwealth and Federal Court decisions in relation to the common law of native title, why does it not say so? On the face of it, the clause would clearly cover, for example—
—That is not what I said.
—I thought Senator Evans said that to the extent that the Western Australian—
—State decisions about state statutory title are nothing to do with this. State decisions about native title under the Mabo common law are part of this.
—Precisely. Let us look at the Western Australian Land Titles and Traditional Usage Act 1993. Section 7(2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Rights of traditional usage created by subsection 1(b) in relation to land replaced the rights and entitlements that were incidents of the native title to that land extinguished by subsection 1(a) and, unless this Act provides otherwise, are equivalent in extent to the rights and entitlements that they replace.

That section is purporting to say that, whilst they call it traditional usage, it is equivalent to native title. Therefore, case law arising out of that forms part of the body of the common law in relation to native title. The government's clause would pick that section up and make it part of Commonwealth law, which presumably evolves until such time as it is knocked off by the High Court.

PARA.TAB: I will just give the committee another instance of where the High Court in Mabo was simply one example of a court at a point in time applying some common law principles, rather than in any shape or form purporting to identify what that common law is, because I suggest that that is impossible. The High Court in Mabo said that freehold extinguished native title. But is it not correct that in Pareroultja v. Tickner the Full Court of the Federal Court said that that was not necessarily so? The minister's very point about the common law evolving means that no-one can say what the common law is at any point in time. That is the magic of the common law—that it evolves, and that any single judge—whether it is Denning, Dixon or anyone else—is capable of suddenly giving a different interpretation, going a little bit further and doing what the government's activist High Court seems to do for a living. That is the very opposite of trying to put into statute form a precise provision.

What Senator Evans is doing here is not just picking up some aspects of some head of power; he is purporting to cover the field and adopt the common law, whatever that means. I therefore ask the minister, in view of this unprecedented approach which is clearly designed to shut out any state common law on native title, what authority he has for that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no particular quarrel with the latter part of Senator Alston's description of the way in which the common law evolves and operates and the way in which we cannot predict its precise content. That is in the nature of the common law; I accept that. Nonetheless, at any given point in time, one can ascertain what the state of the common law is and apply it and use it in the way in which this legislation proposes to.

PARA.TAB: I am glad to see Senator Bishop back in the chamber; she may not have heard me over the blower. As I have said, there are precedents—and I mention just a couple of them: section 80 of the Judiciary Act and section 4 of the Crimes Act—where the common law, in relation to a particular subject matter, with all its variability, with all its flexibility, with all its capacity for evolution, has simply been picked up and applied as part of a body of federal law.

The point I do contest is the first part of what Senator Alston said when he tried to develop some fairly extraordinary scenario that the law of Western Australia, as interpreted by the courts under the Western Australian legislation, was somehow becoming, by this means, the law of the Commonwealth. With the utmost respect, that does seem to me to be a complete misconception.

Whatever comparability there may be between common law native title and the new form of statutory title invented and put in place by the Western Australian parliament, it is not the same thing. The Western Australian legislation in terms refers to the creation of a new statutory right to replace the common law right. Any interpretation of that new statutory right is, by definition, the interpretation of a different body of law from the one it is replacing.

There may well be some persuasive utility about court decisions that relate to the new statutory title. They may have some comparability, some persuasive applicability to the jurisprudence as it evolves elsewhere about Commonwealth native title. But it is not the same thing; it is not the same body of jurisprudence; it is about something different. So the notion that this clause somehow picks up and applies, as Commonwealth law, the law as it evolves in Western Australian, if that legislation survives, is, again, with the utmost respect, a misconception.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does not 208 purport to do just that? Does that not purport to say that native title rights and interests converted or replaced by statutory rights and interests are also covered by the expression `native title and native title rights' in this bill?
—Maybe so, but they are not in common law of native title.
—There is nothing on the face of clause 11 that reads in the way that Senator Evans wants to read it.

—There is. It does not say, `in the statute law of native title'; it says, `the common law of native title'. What you are talking about in 208(3) is a statutory provision which operates in a quite different way.

—Case law arising out of that state statute would be common law in respect of native title, surely; but the minister has told us previously that somehow he intends this to be read as applying only to Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The minister again tried to suggest in respect of Senator Bishop that he had discovered a couple of examples of earlier statutes basically picking up the common law holus-bolus. What I said to him was that, as he quoted it, the Judiciary Act limited any transfer as modified by statute, and the Crimes Act merely said that the common law would apply. Neither of them used the expression `shall have the force of a law of the Commonwealth'. Surely that is a quantum leap from what has previously happened in Commonwealth legislation and, again, is unprecedented; and on what authority does the minister use that expression?

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be the meaning of section 80 of the Judiciary Act and section 4 of the Crimes Act that the common law, as picked up and applied, has the force of the law of the Commonwealth. Otherwise any exercise by a court or anyone else of the authority conferred by these sections would be contestable, would be challengeable, because it would not be a proper exercise of judicial authority or the other authority conferred by this clause. The effect of these provisions must be to treat the common law, whatever it is, as here defined and picked up, as having the force of the Commonwealth law.
—`Whatever it is'. That is the acid test.

—Senator Alston has said that the common law, by definition, is variable. So whatever the common law is at any given time has to be a matter for scrutiny and judgment at that particular time. That is why I used the phrase `whatever it is' because it is variable in content. But whatever its content may be at a particular time, it is picked up and applied and has the force of Commonwealth law under the relevant provision of the Crimes Act, under the relevant provision of the Judiciary Act, and that will be the effect of it under clause 11 of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans has just made my point. When I first stood I said that clause 11 should fail because of its uncertainty. The common law is uncertain. Senator Alston made the point clearly; Senator Evans has just admitted it. It is unknown; it is uncertain, and we do not make laws for uncertainty. Senator Evans has deliberately used the words out of clause 109 to attempt to cover the field, to put in place unknown concepts and say that they have the force of law.

PARA.TAB: The analogy that Senator Evans was drawing by saying that there is precedent where particular parts of the common law had been picked up and given statutory authority relates to very specific areas of law which in effect are codified by the statute. I will give Senator Evans an example. The concept of unconscionable conduct was given statutory force in the Trade Practices Act but that was not an attempt to say that all the common law of Australia shall be given the force of law because all the common law of Australia is unknown, even if Senator Evans tries to say as it applies to native title, because the things that apply to native title are far more than this particular piece of legislation.
When I spoke earlier I gave the minister examples of how it can affect the operation of policing of the state, of bushfire protection legislation; there is the whole area of fisheries—

TALK.START.PARA: —The criminal code.

—As Senator Vanstone says, the criminal code. There are whole rafts of state legislation which are affected by native title and Senator Evans was trying to say that the common law shall have the force of law and, therefore, where it is in conflict with the state legislation, the state legislation will be struck down.
—Subject to clause 7.
—Subject to clause 7, which states:

PARA.TAB: This Act is not intended to affect the operation of any law of a State or a Territory that is capable of operating concurrently with this Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly, it is not capable of operating when clause 11 is enacted. That is the whole point.

PARA.TAB: Then in the government's earlier submitted amendment, the government was trying to say that it would reserve the status of the state laws by allowing them to continue to operate despite clause 11. The government then suddenly woke up to the fact that that would not work because it was trying to amend the constitution; so the government is now desperately struggling to find a way to put something into this legislation that will, in effect, allow state legislation to remain effective.

I am putting to Senator Evans that it cannot be done because of the words in clause 11. I would like to hear from Senator Evans an analysis and some opinions that tell him that if the government continues to use the words that are in clause 11 it can have another form of words that can in fact save the operation of state laws and, indeed, preserve our whole concept of federation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to endorse the remarks made by Senator Bishop and expand on one point. As we know, the common law is not comprised of the words of any particular judge or judgment. It is very much an uncertain doctrine of law. There are two matters that trouble me. This provision runs together in an impermissible manner the judicial and legislative power in taking the decisions of courts and converting them into legislation upon their being handed down. When the minister addresses the question put by Senator Bishop, I wonder whether he could address this query as well.

PARA.TAB: In effect, this provision says that the common law shall apply, and the common law operates on precedent and the decisions of judges. It then says that whatever the judges say is law. That is not the way this country ticks. We are elected, as are members in the other place, to represent the people of Australia. We make laws in accordance with the mandate given to us by the people of Australia in an election. The judges of this country are not elected by the people of Australia to make laws. But this is what this provision would be doing. It would say, `Whatever the judges say in relation to common law, that is the law'. So that even if, tomorrow, the judges said, `We were wrong. Mabo was wrong. We are taking away native title', that is what it would do. It would divest native title straight away because what the judges say is law.

That is what clause 11 is doing. It is disgraceful for a number of reasons. Firstly, it cuts clearly across the democratic process of this country and the basic principle that the parliament is the legislator and the parliament is ultimately responsible for the making of laws. Secondly, it leaves the way open for judicial legislation of the most rampant form so that rights may be conferred by judges or rights may be taken away by judges. I ask the minister to comment on that.

I also ask the minister to comment on the concept of state laws failing for inconsistency with Commonwealth law. The Commonwealth law is saying that there is this body of uncertain doctrine which is defined by judges and any state law which conflicts with it is out of order. How can the minister say that when we have a certain state law on one side and an uncertain body of law on the other side? The common law, as we have said and the minister has admitted, is not a certain doctrine; it is not definitive. It is a doctrine which has been developed over hundreds of years by courts and by precedents. Therefore, I would like the minister to explain that aspect of it.

In relation to clause 7, bringing me to my third point, I said yesterday that the phrase `capable of operating concurrently with this act' is a vague one. If we have a state piece of legislation dealing with bushfires and the maintenance of fire breaks, then on any freehold title or leasehold title there is an obligation to maintain fire breaks around that property. This clause says that common law will be a Commonwealth law and it will operate retrospectively; then we look to common law and we see that there is paramountcy of native title.

Senator Bishop's point is a very good one because that then makes any state law subservient because the making of fire breaks would impair native title on that land. It would require the imposition of the making of these breaks—the grading and construction of them. I put it to the minister that that would be an impairment of native title. That would be a general state law which was not capable of operating concurrently with this piece of legislation.
Clause 7 is not clear enough. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act is not intended to affect the operation of any law of a State or Territory that is capable of operating concurrently with this Act.

Can the bushfires legislation of Western Australia, for example, operate concurrently with this act? There is nothing in this bill to assist us in coming to that conclusion or arriving at a decision. It is completely vague. It will only encourage litigation because people will be going off to court saying, `Can the state force these native titleholders to construct fire breaks? Can the state have legislation which demands the native titleholders abide by certain requirements of health or environment. Can the State Energy Commission build a power line across a part of the native title land?'. Those are the questions I am asking. They are all there for a public purpose. Any landowner in this country is subject to those state requirements—health, prevention of bushfires, environmental protection and the provision of public works.

PARA.TAB: This bill does not spell out clearly how the two are going to operate together. Whilst there is not any clarity and whilst there is uncertainly, it will be a breeding ground for litigation. I ask the minister to comment on those three aspects.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the question of there being a common law of the Commonwealth which exists quite independently of any interpretation of Commonwealth statutes or other evolution of Commonwealth law of that kind, this is an old issue that has been debated for as long as I can remember. I suppose the majority view is that there are probably some areas—for example, frauds committed by public office holders in certain circumstances—which are not presently governed by specific statutory provision but in relation to which the common law would be regarded as being applicable if situations ever arose. That is one example that is given. The notion of entirely judge-made law having a status as law of the Commonwealth, other than laws of the Commonwealth which have some statutory foundation, probably has some precedent and some existence other than in this context.

PARA.TAB: As to the business of laws capable of operating concurrently, of course it is the case that most other forms of proprietary right in this country do not in any way immunise the proprietary right holder from the application of laws of general application, be they about health, conservation, bushfire protection or anything else. That is exactly as it should be. I would think it inconceivable that in the case of bushfire protection legislation and things of this kind, which manifestly involve some overriding public interest, any court could construe clause 7 in such a way as to say that that kind of law was not capable of operating concurrently with native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not spell that out in the legislation?
—We are going to spell out some specific aspects of this when we get to section 196.
—Why don't we postpone this until we get there?

—I said about 25 minutes ago that I am perfectly happy to defer it. Senator Bishop asked to defer it and I say we are happy to defer it until then, but the opposition keeps on pursuing issues and gets very grumpy if I seek to defer. I am trying to respond to as many of the issues that are raised now in the hope that we will not simply repeat all this later. It is reasonable to debate these issues in the context of a particular clause which addresses them.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the only kind of context which has any real practical area of concern at the moment tends to be in that hunting, gathering, fishing area where there are a number of laws of general application which would operate absolutely to ban or prohibit fishing rights, hunting rights or whatever. For example, there are those areas of the law which create commercial fisheries and have a licensing system and one can only fish pursuant to a licence and everyone else is absolutely prohibited.

Perhaps the South Coast abalone fishermen of New South Wales is a good example of this sort of area because some local Aboriginal people have been prosecuted for seeking to gather abalone for essentially personal family domestic use, not in the purported exercise so far as a native title right is concerned, but it may arise in the future that this does acquire a recognised native title character. Then we would have a square conflict between an absolute prohibition of any kind of abalone fishing combined with a legitimate native title claim to do a little bit of fishing and gathering on a small scale which would not intrude upon the commercial fishery.

In that kind of dilemma it seems to me that perhaps we can right now give some kind of statutory guidance as to how that issue might be resolved. I hope the clause is about to be circulated, but it is a long way before we get to it. This will address that kind of issue.

As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) frankly acknowledged, there are a number of issues that will arise across a number of different areas which do require some thoughtful review of the present applicability of some of these laws of general application. One simply cannot anticipate, as Senator Bishop quite rightly says, all the situations that might arise in future. But it will be some time before we are going to have the processes of determination of native title worked through with proper definition of what the nature and extent of a particular native title right might be in areas that might give rise to these sorts of concerns. So there is a reasonable time for this kind of process of more thoughtful review to take place.

In the meantime, we simply do not believe that it is remotely likely that courts would act as irrationally as has been suggested in striking down the applicability of obvious laws of public interest relating to health, bushfire protection or whatever, and the language of clause 7 is deliberately designed to give them encouragement not to do so.

That is the kind of answer I would give it, but if the opposition wants to defer further consideration of this until we get to proposed section 196A, I am perfectly happy to do that. The opposition has asked me to do that. Senator Chamarette has indicated that she is willing to do that and Senator Kernot has indicated that. Perhaps we ought to do just that. Might I suggest that we defer further consideration of this clause until we get to proposed section 196A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When will we get to that?
—With a bit of luck and a bit of application—
—I am not into luck. What about application?
—With a little bit of application and dignified focus on the substantive issues and a little less point scoring, we might be able to get there later in the day.

—This matter is going to be deferred until later in the day so that we can get the amendments which the minister has kept saying are coming, coming, coming. But there are a couple of points he and the Green senators might like to bear in mind. What has been raised here is the completely novel aspect of proposed section 11.

PARA.TAB: No-one denies that there are other Commonwealth statutes that purport in some way to pick up the common law. But what we do say is that this is a completely novel clause in the sense that it uses the wording of section 109 and says that the common law has the force of law of the Commonwealth. In other words, the government is quite clearly trying to cover the field completely under section 109 and block out the applicability of any state laws that might otherwise apply.

In the next breath the minister says, `We are not knocking out anything that could operate concurrently' which is a somewhat inconsistent statement. If he wants to cover the field, he wants to say, `The Commonwealth has the right to make these laws—all of them, full stop', rather than, `The states have some sort of concurrent power'.

Covering the field locks out the states. What we want is an example, which we have not yet been provided with, of where the Commonwealth has purported to cover the field by simply a one-line clause adopting common law. That is the first point we want an answer to. All of the rantings and ravings of the minister have not yet given us that answer.

The second point we want an answer to is whether the minister thinks the proposal in any event could be held to be valid as opposed to void for uncertainty. The common law of native title is not like the common law relating to, for example, unconscionable conduct that we might use in the Trade Practices Act or some other recognised and well-developed body of common law. This is completely new.

Senator Alston gave an example of where the High Court said one thing in Mabo No. 2 and then in a couple of Federal Court cases the Federal Court said, `Well, it might have appeared as though they said that, but they did not mean that'. We have a very uncertain body of law and we want minister's response to the allegation that this should be void for uncertainty. It is no satisfaction to have the minister saying, `We are all pretty sure this is all okay'.

I am frankly amazed that, with the complexity of the arguments being raised—not those raised here today, but those raised by senior, well-respected constitutional lawyers—the Commonwealth basically says, `We haven't got any advice because we don't need it; we are right'. There is a very long list of examples where, by rushing, we have got it wrong and seen later that we have to get it right. Two come to mind from this year that we have had to redo. One was the bankruptcy law and another was the copyright law. Everyone was sure they were right there.

The third point I make does not relate to the substance of the clause in itself. It relates to the schedule put before us, A to U, the manageable schedule according to the government. The government says that if we follow it and go through it seriatim, everything would be okay. We are only up to D—we have all the way down to U to go—and this is the second time the government has not been ready to deal with matters as they should be dealt with, the second time we have had to have a deferral.

I do not deny that deferrals are a better way to go, but I am saying that, since this is the second time so early in the debate, yet again it raises the question that what we should be doing is deferring this bill until 1 February. This is going to happen again and again as we go through this bill because the minister is simply not ready to answer the detail.

We agree to the deferral of consideration of laws of general application until we come to the proposed section 33 amendment of Senator Chamarette—we are happy to do that—but this second deferral, so early on in the debate, ought to be advice to the minister that he should defer the whole bill until 1 February and get it right the first time. So early in the debate, yet again, he is not ready to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst this matter is going to be deferred, it appears to consider other aspects, I have a point to raise with Senator Evans, if he can spend some time listening to the debate instead of trying to do another deal with the Democrats. Why he does not just lock them into the Labor Party and have them part of the caucus so that he does not have to bother running backwards and forwards—
—Stop wasting time.
—It would save a lot of time if Senator Carr was not here, with his inane interjections. That would be much more appropriate and perhaps we could have a debate then that the minister might listen to.
—Sorry?
—Thank you, minister, for giving us your undivided attention instead of doing deals around the place.
—I was just having a chat, actually.
—I know. As I say, why you do not put the Democrats in your party and lock them in on a caucus vote instead of having to deal with them all the time—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Ian Macdonald, address your remarks through the chair. It would be appreciated if you address the question in front of the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your language and your style reflect on you.

—Senator Kernot is all very sensitive about this. It is one of those cases where the truth hurts. I was just asking the minister to have a look at—when he does defer this matter to come back to us later—an issue which has arisen in Queensland, relating to environment laws. Does this bill, and the matters that Senator Vanstone and Senator Ellison have been talking about, in fact say that the native title rights of hunting and foraging will overcome the state laws?

PARA.TAB: The Queensland laws relating to the environment, and specifically certain protected species, are the same, I am sure, as in every other state. The instance I refer to is one involving the echidna. Some Aboriginal people claimed that, although it was a protected and, I understand, endangered species, they had a right to hunt that animal in contravention of the Queensland laws providing an absolute ban on the killing or taking of echidnas. Can the minister give me now or, if he cannot, include in the briefing and explanation he is going to give at a later date in relation to these matters, whether those sorts of aspects will be addressed and whether there will be some clarity about what happens there?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that issue will be addressed, and I hope that there will be clarity. I move:

PARA.TAB: That further consideration of clause 11 be postponed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Clause 12 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I understood that Senator Faulkner was going to come in and move a procedural motion. I have come back for that.

—I do not know what is going on in that respect. I think there was some misunderstanding about that. Senator Faulkner was going to circulate a motion in the chamber, but I do not think he was proposing to move it at this stage.
—He was.
—If so, that was a misunderstanding on our side. I apologise for that.
—We are looking for some guidance as to what is going to happen after midnight tonight.

—We will circulate a proposed motion which will give you an expression of our intention in this respect. Perhaps we can debate it later in the day. Can we now try to make some progress on substantive issues?
—At what time?

—Sometime later this afternoon when we have a better idea of how much progress we are making. I think it is just too early to be making judgments about that. Nonetheless, there will be a motion expressing a possible course of action for the consideration of those opposite.

—Although the government does not seem to be particularly interested, the timings that it has set for the sittings are causing enormous inconvenience to a lot of people. I think those people have some right to make reasonable plans for the future between now and Christmas. On the progress that has been made, it seems to me—and nobody could say that in any way there has been anything like a filibuster; it has been a sound debate on highly complex legal issues—unlikely, almost impossible, that this matter will be concluded today, unless of course the government gets the numbers and guillotines the debate.

PARA.TAB: Already there have been two principal clauses deferred because the minister has acknowledged shortcomings in the government amendments. Already we have had the government going away and seeking to redraft its own amendments—and this is in the middle of the debate.
