The amendments were made on the run and—surprise, surprise—they are deficient, so the government is having to go away and redraft them. We know from long experience that, whenever that practice is adopted, the amendment that is made on the run to redraft the one that had been made on the run, it never is right and it just leads to further problems down the track. Those debates are still to be had today. The time has been lost. The government did not do the work properly and did not produce sound amendments, so we now have to have that debate again later in the day. If this is going to continue as it has so far, there is no way, after sensible debate, that this matter will be concluded by midnight tonight.

We have already expressed to the government our view that it is wrong in principle that the parliament sit on Sunday. Over and above all the issues of normal and reasonable labour behaviour in relation to the staff in this place, we want to know what is going to happen after midnight tonight so that at least people can make some plans for the future. I do not think we should have to wait until mid-afternoon or teatime tonight to be told what is going to happen in that regard. Why can the government not tell us its plan in relation to the program?

TALK.START.PARA: —I had hoped to be able to defer consideration of this matter until later in the day, while nonetheless giving the chamber some indication of intention, but since those opposite seem determined to have a procedural debate now, we will probably only be repeating ourselves if we have it later in the day, so perhaps we ought to go ahead with it now. Accordingly, I will leave it to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate to move the motion.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That, if the Senate is sitting at 12 midnight tonight, the sitting of the Senate then be suspended till 10.00 a.m. Monday, 20 December 1993.
(2)That on Monday, 20 December 1993, the sitting of the Senate be suspended from 1.00 p.m. till 2.00 p.m. and 6.00 p.m. till 7.00 p.m.

(3)That, following a subsequent suspension of the sitting of the Senate on Monday, 20 December 1993, the sitting of the Senate resume at 9.00 a.m. on Tuesday, 21 December 1993 and be suspended on that day from 1.00 p.m. till 2.00 p.m., and from 6.00 p.m. till 7.00 p.m.

Honourable senators will recall that last night, during debate about whether or not the sitting of the Senate should suspend and recommence today, it was made clear that the government's intention was that the Senate sit today and tomorrow to complete consideration on this extremely important legislation. It was hoped that it would be concluded today, but obviously there may have been a requirement for us to go into Sunday. During that debate last night a number of opposition senators clearly indicated that because of their religious convictions they believed it was inappropriate for the Senate to sit on Sunday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you not have any of those on your side?
—It was not only opposition senators.
—Be a bit sensitive to other people's views for a change.

—In fact, I am—as is the government—being sensitive to those people who expressed those views strongly in the Senate chamber last night. As the interjections raised the question of what might or might not be the religious beliefs of other senators, I think it is also worth pointing out that that was not a view limited only to opposition senators. In fact, I think most fair-minded senators in this chamber who remember the debate will recall that other senators also raised some concerns.

PARA.TAB: The fervent hope of this government is that we can complete this legislation before midnight tonight. I sincerely hope that it is possible, and I believe that with the cooperation of all honourable senators in the chamber it not only is achievable but will be achieved. However, I do accept that that is one thing that I personally cannot be held responsible for or control.

Given that circumstance, and given the views that were expressed in the chamber, I do believe that it is appropriate for us to suspend the sittings this evening and come back on Monday and Tuesday next week if, in fact, we need to. That will give people the opportunity to make any religious observances that they may wish to undertake tomorrow. I am very keen that all honourable senators will have the opportunity to organise their diaries, and I think it is only reasonable for the government to indicate at this point what its plans are in terms of the sitting of the chamber.

The proposition that I have moved is responsible and reasonable in the difficult circumstances that we all accept we have at this stage—obviously, debating this bill when most people would prefer to be wending their way home. It is the best possible pattern of sittings that we can have in these circumstances. I have discussed this proposal with—

TALK.START.PARA: —With the Democrats and the Greens.

—That is true; I have indeed discussed it with the Democrats and the Greens, and with Senator Harradine and the opposition. This proposal has been broadly understood. I believe that, in the circumstances that we face and given the convictions that were expressed sincerely by senators in this chamber yesterday when we debated today's sitting, this is an appropriate way for us to deal with the routine of business for the remainder of these sittings. I commend this motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing to get absolutely clear is that the government is solely responsible for the shambles in which we find the legislative program at the moment. We are here sitting at lunchtime on a Saturday, just before Christmas, because the government was unable to get its legislative program into any reasonable order. It was the government's decision to bring the Native Title Bill on yesterday—a day after the Senate was supposed to have risen—and to then debate over 200 amendments. That is the government's decision; the shambles is solely its responsibility.

PARA.TAB: The government knows the pressure that is on at this time of the year. It knows the consequences for staff. It knows the threats that have been within this place—very reasonably in these circumstances—of industrial action because people are being required to work ridiculous hours. It does not care a hoot. It does not care whether the quality of this legislation is sound or not.

What we have had as a result is a debate that has clearly demonstrated major failings in the legislation before us; there are major shortcomings within the amendments. That is not surprising. As I said a moment or two ago, we cannot produce those amendments on the run and expect them to be always technically correct. It ought to be a great embarrassment to the government that this would occur, but it does not seem to care. It is not concerned about the quality of this legislation at all. It simply wants a bill passed, come what may, no matter what, by Christmas time because it can see the fragile consensus for this legislation in Australia crumbling before it. That is not good legislative practice.

As a result, the government has already had to acknowledge that its amendments are deficient. It has already had to send the draftsmen away to redraft those amendments. We do not know when the amendments will come into this chamber. We do not know what state the amendments will be in. What opportunity will the chamber have for any sort of independent legal analysis of the amendments that are yet to be produced? What does Senator Evans say? He says, `They will come up in due course. Don't worry about that. With cooperation something will be got through by the end of the night'.

I put it to the Senate that, if the Senate does its job properly—that is, if it analyses and carefully debates the matters that are before it, including the matters that we are told are still to come before us that we have not yet got before us—this bill will not be settled by midnight tonight. The government should have known that as of yesterday. Yesterday, the government had done the deal within the family—the Democrats, Greens, Labor Party alliance—that we would go on sitting today. We now find that apparently the family has met this morning and has decided that, in view of the fact that the bill is unlikely to be concluded by midnight tonight, we will now come back on Monday—the week before Christmas—and continue this process, no matter how inconvenient that might be to an enormous number of people and no matter that it is going to result in poor quality legislation. We regard this process as totally unsatisfactory. We protest it again and we will continue to protest it. It is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you pass the bill?

—Senator Bolkus can sit there and giggle away as much as he likes. He is not interested in the quality of this legislation at all. All he is interested in is getting a bill, come what may, so that he can say to a particular constituency, `We achieved something'. That is all the government is seeking out of this. That is not good legislative practice. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "That", substitute "at the conclusion of the sitting this day, the Senate stand adjourned till 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 1 February 1994".

The effect of this amendment would be to bring this farce to a close at midnight tonight. We are here, we are stuck here. Honourable senators might well say to me that it would be sensible for us to get up at a reasonable time on Saturday night. But it looks as though we are here until midnight on Saturday night. But thereafter, if the Senate is to be sensible, it will say that we will now take the matter away, think about it, work on these amendments sensibly during January, take proper legal advice and come back here and debate the bill and conclude the bill in February in a way that can produce the best quality outcome. That ought to be a sentiment that is appreciated by every senator in this place, even including the Labor Party, but I would have liked to have thought it would also include the Democrats and the Greens.

PARA.TAB: What is to be lost by adopting that sensible practice? There is nothing to be lost at all. No-one will be disadvantaged by that practice. There is no downside at all. It is all on the upside. It means that the Greens and the Democrats would say to the government, `Enough is enough of this farce. Let's go away and finally do the job properly so that we will not all be embarrassed in the end by deficient legislation'. Sensible practice is all we are asking of the chamber at this late moment.

What we have before us at the moment is totally unsatisfactory. What we put to the chamber as an alternative is a sensible outcome. We would like to think that, even at this late moment, there would be a majority within this chamber than decides that, finally, it is time to behave sensibly and to tell this government that it can no longer get away with the sort of practices that it is seeking to inflict on the Australian parliament.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed.
Clause 13.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5)Clause 13, page 9, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2) To avoid any doubt, if a past act validated by subsection (1) is the making, amendment or repeal of legislation, subsection (1) does not validate:
(a)the grant or issue of any lease, licence, permit or authority; or
(b)the creation of any interest in relation to land or waters;

SPEECH.PARA: under any legislation concerned, unless the grant, issue or creation is itself a past act attributable to the Commonwealth.".
(7)Clause 18, page 11, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2) To avoid any doubt, if a past act validated by subsection (1) is the making, amendment or repeal of legislation, subsection (1) does not validate:
(a)the grant or issue of any lease, licence, permit or authority; or
(b)the creation of any interest in relation to land or waters;

SPEECH.PARA: under any legislation concerned unless the grant, issue or creation is itself a past act attributable to the State or Territory.".

Amendment No. 5 to clause 13 is designed simply to make perfectly clear that, even though past legislation may be validated, future grants under that legislation have to comply with this bill. Similarly, government amendment No. 7, which is directed to clause 18, is designed to clarify its effect, again so as to say that if the validated past act consists of the making, amendment or repeal of legislation, this validation does not of itself validate all the acts that are made under that legislation.

PARA.TAB: Any act which is to be so validated has to be within the definition of `past act' under clause 213 of this bill in order to be validated. The point of these amendments is simply to get a greater degree of clarity into a rather technical corner of the bill. I do not think there is any substantive policy point in issue here; it is just a matter of getting absolute clarity that the effect of the validation in question is confined as I have described, and does not have a larger possible effect. That was a possible implication in the original draft and we have sought to deal with that implication in this way.

I understand that the Democrats' amendments, designed to achieve the same result but using slightly different drafting, will not be pursued, but that is for the Democrats to indicate for themselves. I hope they find it possible to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the minister amplify the points he is making. In particular, is it not the case that what the government is doing by this clause—and this is not affected by the amendment—is validating past Commonwealth acts, and quite specifically not validating past state acts?

—That is a matter for the states. We are not able to do that as a matter of constitutional capacity. The states have to do that themselves. The scheme of the legislation is that the Commonwealth does what it can do in areas within its own jurisdiction and then makes it possible for the states to do what is within their own jurisdiction. That is how the bill is constructed. We can only go a certain distance and that is why this is confined in this way.We want the states to act in this way to validate these acts to create the same degree of certainty. That is the point of the kind of legislation that has already been introduced or foreshadowed in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. I hope that is clear. If it is not, I am happy to try to clarify the matter further.

—Will the minister indicate what the constitutional limitation is on the Commonwealth doing this for the states? Will the minister also explain why the government is saying that it is up to the states, but they can only validate those acts provided they do so in accordance with the government's scheme of things? This is not a matter for the states, according to this legislation. It is only a matter for the states if they do it the government's way. The government is taking away from the states their rights to deal with the land as they see fit and to validate what they want to in the way they want to.

—The latter part is not true. Certain other consequences flow if the states do accept the whole package—how all jurisdictional provisions work out, who gets to do what in terms of the determination of native title, and so on. If it can be done on a cooperative basis, then so much the better. That is the attitude that most of the states have so far had. It is not in that way an attempt to be intrusive—on the contrary.

PARA.TAB: Regarding Senator Vanstone's first question, what we are talking about is grants of interest in land, whether mining interests, pastoral interests or whatever. The Commonwealth simply constitutionally cannot grant those interests. If we cannot grant them we cannot equally validate possibly invalid grants in that past. That has to be a matter for the states.

The Commonwealth can do certain things to protect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people under the exercise of its constitutional power. There are all sorts of other heads of constitutional power under which the Commonwealth can, in various ways, limit aspects of that land management regime. But the basic business of issuing proprietary interests to mining companies or pastoral lessees is and must continue to be a matter for the states. We cannot trespass in that territory. It is not possible for the Commonwealth to do that. That is the basic reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up two aspects. The minister said it is not possible. Why is it not possible? What is the limitation on the Commonwealth doing that?
—The constitution.

—Perhaps the minister could spell out that constitutional argument. I, for one, do not immediately see what he means by that. Will the minister say what type of Commonwealth acts he imagines the Commonwealth is seeking to validate here. He said the mining and pastoral matters have to be left to the states. It is the matters that do not have to be left to the states that the Commonwealth seeks to validate. What are the things that the Commonwealth thinks it can do that it wants to validate?

—So far as the validation is concerned, things that are in the Commonwealth domain would be, for example, offshore fishing and offshore interests which are not within the state territorial waters. Another example would be Commonwealth grants of interests over what has been hitherto defence land or land specifically vested in the Commonwealth that we deal with in some way. Those are examples of things that are within Commonwealth jurisdiction. To some extent the ACT might be, but probably not. That is a matter for the ACT legislature.

PARA.TAB: To answer the more general question about why the Commonwealth has not got the power to issue mining grants, that simply follows from the structure of the constitution. The Commonwealth only has legislative power to do things which are specifically set out in the provisions of the constitution conferring power upon the Commonwealth. The states have the power to do everything else. The states have the residual powers; the Commonwealth only has those that are vested in it. I do not think even in the most adventurist, centralist spirit one could find a head of power on which to hang a Commonwealth capacity at large—and that is what we are talking about—to make grants of mining interests, pastoral interests and all the rest of it in areas of purely state territorial responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that one of the heads of constitutional power the government is seeking to rely on to pass this bill is to make laws with respect to a particular race. The validation of past acts is a part of that law, and the minister is saying the Commonwealth can only act in so far as it relates to the Commonwealth's existing power. Why can we not extend that argument? Where does the minister see this stopping?
—That is an interesting argument coming from Senator Vanstone's side of the chamber.

—It is not an argument I am putting. The minister has said that we can use the race power yet in the next breath said, `But I can't use it to do this'. I am trying to get from the minister some understanding of where he sees the limitations of that power.

—We can use the race power to protect Aboriginal people from the operation of state laws of various kinds that negatively impact upon them. We cannot use the race power in order to do basic things that are properly within state competence but which may have some implications for a subject matter that is within Commonwealth control. What we are talking about is the Commonwealth validating grants that may be invalid by virtue of the operation of native title combined with some other law.

PARA.TAB: The classic case is a pastoral lease that might conceivably be invalid by post-1975 by virtue of the existence of native title plus the existence of the Commonwealth Racial Discrimination Act. A corrective exercise is necessary in that context. It is not a correction that the Commonwealth can make because the effect of making the correction would be, in effect, to make the original grant all over again of the mining interest or the pastoral interest. I want to make it absolutely clear that the Commonwealth has no ambitions whatsoever to get into those areas of state land management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet.

—I am indebted again to Senator Kemp for his confidence in the Commonwealth's integrity and good faith in these matters. He should calm down; we have a long day—perhaps a long week—ahead of us. There are limitations to what it is even sensible to contemplate the Commonwealth doing and this is way outside those limits.

—My question to the minister is: what test can be applied to determine whether or not a prior grant by the Commonwealth is valid? As I see it, the bill does not necessarily provide a test as such. Is it the case that, in the absence of any statutory definition, each grant must be tested in a court on a case by case basis?

—No. There are circumstances which can be contemplated for Commonwealth grants as for state grants where it may possibly be that there has been some invalidity, but the whole point of the legislation is to try to anticipate and avoid that issue being tested on a case by case basis. It is rather to anticipate the possibility that there may be some such invalid grants and to correct them immediately, at the beginning, at the threshold, as soon as possible, by a stroke of the legislative pen, as it were. That is the intention. One of the main reasons for having this whole legislation is to avoid any continuing, lingering uncertainty and a need to test that on a case by case basis. That is one of the reasons why we want the legislation to be clear and certain.
—A question flows from that. Are you saying that all these invalid acts, no matter what they might be, are now validated?
—In essence, yes.

—But there is no test as to what is invalid. So people do not know what requires validation. If somebody comes along and says, `This act is invalid' and the other side says, `No, it's been validated', there is still an argument about whether it is invalid, is there not?

—The whole point is that we do not need to know whether any particular past act may have been invalid. What we are doing with a stroke of the legislative pen is saying: to the extent there may have been any invalidity, that is now corrected, the slate is wiped clean and certainty is recreated. This is one of the great virtues of this piece of legislation for Senator Ellison's constituency—for farmers, miners, potential investors in those industries and others in this country who might otherwise be living in some fear that litigation might be sought relying on the Racial Discrimination Act post-1975 and possibly striking something down.

PARA.TAB: That fear goes as a result of this validation exercise. That is why it is so important that it be accomplished in those interests. We just do not need to look at this on a case by case basis. All that will happen if this legislative clause is agreed to is that possibly invalid things will have exactly the same status as timelessly valid things. There is no difference between them. The slate is clean. Equality is restored. There is no advantage to anyone in poking and prying around and seeking to get some determination.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—Before I call Senator Ellison, I suggest that he directs his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an aside, I would like to think that my constituency is wider than that indicated by the minister. I represent the great state of Western Australia with all its diverse interests. I take that point and I think it is important to place on the record that this is what it is doing. Obviously, what we say in this chamber could well be reflected on in the future by other places in litigation perhaps and other issues.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister: is there any difference in the effect between a past valid act and a past invalid act? What we have is that question of a past invalid act being validated and thereby extinguishing native title, but the bill seems to be silent on the effect of a valid act which was existing quite competently. I appreciate that the government wants to validate the invalid acts and that it says validation thereby extinguishes native title, but what about the valid acts? There seems to be a silence in relation to the effect of the valid acts. Could the minister point to anywhere in the bill which deals with that? Could he clarify that?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is assumed, I guess, that valid acts have accomplished extinguishment and all the rest of it. Nonetheless, that is still a matter that is left to be tested in the courts, if anyone wants to do so. I imagine at some stage there may be a test case to clarify once and for all whether the effect of a past valid act in the context, say, of a pastoral lease or a mining lease, is to accomplish full extinguishment of the native title or only to the extent of inconsistency or whatever. So that matter is left to the courts to finally resolve.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt about the validity of the lease and the capacity to go on exercising the rights under it. But, in the case of the invalid grants, there would obviously be a huge question mark about what the status of the current occupancy was if we did not get it right by statute. There is no real question mark about the capacity of the occupant to go on exercising the occupancy and engaging in the economic interests and questions so far as past valid leases are concerned. The only residual question mark is whether there is some residual native title right that might bounce back to life once the interest is exhausted or something of that kind, and that is a matter that is left to be tested.

In our proposed new clause 24, which we will deal with later on, one thing we did want to make clear was that, when it comes to renewals, extensions and so on, people with past validly granted interests would be in exactly the same position as those with validated past interests. It is to get an extra degree of certainty in that respect that the proposed amendment to clause 24 has been foreshadowed. But, in terms of the basic capacity to enjoy the interest in question, to derive economic advantage from it, there is no doubt about that so far as past valid interests are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the minister agree then that there is a difference in this bill between what it does by validating past acts and the actual Mabo decision? What the minister is saying is that by validating these past invalid acts, that extinguishes native title, whereas the Mabo decision said that a crown grant could extinguish native title only if there were a plain and clear intention to do so. By this validation process the government is providing a much more definite and sweeping extinguishment of native title than that which was provided for in the Mabo decision, because that depended on the nature of the grant as to intention and how it operated adversely to native title. Would the minister agree that this is different from what the High Court decided in the Mabo decision and, in fact, is more adverse to native title than the High Court decision itself?

—Our reading of the High Court decision is that it is overwhelmingly likely that when this comes to be formally decided again—no doubt it will be the subject at some stage of some further decision—the High Court decision will confirm that properly granted pastoral leases, for example, do in fact extinguish native title. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said as much. That is our legal judgment, that is our belief, that although the High Court did leave a sliver of doubt, as Senator Ellison puts it—and I am not sure whether Senator Ellison is listening—
—We all try to listen and do things at the same time. You do it all the time.

—That is because I am taking advice; I am trying to respond. All I am trying to say is that we do not genuinely believe that there is much room for doubt about what the status of extinguishment is in relation to past valid titles, although we acknowledge that there is some degree of residual uncertainty with the High Court case, and that probably has to be tested at some stage just to clarify it.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that the economic interests can be fully enjoyed, however, so far as past valid title is concerned. Nobody need feel that their interests are pressured or threatened in any way. The difficulty we had to deal with in the legislation in confronting the possibility that there were past invalid acts, however, was the need to create instantly some certainty for the land-holders in question as to what precisely the status of their rights actually were.

We thought the best way of creating that certainty—and this was a very difficult issue which obviously involved a great deal of debate, particularly with the Aboriginal community and so on—was to incorporate in legislation our judgment of what the High Court is in fact likely to do when it is confronted eventually again with the issue of what is the effect, for example, of a valid pastoral lease.

I guess that we have anticipated what we believed the law actually is. There was a necessity, because there had to be statutory re-creation of the interest in question and because there is all this doubt about what the status of everybody's interests would be if the original grant was invalid, for us to be that much more explicit in order to get the degree of economic and other certainty that everybody wanted. That is why the thing has been left that way.

I repeat that, so far as past valid acts are concerned, we do believe that they accomplished extinguishment in both the standard pastoral lease type situation and the mining lease type situation on the basis of what the High Court has said. Accordingly, we felt there was no need—because there is no doubt about the capacity to go on exercising it in the economic interest in question—to address that specifically.

There has been an issue of whether or not we need to address specifically the status of past valid grants when it comes to renewals and extensions. That is why we propose to introduce some extra clarification so far as clause 24 is concerned. But that is a different issue from the status of the original grants themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the answer given by the minister, I would like to place my view on the record in relation to these two clauses. I started out by referring to a statement by Simon Crean on 2 February 1993 at the ABARE conference, where he stated:

PARA.TAB: In October last year, the government in responding to the High Court decision on native title, made it clear that existing grants of interest in relation to property will continue, and it is wrong to see the High Court's decision in terms of existing land holders losing their land.
We remain committed to this principle and the Commonwealth, in cooperation with the states, would, if necessary, act to ensure that the rights of existing land holders are protected.

SPEECH.PARA: That was a principle espoused to reassure people and ensure that existing land titles and interests would be protected.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it from the minister, whilst past invalid acts are now validated, and thereby extinguish native title—I can appreciate how that works—we still have the problem with valid acts not enjoying the same status. If one was the beneficiary of a past act and wanted to extinguish native title, one would be better off arguing that it was an invalid act so that it would then be validated and extinguish native title completely. However, if one had a valid act, one would be in a lesser position because, as stated by the minister, it may be that there has to be a testing as to what effect past valid acts actually have.

We have the rather curious position where a past invalid act can enjoy more benefit at law than a past valid act. I just find that inappropriate and it needs clarification. For those who are interested in maintaining native title, these two clauses actually roll back the High Court's decision in Mabo because they say that past invalid acts are now validated and extinguish native title completely, whereas the High Court, as I understood it, said in Mabo that native title is only extinguished with these past acts if there was a clear intention to do so and the act was adverse or contrary to the exercise of native title.

In effect, I see a downside for Aboriginal Australians, pastoral leaseholders and mining leaseholders because I think that those that have a valid act do not enjoy as strong a position as those that were the subject of an invalid act. On the other side of the coin, those who wish to claim native title might not be in as strong a position as they would under the decision of Mabo in the High Court.

Until I am convinced otherwise and it can be demonstrated accordingly, I believe that these two clauses taken together are detrimental to two areas of interest which, on the face of it, would be at odds with each other. It is strange that we have provisions like this which do not really seem to help anyone. For that reason, I am opposed to them. It is another demonstration of a flaw in this bill where it just has not quite been thought through. There has also, of course, been the lack of time and attention paid to this legislation to make it work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would agree that Senator Ellison has picked up a perversity in the legislation which is that if there is an invalidity in one's title then this legislation validates it. If, however, there is no invalidity in one's title, then this legislation provides absolutely no protection. It is an extraordinary situation.

PARA.TAB: But more importantly, Senator Ellison is quite right in saying that Mr Crean gave an assurance at the ABARE conference that all currently held land-holders would be protected and that there was no chance of their losing the land. The government has already said that its view of the Mabo High Court decision was that, where there was a validly issued title, it extinguished native title. Why is it that in this legislation the government does not clearly and explicitly give effect to that proposition, if that is what it believes, in accordance with what Mr Crean said at the ABARE conference?

What the government is in fact doing in creating this loophole is inviting further litigation in this matter; it is inviting further claims; and it is inviting more uncertainty which will erode the value of people's existing pastoral properties. That is the concern that we on this side of the chamber have with the attitude that the government has taken.

Why does the government only say that it will protect the invalid and not look after the valid? This creates a situation where the government is seemingly holding out some hope that people will get even more by lodging more claims, when it is clearly of the view that these claims should not succeed. The government has given a commitment to industry and not just at the ABARE conference. A paper prepared by Mr Higgins on behalf of the government and presented in the June 1993 issue of Mining Review states:

SPEECH.PARA: That commitment stands—
that is, Mr Crean's commitment stands—
and was reiterated by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Resources, Mr Michael Lee, in the meeting with the industry representatives in April.

With due respect, minister, it does not seem that this particular legislation meets the undertakings given by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and by Mr Lee in their April meeting with industry leaders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can comment on this to anticipate some further points of the same kind being made. It is worth repeating that if we are talking about a valid prior grant—about which there is no question, threat or suggestion of invalidity—what this means is that the interest that is granted by a valid pastoral lease or a valid mining lease can be fully exercised, fully enjoyed.

PARA.TAB: If the nature of the pastoral lease in question is such as to vest exclusive rights of occupancy, that means just exactly that. Other people can be excluded physically from doing anything on the property, even though there might be some conceivable non-extinguished native title still there and capable of revival at some future stage. I am reminded that `valid' is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't you read?

—I could not read which bit of the page I was being referred to because there is a mass of bits of scribble on it. Also I cannot read when I have my glasses on because they are for long distance as distinct from short distance. If Senator Crane gave me some bifocals, I would be much better.

PARA.TAB: Just to reinforce the point—and I am indebted to my adviser for confusing me on the matter—`valid' includes `having full force and effect', which is what I was saying. But there it is; it is in the statute. `Having full force and effect' means just that. If the terms or the legal nature of the pastoral lease is to give one exclusive occupancy, it means just that: one can exclude other people. If the terms of the mining lease are such as to enable one again to have exclusive physical occupancy and do other sorts of things, one can do all those things and exclude other people, whatever the notional continuing existence of a non-extinguished native title might prove to be.

The only context in which it really becomes relevant to determine whether or not native title has been wholly or partly extinguished by the grant of the interest in question is when that interest comes up for renewal or extension, or something of that kind. The rights then do vary, depending on whether there is in existence an extant native title or only an extinguished native title.

If, when the interests come up for renewal or whatever, there is an existing native title, under those circumstances there are rights of negotiation and all the rest of the things that are associated with native title. It is implicit, I guess, but it gives that extra clarity and makes clear that there will be rights of renewal and confidence in the capacity to go on enjoying the economic interest in future. It is because of the need to introduce some certainty about that that we have proposed later on the amendment to clause 24, which is controversial for various reasons.

But let us leave the debate about renewals and extensions and all the rest of it till later. If those opposite are just asking about why we have not got in the legislation more explicit provision defining exactly what the status in detail of valid interests are, vis-a-vis native title, it is because it is not necessary to do so. The very nature of a valid interest is such as to mean that it has its own full force and effect. One just reads it in terms of the legal character of the interest in question. It only matters as an issue when one gets to renewals.

Perhaps that has explained a little more clearly why the legislation is silent on validity generally. Obviously, it could not be silent on invalidity because there would be real uncertainty if that area of potential invalidity were unaddressed. That is why we go into almost a codification of it so far as invalid leases and interests are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. I disagree with his comments, but I do not want to pursue those here and now. I think the minister would recognise though that the bill is quite interesting. The minister says, `Oh well, it only preserves native title so far as it is extant', and then he says, `The only issue, of course, comes up with renewal'. The problem is that, as the minister knows, there are later provisions of this bill, which we will no doubt debate at length, which deem that, when one comes to consider the renewal of a leasehold interest, one is to operate under a fiction: that the native titleholder's rights are not the rights he or she enjoys but are, in fact, a greater right.

PARA.TAB: Mr Temporary Chairman, I put it to the minister: if the context of this legislation is to provide a framework for preserving the status quo in an orderly fashion, then why in certain circumstances does the bill say we are to deem the native titleholder's rights to be something greater than they are? That is the effect, for example, of clause 213(4). I do not want to get into it now, but that was also one of the possibilities—that the government was going to insert this fiction into its amendment to clause 24.

That certainly does not seem to be consistent with the undertakings given by Mr Crean at ABARE, and by Mr Keating and Mr Lee when they met with industry representatives in April. That is why I am just a little perplexed. It is not just the issue of the prior valid grants of interest in land; it is also the issue, of course, of the fiction which is applied to the status of native title at certain future dates, for example, when one considers the renewal.

Apparently, Senator Evans is coming back and I am sure he will be listening with bated breath to these important comments. But the point is this: it is wrong to say that this bill preserves the status quo. It is wrong to say that this bill, in consequential clause 18, seeks to give effect to the High Court decision when what it does, in fact, is vary it quite dramatically because it creates a fiction about the exact status of native title rights.

When one creates that fiction, it causes all sorts of consequential legal problems because of the inconsistency of the deemed status of native title with the interests of other people. For example, in clause 213(4), the bill says that, when there is a renewal of certain leasehold interests and native title exists, one should consider the native titleholders to be freeholders. If the native titleholders merely have a right to walk across a bit of land, that is really just an easement in the anybody else's language. But here it is native title and then it is deemed, for the purposes of considering certain future acts, to be equivalent to a freeholder's rights in the land.

That is just inconsistent. It is certainly inconsistent with the High Court decision and it is certainly inconsistent with the undertakings that have been given to industry. I would seek an explanation as to exactly why that is the case because, to us, it certainly does not seem to be terribly fair, and it certainly does not seem as though the government is giving effect to all of the undertakings it has given to people along the way. It just took us so long in the committee hearings to unearth these problems, and it has taken us almost as long to make the point. But I am very glad to see that Senator Evans is back, and I am sure he will be able to give us a much more succinct answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could if I knew what the question was. Maybe someone else would like to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the minister is working out what Senator O'Chee was asking, I would say that the government is inclined to dismiss our views as unduly partisan. But in relation to clause 18, I would draw the minister's attention to the analysis of this clause by the Parliamentary Library, a very worthy and learned analysis, in which it says:

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of pastoral leases which were validly granted, there will be no extinguishment of native title. If, therefore, the common law provides that native title may co-exist with a pastoral lease to the extent that it is not inconsistent with the lease, this bill will act to preserve that native title rather than extinguish it. This may lead to the absurd result—
And I emphasise `absurd'; these are the words of the Parliamentary Library—
that it may be in the interests of a pastoralist to argue that his or her lease would otherwise be invalid, in order to ensure the extinguishment of all native title, through the validation process.
I ask the minister why we should not accept the words of the Parliamentary Library that this leads to an absurd result.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the short point is that the reasonable working assumption from just about everyone who has read the High Court judgments and understands the issues is that pastoral leases, validly granted, do produce an extinguishment. If someone wanted to spend the resources in order to test that particular issue, I suppose, sobeit. But the overwhelming likelihood is that extinguishment has been accomplished and, accordingly, there is no risk, even at the time of renewal of the lease in question, of some competing interest coming into play.

PARA.TAB: I have already made the point that there is no particular reason why anyone prior to a renewal or extension situation would want to establish once and for all whether actual extinguishment had occurred because there is no downside risk involved to the pastoralist in non-extinguishment. The pastoralist has rights to fully and effectively enjoy all the rights, all the interests, that are associated with that valid lease. I repeat, if there is an exclusive occupancy associated with that, that means the capacity to exclude people completely from the land in question. So there is no interest that is likely to be served, except by some ideologically minded pastoralist, I suppose, who wanted to test the thing for the sheer hell of it or to make a point or to make himself feel better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think they would do it to make themselves feel better.

—I think that is probably right. They are a much more distinguished group. They would not have that sort of motivation. For that sort of reason, it is highly unlikely that people would want to litigate just to make a point when they can fully enjoy their economic interest.

PARA.TAB: It may become a relevant issue at the time of renewal or extension. Our belief, as we have said, is that it is overwhelmingly likely that the High Court, when and if this matter is ever tested, would go down the track of saying that the valid grant has in fact extinguished, therefore, it is not going to become an issue either at the time of renewal or extension. That issue is again addressed in section 24.

It is for those reasons that we do not think it is necessary to spell it out. If there is some residual possibility that the right has not been extinguished, we will let that matter be tested in the courts. That is the Aboriginal perspective on this issue. They want the capacity to test the issue in that way and they should have the right to do it. But, as a practical matter, we just do not think it is the sort of thing that is going to impede the effective enjoyment of the interest in question by the land-holders in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Aboriginals?

—I have just acknowledged the point so far as the Aboriginal people are concerned. Nothing in the bill takes away from the right of Aboriginal people to contest the effect of a previous valid grant; that is left open and there is nothing we are doing that stops that.

—As I understand it, there are claims from Aboriginals that question the minister's interpretation of the High Court judgment—that suggest that the High Court judgment did not provide that native title is extinguished. There is a claim in the west and in South Australia, as I understand it. Therefore, presumably, the Aboriginals with highly paid legal advice are getting professional independent legal advice that the High Court case did not extinguish native title for pre-1975 leases.

—But what you have to consider is what follows from that so far as the interests of the land-holders are concerned. There is no downside negative impact on the land-holder of the continued existence of that native title.

—There is an obvious downside in terms of the commercial value of the lease. A leaseholder must find that his lease value will be downgraded by the potential for a claim for co-existing native title against his lease. Whatever the consequences of that may be, there must be a consequence for the value of his lease.

—I honestly think, quite frankly, that Senator Minchin is overstating that because the whole point of co-existence is that it is only possible to the extent that it does not interfere with the full enjoyment of the lease, of the mining interest or whatever, with all the commercial return potential that is associated with that.

PARA.TAB: In effect, the tragedy of the whole native title debate in this country is that so much exclusive enjoyment has been lost over the last two centuries by Aboriginal people. We want to stop that occurring in the future, but we are not trying to rewrite the past. Where that has been lost in the past, it has been lost. It exists at best in the interstices; it exists at best in a way that does not and cannot impinge upon the effective and economic enjoyment of the interest in question. If one has full and effective economic enjoyment of the interest in question, where is the possibility of the commercial downgrading of the value?

It is more an emotional issue than a realistic one, and that is part of the tragedy of this debate. Some of those opposite have been able to understand that but so many others have taken off with anxieties that are based on just simply not thinking the thing through.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not able to hear the beginning of the minister's remarks but my attention was drawn to the phrase he used about validation equalling extinguishment, meaning that Aboriginal people who may have been living on pastoral leases may be actually excluded from those properties as an interpretation of that, and I would like his clarification.

PARA.TAB: This is one of the areas that has concerned the Greens very much because there are many people in the north-west of Western Australia who have been living in a co-existent state with pastoral leases. Those communities have been there sometimes longer than the pastoral leases in question. If this bill is actually seeking to extinguish their rights to co-existence, I want some clarification. Even the Premier of Western Australia has recognised that the Mabo decision did allow for the possibility of validation of leases with co-existence, and certainly left statutory and equity rights intact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make absolutely clear that statutory, equity and common law rights are left intact in our model in the way in which this will work. The validation will operate maybe to extinguish the core native title but not to the extent that it is capable of existing consistently with the lease, and if there is a statutory reservation which has enabled people to sit on the land. Even if there has not been a statutory reservation but there has been a longstanding practical occupancy by a particular group by tacit acceptance and so on, our clear perception is that that confers a common law right and that that would continue.
—Where does it say that in the bill?

—Clause 15 is the relevant part of the bill that makes clear the preservation of any of those kinds of rights in the validation exercise. Any of those rights that do actually pre-exist would carry through in that way, but not to the extent that they can actually affect adversely the full enjoyment of the validated interest. Their continuation is still provided for. That is an important reassurance that needs to be given to Aboriginal people.

—I would like to pursue this matter further. I was grateful to Senator Chamarette for raising it. The situation with the Court legislation is that it is absolutely clear that the reservations have existed under statute law in the Land Act since 1934 and as a condition of the lease, I believe, almost continuously since Lord Forrest was the Premier of Western Australia or even before that. There seems to me, from the answer that has just been given, to be an enormous inconsistency with what the minister is saying. According to clause 14(a), if a title is not valid, for whatever reason, and it is validated, that, in effect, extinguishes native title.

PARA.TAB: In Western Australia there is a lease that has been recognised in Western Australia for 100 years or more, and it will be recognised again in the Court legislation. There will be situations where some pastoralists' titles, for whatever reason, were not valid; those titles will be validated and will extinguish native title. In effect, we will have two different classes of pastoral leases because of that. We will end up with a situation whereby they lose their co-existence rights from those titles that have been validated.

I think the point that Senator Chamarette raised is a very valid one. It is a factual point. I would like the minister to show me where that is not the case. In relation to those situations where it has been accepted in Western Australia for 100 years or so, I pose the question: why would the government want to go down the track of creating two different situations for Aboriginal people and two different situations for pastoralists? I have never been approached by a pastoralist who has complained about that particular reservation which existed. For me, it has been an accepted fact of life.

I have been approached by elders in Western Australia who say they want the current situation which exists in the Court legislation because it actually protects their reservation in terms of their situation on all pastoral leases, whereas the government's legislation does not. I want the minister to explain to me why that is so and how it works. Have I misunderstood something? I do not believe I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to try to explain it. This is a central feature of the bill and it is fair enough for these questions to be raised in this way.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look, I am trying to approach this in a sensible and helpful way. For God's sake, can we cut out some of the bloody nonsense across the chamber please.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! I am sure that is Senator Evans's way of being friendly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, he doesn't take it as our way of being friendly when he gets a bit of condescension back.

—I am glad Senator Vanstone acknowledges that as condescension. I will try to explain again what this is all about. Valid leases, about which there is no question of invalidity, apply to their full force and effect. But, equally, they apply subject to any existing common law or statutory reservation. There is no doubt about that; it is just the present law as it stands.
—I acknowledge that.
—There is no need to spell it out in legislation. It is there; there is no contest about that.
—I am not asking you to spell it out.

—But Senator Crane is asking me to explain why the stuff is spelt out in the legislation so far as invalid and, subsequently, validated grants are concerned but not spelt out so as far as valid grants are concerned. I am trying, with the utmost respect, to tell him. There is no need to spell it out so far as always valid grants are concerned because there is no argument, no contest and no disagreement by anyone as to what the law is and what the practice is.

PARA.TAB: So far as past acts that have been invalid are concerned and have to be validated, obviously we are in a kind of no-man's-land situation. If we are going to create genuine certainty we have to codify and spell out what precisely the status of all the different elements of the equation are. We have to spell out what the status of the grant itself is, we have to spell out what the status of any statutory or common law reservations might be, and we have to spell out what the status of native title is because there is uncertainty about this. We have done it. In clause 15 we have spelt it out in the case of validated interests. I ask the opposition to glance at clause 15, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: If:
(a)the act attributable to the Commonwealth contains a reservation or condition for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders;—
That is say, if a Commonwealth pastoral lease, for example, contained an express reservation allowing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there such a thing as a Commonwealth pastoral lease?

—I am referring to a Commonwealth grant of an interest over some land for defence purposes or whatever. But if it has been vested in the Commonwealth for defence purposes and it is alienating it for some other purpose, there are possibilities. They do not arise very often. They are mainly in state law, but we are just covering that off to create, again, certainty in the event that there are such situations. More importantly for present purposes, subclause (b) states:

SPEECH.PARA: the doing of the act would affect rights or interests (other than native title rights and interests) of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders (whether arising under legislation, at common law or in equity and whether or not rights of usage);
nothing in section 14 affects that reservation or condition or those rights or interests.

So what we have got is a statement with very great clarity and very great explicitness that existing statutory reservations, existing common law reservations—equitable reservations, if you like—will continue to have their full force and effect. What it does make clear is that native title rights under those circumstances will not have that force and effect.

PARA.TAB: As I said, we had to address the situation of all three—the status of the grant, the status of any reservations or conditions or limitations on that grant, and the status of native title rights. That is all spelt out very succinctly and very clearly in clause 15 of the bill. So I do not think there is any problem about what all this would be construed as meaning, and the reason for the differential between the validated and the valid is as I have described it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish the minister would not use terms such as `would be construed'. We are trying to get to the bottom of a very complex piece of legislation and the minister clearly does not have an understanding of much of it. He has had a much greater opportunity to look at it than we have. I want to get this clear: the minister is saying that if the government extinguishes native title, the only reservation that Aboriginal people have in this case is statute law.
—Or common law.
—We will deal with one at a time.
—Common law based on occupancy, but not based on native title.

—That means another revisit to the courts of the land and a whole range of things. I want to deal with the statute law aspect of it first. As I understand the position, that means, in effect, that the ability of the Commonwealth to deliver on native title co-existing following extinguishment relies wholly and solely on a state government's statute law. When the minister refers to it in the sense of the common law, we create another situation which will be subject to the courts of the land and all sorts of things. I have no doubt about that. I come back to my fundamental point: I believe that the application, as contained in this bill, is severely flawed. That is the message that I have been getting from many people in Western Australia. I want to put that on the public record.

PARA.TAB: I will leave that for now. I have other things that I want to follow up in other clauses. I want to re-emphasise that what the government has done is create a situation where we will have two lines of pastoral people—I am talking about people who run sheep and cattle in the wilderness; I am not referring to defence institutions or leases. Aboriginal people will be treated differently in the two different situations. I find that a very strange way to approach this situation. It is certainly not how we in Western Australia have treated the situation for a long time.

I will raise the other point now because I think it fits in with this. I refer to the granting of new pastoral leases. I understand that they extinguish native title. Can the minister outline to us the co-existence rights in the terms of new pastoral leases?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is better dealt with under clause 24.
—Okay; I will deal with it under clause 24.

—I would like to raise the same point that Senator Crane raised. We require clarification of the intention of this bill. One of the stated aims of this legislation is to preserve native title to the maximum extent possible. Yet many provisions in this bill do the opposite and in fact restrict native title more than the High Court ruling does. I believe that this is one of those principles. There is no argument from Aboriginal people or, I believe, anybody here that legitimate acts of parliament should be validated and that people who have any query over their valid lease should have validation.

PARA.TAB: The exception the Greens take to this bill is that it extends that legitimate premise that leases should be validated to the extent that there is any question. The next step of extinguishment of native title adds an additional factor and it also removes us from the High Court decision which left the question of coexistence of native title and valid leases together. That is the appropriate way to deal with it.

I believe that if people who have native title rights are able by this law to have those rights extinguished, possibly before they even realise they have them, then there is something fatally flawed in the bill. If the position the minister has been placing before us is, `It is all right because they have statutory or equity rights in their present usage—they will be protected; they will not be allowed to be thrown off a pastoral lease', then that is no different from what the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, has just done. He has extinguished all native title with the stroke of a piece of legislation and he has protected that by stating the usage and equity rights by statutory law.

Most of us here would agree that that is a highly questionable step to take from the High Court decision. I challenge the minister to explain why this same principle is not operating in the words he has just given in explanation of validation and extinguishment being connected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand very well what Senator Chamarette is saying and I have some sympathy for the position she is articulating.
—I think she is right.

—If those opposite had any sympathy for Aboriginal people, they would be striking a first. We should not hear any interjections of that kind because the motivations of those opposite are very much in doubt on this whole matter. Let me focus on the point that Senator Chamarette is raising and ignore the noises from those on the other side because they are not well motivated, they are not well considered, they are not well intentioned.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order—
—He has a point of order.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—I do not need your help, Senator Short.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like that comment to be withdrawn because I take it as a personal reflection on me. I am offended by comments such as that and they are not necessary.
—I am not absolutely certain that it is a comment that needs to be withdrawn, but I would ask the minister to withdraw, if he would be prepared to do so. It might help.

—If Senator Crane has taken offence to anything I have said, so be it—I withdraw. I will try to address the point Senator Chamarette has raised. It is the case that for validated, possibly invalid, leases the legislation does go one step further than may be the case as a matter of common law and as is the situation with unquestionably valid leases.

PARA.TAB: In the case of unquestionably valid interests, leases and so on, the legislation is silent on the impact on extinguishment. It is left to be tested at some future stage as to whether that extinguishment was accomplished. We happen to believe that, on the basis of the statements in the High Court judgment, it is overwhelmingly likely that extinguishment will be held to have occurred, but it is left to be tested, and there is an opportunity to do that so far as valid leases are concerned.

When we come to possibly invalid and thereby validated interests here—this is where this knife-edge balance of judgment factor is always involved—it was felt that because of the element of uncertainty that was being expressed to us by commercial interests, pastoral interests, mining interests and everybody else about the possible impact of invalid leases having to be validated, they have asked that we address not only the questions of the status of the interest itself—namely, to validate it, the status of the common law and the statutory reservations and to tell them clearly whether or not those continue with existing rights of practical occupancy and so on, which we have done, but they have also asked us to state with absolute clarity in the terms of the legislation that extinguishment is in fact accomplished. The government, for better or worse, has acceded to that request so that, in the context of creating absolute certainty in areas of possible invalidity, all three of those issues are addressed.

I repeat that the extinguishment issue is believed by us to be likely to be what the High Court will in fact find, if and when this matter is ever tested. It is not as if it was going out beyond what we thought would happen anyway, but it has happened. To that extent, I can understand the Greens' point and I can understand why they are going to continue to push away at this particular issue for the remainder of this debate. And we will no doubt hear some more from them on that. I understand that, but it is a matter of balanced judgment.

I just introduce one other element into the equation—and this is an important one. The truth of the matter is that it is essentially a theoretical argument because, as a practical matter, the number of leases and interests around the place that we believe may be actually invalid and have to be invalidated is really very tiny indeed—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is irrelevant.

—It is not irrelevant, because it is a question as to whether this is a purely theoretical concern or whether it is a real practical one that has a potentially very large impact on a very large number of people. The point of the matter is that the number of interests that are likely, we believe, to be possibly invalid as a result of the Racial Discrimination Act or indeed any other law, breach of fiduciary interest or whatever else, is absolutely tiny.

PARA.TAB: We have discussed this before and I do not want to go over it again, but in the context of pastoral leases post-1975, the best estimate we have had from the National Farmers Federation—we have not been able to make an estimate ourselves—is that maybe there is a total of something like 11 leases in one part of the country and that is it. In the case of breach of fiduciary duty and so on, every lawyer I have ever spoken to, except perhaps those involved in testing this matter at the moment on the part of a particular client, believes that that is a no-go zone and is not going to produce a result. So, as a practical matter, the number of interests by Aboriginal people that will actually be extinguished by this validation proposal is likely to be very tiny indeed.

The overwhelming number of proprietary interests over pastoral areas, mining interests or anything else in this country is likely to be in the valid zone. We are talking about 98 or 99 per cent plus of all the interests in this country which give rise to potential native rights claims as being in the zone of previously unquestionably valid grants. It is only a tiny percentage that is to the contrary. As to that 98 or 99 per cent, the question of extinguishment is left to be resolved in due course by the High Court.

In the meantime, as I have sought to say at painful length earlier on, nobody's economic interests are being prejudiced because the existing pastoral and mining interests and so on in those valid areas continue to have their full force and effect. The only question mark arises as to what will be the consequence in the future at the time of renewal and so on. That is an issue to be debated in another context.

I hope Senator Chamarette will at least understand where we are coming from in this respect, why we are doing it, and in evaluating the significance of our continued position on this, so far as invalid and validated leases are concerned, will appreciate that it really is just trying to tie off an element of uncertainty in one small corner of the canvass and that the vast remainder of the canvass is assumed to be valid leases. I think everybody, as a practical matter, assumes that is so. In that area, that extinguishment is not accomplished by this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for being very clear about the stance of the bill. I am not debating whether I agree with it or not. I think it is important to understand what this legislation is doing and what its impact will be on the ground. I note that the minister has admitted that there is in this legislation a pre-empting of a possible future High Court decision regarding whether certain leases will be regarded as having extinguished native title. So I note that.

PARA.TAB: The minister has repeated that a very tiny number of pastoral leases will have their native title extinguished by this legislation. I ask the minister: how many commercial and tourist leases, as well as pastoral leases, may well be in the category of validation that extinguishes native title? How does the minister know how many there are? What procedures has the minister undertaken to find out where they are located? What degree of preparation has been made to consult with the people who may be in a position of having their native title extinguished so that there is the principle of at least informed consent to a procedure that is about to happen?

TALK.START.PARA: —No estimate has been made of the number in the commercial tourism area because it is almost impossible—
—You said a `tiny' amount. How do you know?
—We are really only talking about post-1975 grants. In the case of pastoral leases, there have been only a relatively small number—
—We have been through that. She asked you about `tiny'.

—Please, Senator Macdonald! Post-1975, because so much of the pastoral area of the country has been granted over previous decades, not many brand new—as distinct from renewed—pastoral leases have been granted. It only happens from time to time. There are very few new leases which could even begin to give rise to questions about possible invalidity. In the case of commercial leases, or tourism leases, or other kinds of property interest, however, obviously innumerable such interests have been granted since 1975; therefore, conceivably, they could involve some problem with the Racial Discrimination Act.

PARA.TAB: The only way we could even begin to make such a serious assessment is to know in the first place in which parts of the country native title actually exists. We will not know that until we have been through a determination process. It is not a matter of consulting people; it is a matter of having to wait for a determination process to occur. To make some reasonable judgment about what might be likely to occur involves a major research effort. The only ones that might be invalidated are those which have been granted since 1975 over some area of land which has a native title claim which is likely to be valid. It is just a matter of making a guesstimate of the number of such things that might be involved.

This is a matter of the judgments that have to be made. This is all about a balance of interests. As much as we want to redress the injustice and fix things up for Aboriginal people, as much as we are absolutely determined to do so as far as the future is concerned, and as much as this legislation will produce that result as far as the future is concerned, as a responsible government we do have to weigh and balance all the interests, other than just Aboriginal interests, that are involved in this country, such as those in industry and tourism, as well as pastoralists, miners and ordinary residential property holders. When in utterly good faith people have taken those interests and set in train things such as commercial ventures, it is just a matter of making a judgment that the balance ought to be resolved in this way.

I understand where the Greens are coming from. They would tip the balance the other way and try to redress some of those past things that have gone wrong, as well as doing it for the future. I understand that, but as a practical matter we have to draw the line somewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —So, after questioning by Senator Chamarette, the minister has finally admitted that there can be a situation in which one pastoral lease involves co-existence and another does not. Earlier, in answer to a question from Senator Minchin, the minister said that with all of these acts there will be no financial impact, or value impact, on pastoral leases. If there is one pastoral lease with co-existence and one without co-existence, there must be a free market difference. It might be a matter of judgment as to how much, but there must be one. I can give various examples. The minister may have read in the paper—Western Australian senators certainly would have—about the case of the station at Christmas Creek which is owned by Aboriginals.
—No. It probably should be, though. They were thrown off.
—Okay, I withdraw that. The Christmas Creek station is owned by the Klopper family.
—It isn't owned by them; it is leased.
—It has an Aboriginal community on it, the `Wonkajonka'—is that right; do I get the Greens' approval on that? Obviously they have not been there, so they would not know whether it was right or not.

PARA.TAB: The Christmas Creek owner fenced off the road going from the community to the rest of the property. There was a big kafuffle about that because the Aboriginals reckoned that they had the traditional right to go over it. The owners fenced it off because they had drafted off about 2,000 head of cattle and put them in a paddock ready to go to market, and Aboriginal people coming out of that community opened the gates to go somewhere—hunting or something like that—and left the gates open. The cattle all remixed. That was three weeks work down the drain. It is the unwritten law in pastoral areas and farming areas that, when you go into a place, if the gate is shut, you leave it shut, and, if the gate is open—because stock could be going through it to water—you leave it open.

TALK.START.PARA: —So that gave them the right to exclude Aboriginals from their property?

—Senator Margetts did not know the name of the community. She has not been there. Why is she interrupting me now? The station next door was owned by Aborigines. A group—I think it might have been visiting politicians—tried to get into the place to see them, but could not. Why? Because the gates were padlocked. So it was all right for them to padlock their gates but it was not all right for the Christmas Creek station to padlock its gates!

PARA.TAB: The minister said that there have not been many pastoral leases issued since 1975, but I know of a few that were re-issued. In other words, they had expired and been handed back to the lands department. Sometimes the lands department will rest a station for a while and then re-issue it. So there could be more than the minister may think—some that are validated after having been invalidated and some that have existed all the time. For those reasons, there can be a difference in the value of the property on the market. If the owner does not have the right of transition over the property, it can lead to problems such as cattle mixing. If owners do have that right, they are more secure in the handling of their stock. I think the minister could remark on that and change his view on what Senator Minchin had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the minister involves a state minister acting as a designated authority under Commonwealth legislation and making a grant or acting with regard to, for instance, legislation for offshore petroleum exploration or fishing. Would that act be attributable to the Commonwealth?

PARA.TAB: I am referring to subdivision A headed, `Acts attributable to the Commonwealth'. As I understand it, there are situations where we have state ministers doing things which are pursuant to Commonwealth legislation. They are acting as a designated authority. The petroleum exploration is one such case, fishing might be another and, no doubt, there are many more. Where does that category of act fit in? Is it under this subdivision or subdivision B, `Acts attributable to a State or Territory'?

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is either one or the other, depending on the particular context and the particular situation. Clause 18 makes provision for that to be so. Let me take some further advice.

—Although I have to confess that I am not coming from the same direction as the Greens, I thought they raised a very valid question. I would agree with the Greens on the very unsatisfactory nature of the minister's answer on the commercial and tourist leases which would be affected. This is yet another one of the great uncertainties which is emerging.

PARA.TAB: The issue has been raised of what this bill means in terms of the overall proportion of land which will be affected by native title. I put it to the minister that, because of the unintended consequences of the bill, we will get back to where the government will raise its previous famous saying: `It seemed like a good idea at the time', as it did when it sent its F111 fighters in to the Franklin Dam in Tasmania. The minister has launched another attack on the states.

Whether people agree with this bill or not, a valid question which the Australian public want answered is: what proportion of the land area of Australia could, on the government's estimates, be likely to be subject—with reasonable grounds for success—to a native title claim? I think that goes to the nub of the question which the Greens are asking, and it is certainly what we are asking. Whatever direction one is coming from on this debate, we really want to know the consequences of the legislation which we are being asked to pass.

When I pressed the minister on this issue at estimates committee hearings, he said that the government had no idea. I then asked him whether the government would do any work on this issue and he said that the government would not do any work on it. I put it to the minister that it is extraordinary that one of the most important pieces of legislation is going through this parliament—which everybody agrees will have major social consequences, major consequences for the economy of this nation—and it seems that the government has not attempted at all to assess its overall impact.
