In the context of this debate, could the minister take a step back a bit and try to be more specific in relation to what I thought were very useful questions raised by the Greens? Could he then perhaps come to the question that I raised, which is: since the minister's statements at Senate estimates hearings, has the government done any work in this area? That is a reasonable question. If it has not, why will the government not do this work to assess just what proportion of the land mass of this country may be subject to native title claim with a reasonable chance of success? It is a question which goes to the crux of this bill and we and the Australian people are entitled to an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the ultimate irony. Take the example of a tourism lease based on ecotourism, where Aboriginal people are living on their traditional lands; other people are engaged in successful business in allowing people to meet with, talk with and have explained to them the traditional lifestyle of Aboriginal people, as well as being able to enjoy the natural setting. Is it not incredibly ironic that that very process of the tourism lease will in fact extinguish the rights of those people on whom that business is based?
—I missed the last bit.

—There is an increasing number of these types of business in Australia. Would it not be the ultimate irony if the holding of a lease by a company, in conjunction with people finding out about the natural environment and the people on that land who are living in a traditional way, will actually extinguish the native title rights of the very Aboriginal people upon whom that business might be based?
—Yes, it would be an irony under those circumstances, but that is one of the consequences that occur from time to time when one is trying to strike a balance between commercial tourist—
—The native title argument.

—I can be spared, I would hope, the crocodile tears of the opposition in this respect. There is a little cheer squad every time the Greens make a fair point about something, in the context of a group of people which is going oppose the legislation root and branch, in the context of a group of people who have shown by their attitude to Aboriginal issues generally and to native title issues generally that they regard with nothing short of contempt the claims that have been made and which are now recognised by the common law. It is an example of the kind of breathtaking hypocrisy we can do without in this debate. I am sure the Greens are not taken in by these expressions of concern and anxiety and applause for particular expressions that they make from time to time that do have some force.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I think this debate is going to be a fairly robust debate. It is a pity that it seems to be starting so early in the day.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—Get to your point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —My point of order is that we are being subject to great abuse from the minister at the table. We asked a valid question, which I thought was a sensible question from the Greens; then we are subjected to these provocative comments from the minister. I ask you to bring him to order on the point of relevance and get him to address the question, rather than indulge in his usual tactic of abuse.
—If you are worried about that, you are being very sensitive.

—Senator Kemp is a very delicate flower, as we are all well aware. Senator Margetts is right. I cannot pretend a denial. It is a good point, a good debating point, but at least the economic interests and the cultural interests are being advanced, albeit it in a different way in that particular context. It is a matter of striking the overall balance between competing interests elsewhere, and I cannot add further to that. I think Senator Margetts knows that. It is a good point, but let us move on.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether Senator Kemp is interested in an answer or whether he is just making the usual familiar debating points. I have said, as best I can, in answer to him in question time previously when this matter has been pursued that it is simply impossible at the moment to make any seriously considered value judgment as to the quantum of likely to be successful claims.

We are talking about 260,000 Aboriginal people scattered right around the country and with varying degrees of affinity and continued association with different parts of the country. We are talking about a definition of native title which, itself, is very variable, extending from one end of the spectrum to exclusive occupancy type rights to, at the other end of the spectrum, hunting-type access rights of a much lower order of exclusivity or non-exclusivity at all. We are talking about a very variable concept and one that has yet to evolve through a process of common law and tribunal determination.

Quite apart from not knowing who is going to claim rights, quite apart from not being able to identify with any precision what the precise content of that right is likely to be, we then have to make judgments about the amount of land that is prima facie accessible. We have to go through so many quantitative hoops in order to produce a judgment which, at the end of the day, will do no more than contribute debating points to the debate. It will not help policy formulation. We need to acknowledge that there is still a significant area of inalienated land in the country where—

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly in Western Australia.

—Particularly in Western Australia—Senator Crane is right—and in other parts of the country other kinds of rights which are capable of enjoyment, notwithstanding large degrees of utilisation in the past. It is a matter of waiting until the claims start to be registered under the process that we are establishing before we can make any better judgment about that.

PARA.TAB: In response to Senator Ellison's question about clauses 13 and 18 and attributable acts, I am advised that, if the act in question is attributable to the Commonwealth, clause 13 will constitute the validation authority. Clause 224 states what such attributable acts are. If they are not attributable to the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth does not act accordingly, the states will need to validate under the authority conferred by clause 18, which is what we are still debating.

This means that, in any area of some doubt as to whose responsibility it is, the greatest certainty will arise if both the Commonwealth and the states validate so that all possibilities are covered. I am advised that that has always been the Commonwealth's position. Sensible states will now proceed to validate in accordance with the bill they have passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by `sensible states'?

—Those that are prepared to recognise that there is some virtue in the concept of native title in terms of social justice considerations and those who are prepared to work cooperatively with the Commonwealth to produce an effective blanket regime which will create genuine certainty for everyone at the same time as the maximum degree of justice. That is what I mean. I do not think it is a bad definition on the run.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—Before I call on the next speaker, I remind the chamber that the question before the committee is that government amendments Nos 5 and 7 be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to allow what Senator Gareth Evans said about the opposition's crocodile tears and its response to the Native Title Bill to go through to the keeper without some comment. Senator Kemp took a point of order. Mr Temporary Chairman, you did not uphold it, but he did seek to make a point. I am the secretary of the coalition's backbench committee on Aboriginal affairs. Senator O'Chee is its chairman and Senator Kemp and Senator Panizza are members of it. There are consistent allegations by the government that, because we are opposed to this Native Title Bill, for a whole range of reasons, we have not had a deep and genuine commitment to Aboriginal issues over many years.

PARA.TAB: I have been involved in doing policy work on Aboriginal affairs since probably 1980 or 1981. The Liberal Party and the National Party—the coalition—have a deep and genuine commitment. We just seem to have a slightly different view on some issues. We do not think the native title legislation will help Aboriginal people fulfil their potential. That is why we bring a slightly different view to this debate. We will have a robust, interesting and long debate.

To reflect on the coalition's genuine bona fides when it comes to a commitment to Aboriginal affairs, Aboriginal welfare and Aboriginal advancement is quite crass of the minister. It is a gross reflection on people such as Dr John Hewson, who has a deep and personal commitment to it; Michael Wooldridge, who also has a deep and personal commitment to these issues; and Peter Nugent and a whole range of people in the coalition who have a deep, abiding and personal interest in Aboriginal affairs.

The record of previous Labor and Liberal governments in Aboriginal affairs is quite abysmal in what they have been able to achieve for Aboriginal people. It is important for this parliament and all parliamentarians to assess what has happened over the last 15 or 20 years with Aboriginal affairs. We should assess the policies in relation to the Northern Territory lands right legislation and see what it has achieved for Aboriginals. We should also assess the policies of setting up ATSIC and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. We need to be a bit objective about what we as parliamentarians have achieved for our Aboriginal brothers and sisters in the past 20 years.

Most of us can hang our heads in shame because very little has been achieved. That is not to say that nothing has been achieved; I am sure there have been advances. If Senator Evans wants to have a sensible and rational debate on this bill, he should stop his gratuitous insults to the coalition about our commitment to Aboriginal affairs because it shows his prejudice. I take great offence at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister a question about clause 18 and its interaction with the Racial Discrimination Act. I assume that at the end of the day the five factions of the government will incorporate the Greens' proposed new clause 6A which says, `Nothing in this Act affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act'. I assume that the proposed new clause will be incorporated into the bill. I again draw the attention of the Senate to the very useful Parliamentary Library analysis of this bill. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed s. 18 would, however, effectively grant a complying State Government an exemption from the effect of the Racial Discrimination Act, allowing it to validate State titles to land.

I want to know whether that is the case. Is clause 18 not in effect granting an exemption? On the face of it, it would be contrary to the RDA, particularly if the bill incorporated the proposed new clause to the effect that nothing in the act would affect the operation of the RDA. I am asking a general question about the interaction of clause 18 with the RDA.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first and most important point to make is that the government believes that these validation exercises, whether conducted at the Commonwealth level or the state level, will comply with the Racial Discrimination Act because in particular there is provision for just terms and compensation to be payable as a consequence of any extinguishment that may be involved with that validation process. That is a very important element which distinguishes the validations occurring now under this authority from what might be achieved without provision for compensation.

PARA.TAB: That having been said, as a belt and braces kind of an exercise, proposed new clause 6A(2) makes clear that validation exercises of this kind can stand on their own merits, notwithstanding the value that we continue to give to the RDA. Proposed new clause 6A(2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subsection (1) does not affect the validation of past acts by or in accordance with this Act.

So a validation accomplished by a state would not be accomplished by this act but it would be accomplished in accordance with this act. The states are given the authority to engage in those sorts of validation exercises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Presumably, someone who did not want to see a state validation proceed could bring an action to the effect that in some way the validation provided for under this act was contrary to the RDA. Is that not possible?
—It will bring all sorts of litigation. The question is whether or not one succeeds.

—I would like to make a comment in reference to Senator Minchin's query. It disturbs me that assumptions are being made as to whether the particular amendment that the Greens put up yesterday regarding the Racial Discrimination Act is being used to debate matters. I did consent to defer the issue yesterday because no amendments relating to the body corporate were in circulation at the time. But I feel that we should bring the matter back and resolve it so that when the relationship between this clause, my amendment and any other subsequent matters is discussed, it can be discussed not in a hypothetical way. That is one suggestion I would like to make.

PARA.TAB: I comment on Senator Minchin's question which, as is put in my clause—and it has not been accepted—also covers the area of validation provisions not being affected by the relationship with the RDA. So, if we had actually resolved whether that amendment was being placed within the bill, it would also have answered the concern that I believe Senator Minchin was rightly addressing. I foreshadow a suggestion that we could return to the deferred Green amendment A1 in relation to clause 6 as soon as possible after these particular amendments that are in hand have been dealt with.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—That is really in the hands of the committee, Senator Chamarette. It determines whether it wishes to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will raise it at a later stage.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Question put:
That the clause, as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clause 14.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise some questions additional to those we were addressing in the body of the previous debate—the clauses tend to get a bit mixed up—concerning some matters arising from clause 14A as it affected a pastoral lease title and the different rights which would exist under this act when comparing a valid act against a invalidated act.

PARA.TAB: I will just recap what the minister said to us, because we were discussing this quite some time ago, about the extinguishment of native title in respect of validation. The minister was saying that on the balance of probabilities there may or may not be a coexistence of title.

I find it very difficult to accept, where in actual fact one extinguishes the native title, how there could still be on the balance of probabilities a continuation of some other claim. Perhaps the minister could clear up that particular point. I would have thought that the extinguishment of native title would have been just that: the extinguishment of native title. If I could go a bit further as to whether or not it does extinguish native title, the minister in his answer said that there would be a small number, but he was not sure exactly how many.

In addressing the question of equity, what the minister was saying is that it was fine because there was a small number and therefore the government could just with the stroke of a pen—to quote somebody else in this debate today—wipe that away, yet leave it in as far as valid titles were concerned. I was particularly referring to the Western Australian title where, as we know, there is a reservation in law. It does not matter whether it is a valid title, whether it is a validated title or whether there will be a future title; that statute law will stand in place.

So far as the Commonwealth legislation is concerned, the minister was saying that it is okay to rip it off if there are only a few people. In other words, if there are just a few people, and not 200, 300, 1,000 or even one million people, it is all right to take them around behind the garden shed and give them a damn good hiding. But if the government gets to a certain number then it is not all right. That is, in effect, what the minister was saying.

I find it incomprehensible that the government can actually be putting up legislation that will give a few people a good hiding behind the garden shed when other people are okay. As I mentioned before, this creates a double standard situation with the pastoralists. There could be an instance where pastoralists who are neighbours may be faced with totally different situations. That is what has occurred under the Western Australian legislation—I will not go into it again—which has been in place for 100 years. Is it really fair to give those few people, to draw on an analogy, a good hiding behind the garden shed?

I ask the minister whether he would confirm that validity of pastoral leases actually extinguishes native title. In effect, whatever rights that may survive in this mystical thing—which will be challenged before the court—because native title has been extinguished is not native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us distinguish between the two situations again. When I was talking about valid leases—not validated ones—I was saying that, while we believe the High Court made it pretty clear that that would result in the extinguishment, there is still some room for argument about that. That is something that ultimately will have to be, and no doubt will be, tested by litigation.

PARA.TAB: When it comes to validation exercises of that very small number, I think we all concede, of possibly invalid leases—and it may be entirely hypothetical but nonetheless it is a problem that needed to be covered—the bill makes clear that the validation of the lease will result in extinguishment. I suppose there is a question mark remaining where there is a reservation, in particular, a statutory reservation. There is a suggestion in some quarters that an existing statutory reservation that is maintained under clause 15 as a result of the validation process gives a window for the retention of a native title claim to the extent at least—not going beyond it—of the statutory reservation.

There is an argument about that and that is what I was referring to in passing, maybe not as clearly as I should have. To the extent that the statutory reservation carves out a notional area of exemption from the operation of the lease so far as it affects Aboriginal people, it might leave room for the retention of some kind of claim that there is a little bit of native title left as a result.

It is difficult to predict how the courts will jump on that one. By definition, we are talking about something that will not make the situation any worse for the pastoralists than it is at the moment, because we are talking simply about enjoyment of rights pursuant to an existing statutory reservation. The question is whether it is possible in future for those rights to be regarded not just simply as statutory rights, but as having some of the colour of the native title rights still about them.

I think we are in the realm of pretty abstruse speculation here. I repeat that, in practice, these validation cases are likely to amount to only a very tiny proportion of the total landscape at best. So it ought not to be a matter of practical concern to the people Senator Crane is talking for on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister can assume whom I am talking for if he likes, but I am looking at the fact that, in this particular clause, there is not equity among pastoralists or equity among Aborigines. I am not sure who Senator Gareth Evans thinks I am talking for. I am trying to get to the bottom of this, and I think he missed the point. I repeat: just because there are only a couple of them it does not mean the government can take them behind the shed and give them a hiding; and that if there are a lot, it cannot. We need to go further and examine this on a state by state basis. I would like the minister to tell us what the situation is with reservations as far as pastoral land is concerned on a state by state basis, and what the comparison is between those reservations that have been held.

PARA.TAB: Could the minister provide us with information on what reservations have been held in the various states; what he sees as being the position as far as it relates to validation; and in which states will validation come into play? For example, are there any reservations in Queensland and will it come into play there; what is the situation with reservations in New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia, the Northern Territory, Western Australia, Queensland and Tasmania? The minister knows the states as well as I do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give an instant response as to what the statutory provisions are state by state. I certainly know, for example, there are statutory reservation provisions under the Crown Lands Act of Western Australia, which makes provision for reservation for purposes of Aboriginal—
—Under the lands act?

—Under the Crown Lands Act; I think that is right. I think there are probably similar provisions in most other states—certainly in the Northern Territory and South Australia; not in Queensland, I am advised; and I am not sure what the situation is so far as New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania are concerned. We can find out and let Senator Crane know, but I do not think it affects the future of this clause. It will take a little time to find out. The truth of the matter is that in at least three jurisdictions in Australia there are provisions of this kind which make allowances for Aboriginal people's interests to be preserved in this way. Also, I should have added before, the common law, as well, is thought by some people to give possible coverage for some operation for a sort of residual native title right; it is not just the statutory reservations.

PARA.TAB: I suppose it will be a matter in due course for argument because nobody is in a position to be confident one way or the other about the outcome of that. I am advised that our judgment has been that there probably will not be any residual native title right, as such, retained under the umbrella of those statutory or common law reservations; that it is simply in the nature of a statutory or common law right, different in kind from native title. But that is something that could be tested and, no doubt, will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. I would have thought that information was really central to proceeding with this clause. In establishing what the position is on a state by state basis, I think we can fairly say that, as far as I am aware, there will be no possibility in Queensland, Victoria, New South Wales or Tasmania of any residual native title remaining because of reservations held by the various state governments in those particular states. But when we look at South Australia, the Northern Territory and Western Australia, we have very different situations. I would have thought, in proceeding with this clause, we should have them laid out purely and clearly on the table.

—If Senator Crane wants that information, I am happy to supply it and defer consideration of the clause until then. It is simply extractable information and we can provide it, presumably, later this day. I think Senator Chamarette would welcome a pause to consider some aspects of the legislation as well, so perhaps we can defer it. I wonder whether Senator Chamarette has any idea of how long she would like to defer it.

—I thank the Minister. I also share difficulties on this clause. The Greens have grave concern about it because this is the clause that, as was foreshadowed in earlier discussion, equates validation of a possible invalid lease with extinguishment of native title. It pre-empts a High Court decision that, in some cases, it may well be found that native title is able to co-exist rather than being extinguished and, therefore, it is removing a potential right available to Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: This would not be a problem in this clause if it were not for the fact that pastoral leases are all held in category A. I think the relationship of the categories to the effects that this clause imposes means that it would be preferable to defer it. I would seek deferral to a point in time when we have dealt with the Green amendments 48 and 53 which relate to clause 214.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to place Senator Gareth Evans on notice of a question so that when we do get back to this matter he will have had time to look into it. My question relates to mention of public works in clause 14A and I ask whether it is necessary to distinguish public works in category A—past acts—and whether public works will be included with agricultural leases, pastoral leases, et cetera.

—I appreciate being give notice of that question because it is not something I can answer off the top of my head. I note for the record that, under our running sheet, it was proposed to deal with Greens amendments 48 and 53 in consideration of clause 212 rather than clause 214. Perhaps we can bear in mind debating them cognately in consideration of clause 212 and all the other amendments proposed for debate at that same time.

PARA.TAB: In turn, when considering their position on clause 14, I would ask the Greens to bear in mind that, while they do not like that part of clause 14 which would produce extinguishment in the context of pastoral leases, there is a part of clause 14 that they should like very much—the part relating to category C, past acts and the validation of possibly invalid mining titles. That is a guarantee of non-extinguishment, which is something that the common law, left to its own devices, may not provide.

They should remember there is a real probability that, as a matter of common law, valid grants of mining leases would produce an extinguishment. Here, in a validation context, we are expressly not extinguishing native title in deference to mining grants. It might be a matter of making a judgment as to which principle they give primacy.

Bearing that in mind, I simply add that in all cases, not just clause 14, this is almost certainly a theoretical rather than a practical issue because of the real difficulty of finding anywhere in the Australian landscape particular provisions which may give rise to a situation.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That further consideration of clause 14 be postponed.
Clause 15.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 15, page 10, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Preservation of beneficial reservations and conditions

PARA.TAB: "(a)the act attributable to the Commonwealth contains a reservation or condition for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or

"(b)the doing of the act would affect any existing access to and enjoyment of any land or waters by Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders or would affect rights or interests of Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders (whether arising under legislation, at common law or in equity and whether or not rights of usage);

SPEECH.PARA: nothing in section 14 affects that reservation or condition or that access or enjoyment or those rights or interests.".

This clause, as has been said before, ensures that Aboriginal reservations or conditions for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders are preserved. Proposed subsection (a) is of no concern; we agree with that. In proposed subsection (b) our amendment adds the words `any existing'—I emphasise existing—`access to and enjoyment of any land or waters by Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders' should also be preserved when a lease is issued.

PARA.TAB: This is a matter of equity. Very clearly, if there is an existing right of access—in the case of Aboriginal people it could be the use of a waterhole or it could be access to a sacred site—we should ensure that this is not extinguished when a lease is issued over that land.

We know that pastoralists and miners need certainty; Aboriginal people need certainty, too. Although I understand, having discussed it previously, that the government's position is still somewhat uncertain on this, I put it to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) that this provision should be favourably considered by the government and I look forward to its support for it.

This is a provision that the opposition should consider favourably. It does not seek to extend rights; it simply says that, if there is an existing right of usage which is an access to a particular location and enjoyment of any portion of land or waters, that should be preserved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support Richard Court's bill? That's what it does.

—No. That extinguishes all rights first. It is well and truly on the record that it is totally unacceptable and unjust for Aboriginal people. I commend this clause to both the opposition and the government.

—I thought we had seen the last of this amendment but now that Senator Spindler has moved it I will need to explain why the Commonwealth, regrettably, cannot accept it. The amendment is designed to extend the protection of Aboriginal rights in the context of validation exercises. As such, we look at it initially with a sympathetic eye. The trouble is that it does go too far in our judgment and undercuts this delicate balance that we are trying to maintain.

PARA.TAB: The present clause 15 protects, as we have discussed in passing several times, rights under Commonwealth reservations and other rights, whether conferred by way of legislation, common law, equity or usage. But it does not protect native title as such. Clause 15 is aimed at doing other things. The amendment seeks to protect not only other rights, including native title, to bring that specifically into the scope of clause 15. It also seeks to protect existing access—not rights of access, but actual access—that might be occurring as a practical matter. I am not talking about legally enforceable rights of access but actual practical access.

In our judgment, this would mean that validated lease rights of the kind that we are seeking to protect in their full extent may be read down, not only by the extent of any native title that might be held to exist. This could cut a considerable swathe into the actual enjoyment of the lease rights in question—something which we said we do not think should happen. Passed grants of this kind and the economic enjoyment associated with them ought to continue to be able to be enjoyed notwithstanding claims of native title. Native title can only expect to have full force and effect so far as the future situations are concerned. Not only is this going to be read down by native title rights in this context but also by access that might be presently enjoyed. We have the actual lease conditions—being lease enjoyment—being read down to that extent.

There is a sense in which, to the extent that there are rights of traverse or other forms of access to land in question being enjoyed in practice, at the moment we would like to see them preserved and not knocked off by a validation process. It is one thing to preserve formal legal rights of a kind that exist under statutory reservations or acknowledged common law; it is another thing to embark upon a much wider enterprise of the kind that is involved in this amendment.

Our intention—this is a response also to something that Senator Panizza raised earlier—is to support a proposal that is currently being mooted and discussed with the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, among others, that codes of conduct be developed between pastoralists and Aboriginal people to systematically address Aboriginal concerns in this respect. That is an essentially voluntary regime that is being talked about, rather than something that is rammed down anyone's throats. As a practical way of redressing these concerns and keeping the rather delicate balance between the nation's economic interests and the interests of Aboriginal people, we think that is the way to go.

I know Senator Spindler will not agree with me but I hope that he will at least acknowledge that sometimes we have had to come down on the side of the balance that does not necessarily have much appeal to him but which is necessary to keep the total shape of this legislation reasonably workable so far as the total interests of the nation are concerned. I do not expect Senator Chamarette will agree with me either but, again, I hope that she will acknowledge that the Commonwealth has reached a firm position in good faith, and I am afraid that is where we have to stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether I cannot persuade the minister to soften his position on that. We are talking about an existing right. In not agreeing to that amendment, one would actually be taking something away from Aboriginal people. When he says that the government is prepared to acknowledge contracts, covenants, reservations or whatever else that are in writing, we ignore the cultural context that there is such a thing as usage by Aboriginal people that has existed for decades, possibly hundreds of years. Nobody has ever put it in writing and nobody has ever signed a contract. But to Aboriginal people it would be very real indeed.

PARA.TAB: Even in European law we have something like adverse possession. If one shifts one's fence and leaves it there for 15 years without a contract, after 15 years that piece of land belongs to that person. We are not suggesting that title should be transferred, as it would be under the adverse possession doctrine in European property law. We are simply saying: why should we take away what is being enjoyed at the moment by Aboriginal people as of usage when everybody has tacitly agreed to it—it has been done; it is being done? Why take it away?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the sake of clarity, I refer Senator Spindler to the language in Democrat amendment 15(b). I think he is probably underestimating the extent to which the sort of situations that he has in mind are already protected by clause 15. If there are actual rights that one can identify—whether created by legislation, which is the easy case, or by common law and whether or not involving rights of usage—long usage and long adverse possession rights will almost certainly be recognised by the common law.

PARA.TAB: We are a bit concerned that a pastoralist may, out of the goodness of his heart, give someone access to a fishing hole or something like that and people will go there for a month or two and establish the access associated with that, but we can hardly say that is long usage—let alone adverse possession or anything terribly traditional. It is just an access that has been granted. Under the terms of the Democrat amendment, we now have a situation that that would produce, in perpetuity, an inhibition on the scope of the lease in question. That is the trouble with the Democrat amendment. Let us look at the language in 15(b):

SPEECH.PARA: (b)the doing of the act would affect any existing access to and enjoyment of any land or waters . . .

That is access right now; it is not access that has existed over multiple generations or something of that kind. It is just existing access. There are some problems in the way in which this is drafted. I understand the intent and force of some of the honourable senator's arguments, but I think the main things he is concerned about are probably already covered by clause 15.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confirm that the Greens support the amendment proposed by Senator Spindler, basically for the reason that the minister has just raised. We believe that unless this bill is to maintain the present standard and not remove existing access to and enjoyment of any land or waters currently held by Aboriginal or Islander people, this legislation is not worthy of support. This clause, therefore, is an important one.

PARA.TAB: The special rights and interests of Aboriginal and Islander people should be recognised and preserved, whether by reservation, condition or usage through legislation, common law or equity. If the validation provisions contained in this bill are to work in a non-discriminatory fashion for Aboriginal and Islander people, these access enjoyment provisions must be incorporated in the bill.

I ask the minister: as the proclaimed aim of this bill is to not erode native title rights but to preserve them in so far as they already exist, does he not realise that there are other aspects of native title that do not relate to land or title to land, but actually involve the cultural and spiritual activities of Aboriginal people? I would like him to specify which of those activities of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people the minister envisages would be covered by the Democrat amendment which is in conflict with a policy decision of the government. Why is the government, therefore, opposing the amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of things to say to Senator Chamarette. The first one—I have to keep repeating this whenever Senator Chamarette starts talking about opposing the bill as a whole because she does not like something associated with the validation clauses—is to remind her that the validation clauses really deal only with a tiny corner of the total picture of the landscape and so on. It is basically a fairly theoretical exercise anyway because nobody has really been able to identify with any confidence which kinds of interest may be invalid and therefore requiring this validation. The vast mass of other interests relates to valid grants in the past and there is still room for argument about the extent of that impact on native title. I am sorry for being repetitive about that, but I think it is important to make that point when Senator Chamarette starts moving into in terrorem mode about what she will do if a particular clause here is not passed to her satisfaction.

PARA.TAB: The second point I would make is that it is one thing to talk about preserving native title and not seeing a validation exercise extinguish native title. I understand her position on that. That is one thing and she is obviously going to support Senator Spindler's amendment to the extent that it does have that effect of giving some possibility of native title not being extinguished. But I ask Senator Chamarette to please recall that Senator Spindler's amendment goes much further than merely preserving native title. It does go to dealing with situations of simple access, maybe entirely current access, not having any particular history or pedigree about it. That does obviously go much further than a clause designed to protect in a further way native title. It is protecting another whole class of interest indeed.

I think there is a practical point that is worth making here. If there is a clause like this in the legislation, it might start making pastoralists very nervous indeed about granting access rights to Aboriginal people in the future to come in and fish in a fishing hole or hunt or do something like that, even though that is not really accurate because we are talking here about validation of past acts and so on.

There is so much misunderstanding and misinformation about the operation of this act. If there is a provision, even in this particular corner of the bill, inhibiting the scope of a lease by reference to access rights that have been granted out of the generosity of a pastoralist's heart perhaps—if that is ever possible, but I am prepared to concede that it is—that may inhibit the willingness to exhibit such generosity on a casual basis in the future. That is something I think Senator Spindler does need to ponder. I do not want to conjure up too many demons about this clause, which is a well-intentioned one, but he does have to think through the consequences of going a little bit further than the balance of interest we are after strictly requires.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens and the Australian Democrats raised questions on the access of Aboriginals to certain places like waterholes. I share their concerns. I believe the access of Aboriginals to these places should be enshrined so they do not lose it. The minister is drawing up a code of conduct, which he tells me is to look after these matters. I presume that the converse also applies; that is, other people have a right of access—either now, or they will have in the future—over some Aboriginal lands, or certainly ones which are claimable. One definite example of that is the Canning stock route in Western Australia, which runs from Wiluna to Halls Creek. There is a Mabo-style claim over that. So I presume that example would also apply in that code of conduct.
—Stock routes are expressly excluded, and you know that.

—I know that, but I am glad that the minister brought it to my attention again. I am sure that the Greens and the Democrats would be supportive of that idea too, because that track is a kind of tourist track. I know it is not a track that an average tourist from the soft areas in Australia would use, but it is one that has been there for a long time, it is used by a lot of four-wheel drive vehicles, and certain stations benefit a little when they can sell supplies. So I think the Greens and the Democrats should indicate that they support my thrust to make sure that all Australians would keep such a right. Furthermore, I point out to the minister that I know stock routes are specifically excluded, but the Canning stock route is an abandoned route and I do not think that it would come under that definition. So he may have to extend that definition.
—If it is abandoned, what's your fuss?

—It is abandoned as a stock route, so your definition of it as a stock route is out. It was abandoned probably in the 1960s, but it is now used as a tourist track for four-wheel drive vehicles. As I said, it is not everyone's idea of touring—it is certainly mine—but I would like to see that track kept open. The fact is that it is an abandoned stock route; it is marked on the map as such, so I think it should be different from other tracks. The minister should expand his definition to include abandoned stock routes.
—It is not my clause. You should be speaking to the Democrats.
—I want you to include abandoned stock routes in the code of conduct that you will be drawing up.

—I briefly want to say that I do not see it as an act of benevolence to recognise these particular activities currently operating for Aboriginal people on or away from pastoral leases. It is a sheer matter of justice that, if people have been living in a particular way and their culture and way of life involves such an area, this legislation should not be detracting from that point. I am quite happy for the legislation to improve upon it in a way that recognises the rights of other people who might have concerns, but I do not support the idea that it should be a way of diminishing any existing practices that they are currently involved in.

—I make the point to the minister that we are not talking about exclusive access or exclusive use; we are talking about co-existing practices—just as the bill preserves public access but ensures that it does not extinguish native title. So I think in this case—I agree for once with Senator Panizza, and I am sure that he will be pleased and perhaps a little surprised about that—that there should be some reciprocity on this principle. I wonder whether the minister could help me on this matter. When we talk about existing access and enjoyment, I imagine that a court would not find this access to exist if it were just a casual one-month use of a fishing hole. For access to exist, the court would have to find that access has been there for some time. I cannot put a time limit on the period of access—I doubt whether the minister could either—but I would imagine that a court would apply a reasonable time limit on that.

—I have a question for Senator Spindler, the mover of the amendment. I am trying to grapple with how this amendment fits in with what the parliament is actually trying to do—and that is to recognise and acknowledge the decision of the High Court in respect of certain very fundamental questions which go to the ownership and occupancy of land—and with the judgment of the High Court in Mabo No. 2. I cannot see that it does. That is not to say that there are not other things in this bill that do not; a whole host of things do not fit in with Mabo No. 2.

PARA.TAB: When we come to land ownership and occupancy—and, in a certain sense, management—it seems to me that this amendment does cut across the Mabo No. 2 decision. As has been pointed out previously in the debate, if the proposition is to talk about the existing access, the current access might have occurred only very recently. Senator Chamarette says that it is up to the courts to determine that. Current means current, I would have thought.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mabo No. 2 establishes the right to native title. It also says that native title can be extinguished by the issuing of leases. The government's clause 15 seeks to preserve some existing statutory rights and reservations of Aboriginals which exist in an area which is now going to be subject to lease because a lease is going to be issued by the government. This clause seeks to preserve some of the benefits and statutory entitlements that Aboriginal people have in that area to which they will lose native title because the lease will extinguish it. It seeks to excise those areas to which Aboriginal people have an entitlement.

PARA.TAB: My amendment seeks to include in that provision existing access and enjoyment. That could be access to a sacred site, to a fishing hole or to a waterhole—something that has never been made the subject of a reservation, never been put into a contract, and never been put in writing, but does exist by virtue of usage by Aboriginal people. Another point that we debated was how long such access has to exist for this clause to apply and for a court to take account of it.

I think the amendment fits within Mabo No. 2. It simply seeks to preserve some existing rights and to give Aboriginal people some certainty, in the same way as the bill seeks to provide some certainty to the pastoral, tourism and mining industries by validating leases which, by virtue of the Racial Discrimination Act since 1975, might be invalid. I understand that there are only about 11 leases in existence in Australia that would be caught by it. The bill seeks to provide that certainty to industries. I am asking that that same certainty about a right that exists by virtue of usage—access and enjoyment are the words I am using—be extended to Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the debate, but, having heard what was said in the debate previously, I still cannot accept the idea that we can have in legislation a protection of an existing right to have access to an enjoyment of land or waters. As Senator Evans indicated previously, it could have been out of the goodness of the heart of some leaseholder, pastoralist or miner in respect of land over which the Aboriginal people concerned may not have any hope of establishing claims. Even though they may happen to, at this present point in time, have access to water, they may be wandering around the place like any other person.

—With your indulgence, I just wanted to make the final point that the access and enjoyment in this case should not be stopped simply by virtue of the issue of a lease. I think that is the only point that I am making. I am not suggesting that, as a result of my amendment, that right should exist in perpetuity. That is not the intention, and I do not think that that is the effect of the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 16.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6)Clause 16, page 10, subparagraph (2)(a)(ii), line 32, omit "both sides of".
(12)Clause 22, page 13, paragraph (6)(a), line 40, omit "both sides of".
(61)Clause 220, page 103, paragraph (2)(a), line 24, omit "both sides of".
(62)Clause 220, page 103, paragraph (2)(b), line 28, omit "both sides of".
(63)Clause 220, page 104, paragraph (5)(b), line 12, omit "both sides of".
(64)Clause 225, page 106, paragraph (a), line 21, omit "both sides of".
(72)Clause 238, page 113, omit the definition of "land", lines 7 and 8, substitute the following definition:
"`land' includes the airspace over, or subsoil under, land, but does not include waters;

Note:Because of the definition of `waters', not only rivers and lakes etc., but also such things as the bed or subsoil under, and airspace over, rivers and lakes etc. will not be included in `land'.".
(74)Clause 238, page 115, definition of "waters", at the end of the definition add the following word and paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "; or (c)the shore, or subsoil under or airspace over the shore, between high water and low water.".

SPEECH.PARA: Most of those amendments are small and inconsequential. The thrust of the main amendments emanates from concerns expressed by representatives of the fishing industry and also the recommendations of the majority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The government is proposing a package of measures to make it clear that the test for acts over onshore areas, which are water, will apply for the purposes of this bill to areas such as intertidal area, bays, estuaries and harbours which may be subject to native title. The effect of these amendments is to confirm that the intertidal area, the harbours and so on will be regarded as water and not as land for the purpose of this bill. These amendments will ensure that where it is possible now to issue, for example, fishing licences over water in areas where freehold land is held over the adjoining shore they will also be able to be issued over water which is subject to native title.

PARA.TAB: It is our judgment that these amendments should overcome the concerns expressed by the commercial fishing industry about its future operations in these sorts of areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part 2 of the bill deals with native title. Division 1 relates to the recognition of native title and the protection of it. In recent times, we have been dealing with division 2, which relates to past acts of native title. Subdivision A relates to acts attributable to the Commonwealth. Under that subdivision, we come to clause 16 of the bill, which is the clause we are now debating, and the amendments, which the minister has just mentioned.

PARA.TAB: Clause 16 is under the general heading of `Entitlement to compensation', remembering that this is in relation to acts attributable to the Commonwealth. Clause 16(1) deals with category A past acts and category B past acts where native title has been extinguished by those acts. Subsection 2 of section 16 deals with the compensation to be paid where there is no extinguishment. Subsection 3 deals with compensation for partial effects of the act. Subsection 4 deals with compensation and who pays it. It simply says that the Commonwealth pays it.

I want to make some fairly general comments in relation to clause 16. I will make some more specific inquiries in relation to the amendments later. I know that my colleagues also have a particular interest in these matters.

What concerns me is that it is now 18 months since the Mabo No. 2 decision was brought down. The government has had all of that time to get together a piece of legislation that is fair to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, which adequately looks after the interests of other people in Australia and which ensures our continuing economic growth. It has had all this time to do that. No doubt it has been through this legislation a number of times. It has received the very best of advice in relation to it and had the Parliamentary Counsel and his staff working on drafting these matters. It comes as somewhat of a surprise to me to find that, after all that, there are all these amendments to be introduced.

I acknowledge that the amendments are somewhat technical. Although they relate to many clauses, they are all in the same vein of things. It seems to me that this is a classic example of why we should not be dealing with this bill today. This clause was obviously introduced by the government with all the best advice and the right intentions. It did not understand or know that there were real problems with it.

The bill was sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for it to do an investigation into all aspects of the bill. That committee did a marathon job in the short space of a week. It travelled all around Australia hearing evidence from a great number of people who had become aware of the difficulties with the bill and who were available to give evidence.

I understand from members of the committee that those giving evidence did so, on average, for about nine minutes each; that was the only time that was available. The committee simply did not have time to allow more than that on average to the witnesses appearing before it. With that very short and perfunctory examination—although it was an excellent effort by the senators involved—it was of necessity a brief look at the bill to find out what was wrong with it.

A number of grave concerns were expressed in relation to this clause. The report put out by the committee in relation to this clause and the matters contained in it makes for interesting reading. I do not know why these were not thought of or looked at by the government beforehand, but it shows that the government simply has not consulted properly or widely enough. It has not given the right amount of time to have a look at what these provisions do. Whilst the witnesses appearing before the committee have identified these problems—the committee, both in the majority report and the minority report, has also recognised this—who knows what has not been looked at.
I will very briefly mention that, in the majority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, its members were concerned about fishing issues. Their report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . Fishing industry representatives claimed that:

PARA.TAB: .The Bill fails to specify whether coastal land subject to native title will be to the high or low water mark; and
.If native title diminishes existing fishing rights of commercial fishermen adequate compensation should be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority committee—that is, the Labor senators—mentioned that in its report. In fact, it recommends:
The Bill should clarify the treatment of the fishing industry as it is effected by the distinction made in the Bill between onshore and offshore regimes.

Senator Spindler referred to the matter as well in his, I suppose we could say, super-minority report and suggested some amendments—not amendments to clause 16 but amendments to clause 22 and others which are interrelated. He did make reference to that clause as well. Certainly, the concerns of the fishing industry were detailed at length in the minority report, which is by far the better report on this issue. The dissenting report states:
(i) The Bill fails to specify whether coastal lands subject to native title will be to the high or low water mark.
Again, the question of compensation was raised. He went on to say:

(iii) The Bill in its definition creates the artificial distinction between offshore and onshore areas with the latter including estuaries, bays and inlets along the coast of a State. Any fishing in the onshore areas would be subject to the more rigorous provisions of the Bill; it was thought that these areas should be categorised as "offshore" which would result in less exposure to native title claims.
The dissenting report dealt with that at some length.

PARA.TAB: As a result of those reports, the government's attention had been alerted to the errors made in the drafting of this particular clause. It has brought in these amendments to that clause which it is hoped, I think Senator Evans said, will fix the anomalies that have been prepared.

I ask Senator Gareth Evans: in dealing with the amendments proposed, what form of consultation did the government embark upon? The government was wrong the first time it tried to draft clause 16, and that had to be pointed out to it by the fishing industries. Has the government, in relation to these amendments, in any way consulted with those people who are very interested in and affected by these particular amendments? To a certain extent these amendments will have an impact not only on the fishing industry in its purest form but also on the prawning industry and, importantly, on the pearling industry in Western Australia, which is a multimillion dollar industry. I am sure Senator Panizza would be able to help with the extent of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $100 million.

—It is worth $100 million annually—perhaps more—and is vitally involved in what we do here. As well, one of my colleagues from Tasmania quite rightly indicated to me today that these amendments will also impact upon the oyster industry, which is a very big industry as well in parts of Australia. I understand it is to become even bigger. As the waterways in the rest of the world become more and more polluted, Australian oysters will become an even greater export activity.

PARA.TAB: We received the amendments only a couple of days ago. We have not had the time to consult as widely as we would have liked on these amendments. I seek information from the minister on what sort of consultation the government entered into with not only fishing and commercial interests but also Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. What sort of investigations were undertaken? Were these amendments fully looked at? Were those groups given the proposed amendments so that they could get their own legal advice on them?

The government got it wrong the first time round. So how can we be confident that it has not got it wrong this time as well. This has concerned the Liberal and National parties all the way through this debate. I note Senator Spindler's comments on the last amendments. I did not particularly agree with what Senator Spindler was saying, but he made some points which I have not heard argued before. I may not have been around at the right time. They are the sorts of things that we should be given time to look into.

The opposition has not had the opportunity to look at these amendments as fully as we would have liked. I would like to hear from the minister what sort of consultation the government has had and what sort of consultation the department handling this bill has had so that he can assure us that the government has got it right this time and that it has not made yet another mistake. I want to be assured that we will not be coming back in February, March or April yet again dealing with amendments to this bill because it was rushed through the Senate and we find that the proposed amendments will not prejudicially affect the pearling industry, the fishing industry, the prawning industry, the oyster industry and so on.

I would like the minister to assist me by explaining in a bit more detail how clause 16 will affect those industries and how it will affect the tourist islands.
