TALK.START.PARA: —Rottnest.

—Senator Campbell reminds me of Rottnest Island in Western Australia. Has the tourist industry been consulted? Are they aware of these amendments. Do these amendments in any way affect the tourist industry? I ask the minister for some assurances on those matters.

—These are not the world's most complicated amendments. The basic linguistic change involved in just about every one of the amendments in the list I read out involves the deletion of three words only from the relevant clause, the words being `both sides of'. Clause 16 refers to `the land adjoining both sides of, or surrounding, any waters concerned'. The point of the exercise is to make that read `the land adjoining or surrounding any waters concerned'.

PARA.TAB: The problem before was that the onshore regime, which has a number of different contexts in which it applies in this bill, was clearly applicable to lakes and rivers where there is land either side of them or surrounding them in an onshore context. The offshore regime by contrast, to which different consideration apply in the legislation, clearly extended to out at sea. It left in an ambiguous zone, not clearly defined as either onshore or offshore, the bays, the estuaries, the intertidal area between high and low tide and so on.

So there was a hiatus in the legislation as drafted. One could ask how that hiatus managed to get there. I think it would be fair to say that the states—which after all are responsible for issuing all fishing licences in the onshore area, including bays, estuaries and intertidal areas that are close onshore—did not raise this issue with the Commonwealth during the really quite extensive consultations that were involved over last year, which is something that has slipped through the cracks. I think this is an area squarely within the jurisdiction of the states. It is just one of those things that happen. But I do not think the Commonwealth can be blamed for not picking up the existence of a problem. As soon as the legislation was exposed, particularly in the context of the Senate committee inquiry, as Senator Ian Macdonald has said, it did become apparent that there was an industry concern that the onshore regime was not clearly applicable.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Chairman: the minister is giving a very interesting answer. We have filled up our side of the chamber pretty well today and I think the other side should do the same and get some government senators down here to listen to the minister.

—If Senator Panizza has a look around him, he will see that there are two opposition senators and four government senators in the chamber at the moment. He has not done really well on that point. (Quorum formed) The main context in the legislation in which this issue arises is in terms of the definition of future acts and what can be done by way of affecting native title. For things that are clearly offshore, all acts are permissible; for things that are onshore, something can be done over native title only if it is done over a freeholder. That is the basic principle—the freehold equivalent test and so on. So it is important to sort out whether one is talking about onshore or offshore.

PARA.TAB: There was this twilight zone that was not expressed in the legislation and it gave rise to concerns and uncertainty as to what the particular legal regime would be. Would it be the offshore test or would it be the onshore test? What we are clearly talking about with bays, estuaries and intertidal zones is onshore waters. They are in the same conceptual category as rivers, lakes and so on. So it is perfectly appropriate that the regime that applies to rivers and lakes applies to those particular areas.

Have we succeeded in producing that result by the drafting? Senator Ian Macdonald worries about that. As I say, it is a very simple little linguistic exercise involved to remove the requirement from the definition of onshore waters that there be land either side. Once we get rid of that restriction, we have to have land on only one side of the water in question—not both sides. We have got to the stage of being able to embrace waters of this kind.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy, which represents the interests in these matters of the fishing industry, has told us that it is perfectly comfortable with the particular amendment. It believes it meets the concerns. Certainly, in the time that these amendments have been out and about—and there is intense interest in this from the fishing industry—we have heard no suggestion that we failed to do what people wanted us to do; namely, clarify the regime in question.

Those opposite can carry on about amendments, but that is what the legislative process is all about. They do not like us bringing in bills, rubber-stamping them and going out the door again. They like to think that they are contributing something to the process by the business of parliamentary deliberation and, in particular, by the work of the Senate committees. Here is a very good example of a problem coming to light in the context of the Senate committee inquiry exercise: the government fixing it by a relatively simple drafting device, fixing a number of clauses simultaneously by very similar language and getting a result that everybody is comfortable with. I do not know what Senator Ian Macdonald is complaining about. I think he is being a bit unreasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I emphasise that Senator Gareth Evans says, `We think we have fixed it'. He thought he had it right originally. It took the Senate committee—and the industry groups that came to the Senate committee—to determine that he was wrong. The minister did not specifically say that he has not sent this out to the industry groups, the people who gave evidence—but I take it that he has not. He is relying on the DPIE. That is beaut. I would have hoped the DPIE looked at it the first time. If the people there did, they missed the problem.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister why the interested parties cannot have a look at these things so he does not suffer this embarrassment again and have to come back to deal with what he says is a fairly simple amendment. If it is so simple, one wonders why he did not pick up the problem previously. I am concerned that those people have not seen it. We have been trying to get in touch with them to get them to look at it; but in the time we have had available to us that has not been as successful as we would have liked. The government has little interest in making sure it gets it right this time; it is relying on the DPIE to say that it is right.

I would like Senator Evans to explain to me how onshore waters are determined and defined. I understand a baseline is drawn somewhere and anything on the landward side of that is onshore waters. I ask Senator Evans to clarify who makes those decisions. Is it done under some Commonwealth act or is it the responsibility of each of the states? If it is the states' responsibility, have they been consulted?

I notice that Senator Evans, in his defence as to why the amendment was needed, said, `It was not our fault; it was the states who were wrong. They did not tell us about it last time'. I do not think that Mr Court has had that sort of problem with his legislation. This is Commonwealth legislation; so obviously the Commonwealth should be aware of these things and make sure everything is covered. I would be interested to hear his answers in relation to what constitutes onshore waters; how that is determined; and in whose jurisdiction it is to make that determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of definition in the act. In the definitional section on page 113, towards the bottom, both offshore place and onshore place are defined. It is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: "onshore place" means land or waters within the limits of a State or Territory to which this Act extends.
"offshore place" means any land or waters to which this Act extends, other than land or waters in an onshore place.

So waters that are not onshore; in other words, waters that are beyond the limits of a state or territory are counted as offshore. Others are counted as onshore, as the definition is laid out. That means in practice that the landward side of waters down to the low water mark are onshore. In the case of bays and estuaries, straight lines join the points of the bay. The enclosed territorial or state waters on the landward side are onshore—everything else is offshore.

PARA.TAB: There was a policy omission. That was recognised in the Senate committee inquiry and the discussion that took place with DPIE and industry at that time. It is a matter of a very simple drafting amendment to the clauses in question to clarify what was otherwise a source of confusion. We have done that. The draftsmen do that sort of thing all the time. I repeat that it is not a matter of believing it—I am certain there is no longer any problem with it. The onshore regime as I have described it is clearly applicable to these characters of waters. Certainty has been reintroduced and I am sure the industry will be happy about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the concerns of Senator Ian Macdonald because I still have a great deal of apprehension about the lack of consultation with regard to this particular area. I would like to ask the minister whether the government, in the intervening period since the Senate committee met in Darwin, has been able to alleviate the concerns of state governments and the Northern Territory government about the issues that they specifically addressed in the evidence on this particular matter.

PARA.TAB: The minister has alluded to picking up concerns of the industry. Yet I notice the raft of amendments that he has just proposed are basically very simple and omit the words `on both sides of' from a number of clauses. Given that the issue of what is commonly called the intertidal zone—that is, the area between high and low water mark—was very specifically raised as a matter of principal concern, I ask the minister to clarify what arrangements have taken place between governments on this matter in the interregnum and to what extent this legislation is consistent with, different from and overrides the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act in this particular regard.

In this intertidal zone between the high and low water marks there are implications for the pearling industry in particular, as Senator Ian Macdonald has very rightly pointed out, involving industries worth $100 million between Broome and Cape York. Similarly, it also has major implications in the mining industry field for the pipelines that will be required to traverse that particular area. I would ask the minister to clarify those issues. Could he also give an indication of his intention with regard to the amendment to clause 238 that is being proposed by the Greens at this stage. That might abbreviate some of my other reservations and concerns on that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble is that some people simply cannot take yes for an answer. We get identification of a problem; we fix the problem in a way that manifestly involves quite a simple drafting technique; and no-one expresses any unhappiness about it. It becomes obvious when one understands the terms of the bill. Some of those opposite obviously have not read the bill because they have not come to the definitional provisions which make a lot of these things very clear. I understand that because this is a big complex piece of legislation; I do not read all bills myself either. If those opposite look at this carefully, and I have taken them through the relevant bits, they will see how the answers are there.

PARA.TAB: The intertidal zone between the low and high water mark created some question mark because of the way these clauses were originally written which talked about land on both sides of the water in question. By definition land is not on both sides of the water that sweeps backwards and forwards in an intertidal zone; land is on only one side of it. So there was a question mark about whether that was properly captured by this language.

The removal of the reference to land having to be on both sides for it to be onshore waters has obviously solved that particular problem, and ditto with the bays and estuaries issue. The governing criterion then becomes the standard definition of `offshore' and `onshore' in the back of the act, because that is the definition which uses the limits of the state or territory as its criterion. It is well known what the limits of the state or territory are; that is, in this context the low water mark and the straight line point between bays and estuaries.

Once we got rid of the possible source of confusion created by the expression `both sides of', that definition does its work and the confusion disappears. The industry together with the states who have an interest in this as the regulators of this industry are also comfortable. Other implications, whether it is for location of pipelines or anything else, all fall into place. It does not just have implications for the fishing industry; anything else that might be dependent upon the precise definition of what is in or out of the different jurisdictions onshore or offshore also clearly falls into place. I think that is a pretty reasonable response to the kinds of concerns that have been expressed in this respect. I hope that Senator Tambling will understand it as such.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister did not answer my question which specifically asked what consultation had been engaged in with the state and territory governments between the Senate committee hearings in Brisbane, Darwin and Perth and whether those governments, which have a major concern in this legislation, have been consulted and are now happy with the proposed amendment.

—I am unable to say whether the governments have been specifically consulted about the actual terms of the amendment. It very often happens in the drafting of legislation that concern is expressed about something. There is no particular issue about what is technically necessary to fix it. The important thing is to get an acknowledgment that there is a problem and a commitment to fix it. That was communicated in this instance I am sure through DPIE. We have no reason whatever to believe that there is any problem about this.

PARA.TAB: If we understand the drafting that is involved here, if we focus on that rather than the politics of it for a moment, we will see that there really is no room left for argument or problem about this. It is a simple matter to fix, once it has been recognised that there was a policy problem because of the way it had been drafted. We recognised that—that became clear during the committee hearings—and it has been fixed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Similarly, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) did not address another of my questions which related to the consistency between the Native Title Bill and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. If there are inconsistencies between the two pieces of federal legislation, is there any provision in this bill which does not lie parallel with that of the Aboriginal land rights act and which would be capable, therefore, of causing considerable confusion and exacerbate the interests of Aboriginal owners, Aboriginal people and people who are interested in this specific area, such as those in the fishing industry, the pearling industry and the mining industry?

PARA.TAB: The minister, in addressing my concerns, has expressed his belief. I hope it is not just a blind faith. We will certainly look to him in the future when he occupies the position of a justice in the High Court as an interpreter of any appeals that might come under this legislation. I hope various witnesses will draw upon the Hansard of today for many of the arguments he is advancing. On this clause, there is indeed a great deal of concern about the areas where the Aboriginal land rights act of the Northern Territory is inconsistent or in conflict with the Native Title Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had to take quick advice on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, and I may need to be corrected if I get this wrong. My understanding is that, under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, grants of land can be given down to the low water mark. Under this bill, interests can be granted down to that mark in the intertidal zone, provided they can be granted where there was ordinary title—that is freehold title—to the adjacent land. So it is subject to a condition in our bill whereas it is not subject to such a condition in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. Moreover, under complementary Northern Territory legislation to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, there can be sea closures whereas there is no provision for such closures under the terms of this particular bill. I think they are the relevant differences between the two pieces of legislation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling also asked me about our attitude towards the Greens' amendment 65 to clause 238. We will not be supporting that amendment. That has been communicated to the Greens. I do not think it comes as any news to them. That is one right at the end of the bill. I hope that helps resolve Senator Tambling's concerns in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) for that information and his response to the Greens' amendment. I notice that the Greens' amendment, as circulated, also refers to clauses 16, 22 and 225. This impinges on the answer the minister has just given on those issues concerning the high water mark and the low water mark. One of my apprehensions and concerns on that amendment of the Greens, which is in three parts, is that the Greens amendment to these other clauses would in effect have quite major economic implications. Those clauses increase rights to compensation and in fact elevate native title rights to something greater than other interested land-holders can hold. So again I seek the minister's clarification on the Greens' amendment 3A which addresses clauses 16, 22 and 225.

—Since Greens amendment 3A has not yet been moved, perhaps we should wait until it is. I can indicate now that we will be supporting that particular amendment. It makes clear the particular criteria by which compensation is payable, and we think that it is a definite improvement to the way in which the act operates in that respect. That amendment has not been moved yet. Perhaps, by leave, it could be moved and debated cognately with our own because there are related matters. Then again, since it relates to offshore waters, and the batch of amendments I have moved relate to onshore waters, it may be desirable to leave it until we resolve this other matter, which I hope we now have.

—In his opening remarks, Senator Evans said that the effect of the amendment was to allow for the issuing of fishing licences or the protection of fishing licences already issued. With respect, I do not quite agree that that is the effect of this amendment.
—It is to apply the onshore regime of the bill; that is the short answer to that.

—Yes, but I think we should look at what that onshore regime is because that is very important. Basically, this amendment omits the words `both sides of' from subclause 2(a)(ii) and makes consequential amendments, omitting the words `both sides of' from other parts of the bill.

PARA.TAB: On my reading, it basically says that as far as a native titleholder is deemed for the purposes of this bill to have the interests of a riparian owner, those interests should be the same as a riparian owner. When I read this particular clause through for the first time, and then when I read it over and over, I kept thinking of it in relation to rivers, where there is land on both sides. That would create an interesting regime—not only in regard to fishing, but also in regard to other uses of the land.

The law regarding riparian ownership is not that a riparian owner has rights over both banks of a river. A riparian owner has rights over his side of the river but not over the whole river, and not over the river and the other bank. What would the situation be for native titleholders with an interest in land on the New South Wales side of the Murray River? Without this amendment, the clause basically says that they could preclude any activity in relation to those waters, even if it occurred on the other bank, because their rights are equated not only with the rights of riparian owners on the New South Wales side of the river but with the rights of riparian owners on either side of the river. That is, it is assumed that they have ordinary title to the land adjoining both sides of the water.

For example, if somebody on the Murray River wished to build a jetty into but not extending beyond the middle point of the river, and starting on the Victorian or southern side, this clause, before the amendment, would preclude that happening because the jetty would have to be affixed to the bank on the southern side. If I am wrong about this, Senator Evans can explain where I have made the error. However, I understood that it precluded someone with a lease establishing a jetty on one bank and extending it into the river because it says that if an act is done in relation to an onshore place—a river is clearly an onshore place within the meaning of this bill—they are entitled to compensation as though they were holders of ordinary title to the land adjoining both sides of the water concerned.

In the case of somebody building a jetty into the river from the Victorian or southern side, they in no way impinge upon the rights of somebody who is a native titleholder or a freeholder on the northern or New South Wales side of the river. I thought that the effect of this particular paragraph was to say, `Look, you can't build the jetty on the southern side either because they are deemed to have the interests in relation to the bank on the southern or Victorian side of the river'—I think Senator Spindler can understand what I am saying here—and that would have had a very deleterious effect. There is a lot of benefit in deleting the words `both sides of' and making those consequential amendments.

The question then is whether that in and of itself protects fishing licences or interests that may have been granted in relation to onshore waters that adjoin land over which there are native titleholders. I do not think that is the case. In so far as native titleholders can be deemed to be riparian owners, they only have the same rights as any other riparian owner—that is, the rights appertaining to their side of the water. It does not give them rights over both banks, only over one bank. I do not think it says that fishing interests that are granted in relation to those onshore waters are protected. I still think there are difficulties to be encountered in fishing interests or any other interests in relation to those onshore waters, and I will deal with what other interests there are on top of fishing interests later.

Perhaps at this time the minister could confirm that I am correct in that it brings the riparian rights of native titleholders into line with the rights of other riparian owners—that is a starting point—and then we can look at whether the fishing interests are protected, whether the onshore regime, which is created even after this amendment, is necessarily a good one and whether it can still jeopardise the interests of people in the fishing industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to fairly succinctly respond to Senator O'Chee. My understanding of the effect of this legislation in the particular riparian context that he is mentioning is as follows: if a freeholder on one side of the river could stop or have a say in the conduct of a particular activity, so too could a native titleholder who has native title over the river itself. The test is that the freeholder on one side of the river has that capacity, not the freeholders on both sides. That may or may not strengthen the position of the native titleholder; it all depends on the nature of the activity concerned. It may not weaken it either. In a nutshell, that is what is required. Formerly we had to have that freehold capacity running on both sides of the water in question; now we only have to have it on one side.

PARA.TAB: The motivation for that particular change was to solve the problem of the estuaries and the bays and those onshore areas where there is only one side of the water. The effect of it is to slightly change the test in a riparian or lake context. I am trying to think of what the practical implications of that change might be. It is very hard to work out whether they would operate to advantage or disadvantage. It is probably pretty neutral. It is a working rule of thumb test as to what an adjoining landowner would be able to do in determining what the holder of the title on the water itself can do. As such, I do not think it ought to be an area of enormous concern. The great utility of this amendment is that it does fix up the other problem that was evident.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. I think he is starting to understand my concerns. When the minister answered the question he spoke as though the native title rights were in relation to the water. They could be in relation to the water or portions of the water in a river or lake, but I refer the minister to the definition of `onshore place', contained in clause 238 at the bottom of page 113. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: "onshore place" means land or waters within the limits of a State or Territory to which this Act extends;

It is not just as though the native title rights may appertain to a portion of water; they may also appertain to a portion of the land. That would still be an onshore place. One of the problems is a little definitional uncertainty because it does not quite say exactly what portion of the land. I will explain what I mean. Suppose there is a very large lease which fronts a river. A native titleholder may have rights in relation to a portion of that lease. For example, the lease area may be an area five miles deep with a frontage of three miles along the river, having a total area of about 15 square miles. If they have native title rights over any portion of that lease, it would appear to me that they would be able to exercise rights in relation to a portion of the adjoining river, notwithstanding the fact that the area that they may have an interest in may be five miles from the river. They are deemed to have an interest in the whole of that land, are they not?

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, that is a misunderstanding. The suggestion is not that the existence of native title or any other rights over the land gives one, by extension, some rights over the water. That is not the context in which this section applies. The context in which we are discussing it is where there are native title rights over the water, to what extent do those rights apply to stop activities taking place on the water? The test for determining whether the native titleholder can stop things taking place on the water is the freehold test—that is, whether or not an adjoining freeholder would have that same capacity.

PARA.TAB: It is because there is a bit of an oddity in ordinary property law about having rights over water as such. There are rights to utilise water and rights of riparian owners and so on to treat with the river in various ways. But the notion of having rights over the water—I suppose there might be fishing licences or things of that kind in the law which are parallel in their character—as such is one that is a bit hard to get a hold of.

That is why, in talking about what we can and cannot do with native title rights over the water, the freehold test has been devised. It has also been devised as a measure of compensation. That also crops up in this clause. I think the honourable senator is probably misreading the clause in question as having some effect in vesting rights over waters if one is simply a native titleholder of land. That is not so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister understands my concern in regard to the clause; I am glad to see that. I will explain to him why I still have that concern. The minister said that this subclause dealt with native title over waters.
—It deals with all sorts of things. But the particular context in which the issue of what you can do on waters arises only when there is native title over waters.

SPEECH.PARA: (a)The native title concerned is to some extent in relation to an onshore place

. . . the act could not have been validly done on the assumption that the native title holders instead held ordinary title to:

(ii) the land adjoining both sides of, or surrounding, any waters concerned;

TALK.START.PARA: —I know this is tricky, but, as the honourable senator says, it is just a matter of reading the text of the clause carefully. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. I hope we do not end up with a case like this, but if we do, I hope the government's intention in the clause is made abundantly clear.
—He will be on the High Court by then.

PARA.TAB: I raise with the minister another problem which relates to this. It is a problem that was drawn to my attention on an earlier visit to Western Australia, and would apply in certain places in Queensland. It relates to state jurisdiction. Essentially, an onshore place is an area of state jurisdiction. I am concerned that areas of Western Australia and Queensland may have a series of what would be called in international law `drying rocks', and that rights would appertain to each of the drying rocks and to the waters enclosed therein, because they would all be onshore places, would they not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Each of the what?

—Drying rocks; rock or coral bommies that are exposed at the low water mark. I note the comments that Senator Gareth Evans made to Senator Ian Macdonald in relation to the drawing of baselines, which is a related but separate issue. PARA.TAB: The question is, what is the effect of this bill over the waters that are on the landward side of those drying rocks? TALK.START.PARA: —And pearling.

—As Senator Ellison says, this could also affect the pearling industry. In Queensland, it could quite foreseeably affect much of the fishing industry. If one looks at most of Moreton Bay, the bars at either end—at Caloundra and Southport—are merely a couple of hundred metres wide. If there are native title rights, do those native title rights affect all of the waters within the bay? This is a separate question from the drawing of baselines between two low water marks across an estuary or inlet.

—The way the bill addresses this is to simply refer to the limits of a state. Therefore, it embodies all the law that exists elsewhere about how one defines the outer limits of a state on the shoreline, including in all these different close inshore islands and exposed drying rocks—as Senator O'Chee described them—situations. My advisers do not carry all this information around in their heads because it is not strictly necessary for the interpretation or drafting of this bill. Their recollection is that where the low water mark on the coastline actually extends beyond an offshore island—I am not sure whether I am explaining this very well; it looks more sensible on the diagram I have—it does count as part of the limits of the state rather than being offshore.

PARA.TAB: There is a lot of learning, legislation and case law about the precise delineation and determination of state boundaries in these situations. All of that is imported into the legislation by the definition here. The problem was that the way the bill was originally drafted—because it had the requirement that there be land on both sides of a stretch of water before it could count as onshore waters; before it could count as part of the state jurisdiction—it excluded things such as bays, estuaries and title zones.

That problem has been removed by the removal of the reference to having to have land on both sides. So we just have to go back to the definition of the limits of a state and the way in which that applies under the general law in order to determine precisely the answers to the question Senator O'Chee is putting to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I follow that, what Senator Evans means is that, provided the waters are waters within the state jurisdiction, they are onshore waters and then anything which takes place in the onshore water is subject to the rights of native titleholders in that area.
—Subject to the freehold test.

—Yes. The problem is not that they have to be freeholders, but merely that they have to have a right which is then, by virtue of a fiction contained in this proposed subsection, deemed to be a freeholder's right. Take, for example, Moreton Bay. Suppose a group of Aborigines on Stradbroke Island have certain rights in relation to Stradbroke Island. They are deemed to be freeholders, notwithstanding that the right may merely be to gather mussels on the shore. Their right is deemed to be a freeholder's right and that has other rights in relation to the waters.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans would not know this because he is from Victoria, but Moreton Bay, as Senator Boswell well knows, is a very lucrative fishing area and this could substantially affect, for example, the prawning industry, which would come very close to many of the islands in the bay. It may affect the fishing industry and it may affect the crabbing industry. Some honourable senators have in recent times had the benefit of the product of some of that crabbing industry in Queensland. Those industries could be affected if one has what Senator Evans described as the freehold test and what I describe as the freehold fiction; that is, that the freeholders have an estate or an interest in the land which is equivalent to a freehold interest. Because it is there and it relates to all of the onshore waters, I believe the effect of this proposed section is to basically cover large areas of water on the landward side of islands or drying rocks.

We have already seen the consequences this would have in Moreton Bay. We well know that there are Aboriginal claims over Stradbroke Island. That is a well-known fact. We all know there are very prominent Aborigines who come from Stradbroke Island or who claim to have links with Stradbroke Island. So, first of all, we have that problem in relation to a bay which is enclosed on one side by islands.

We then have the problem of areas that are exposed or generally exposed at low water, especially areas along the Great Barrier Reef where there are substantial reef structures. If we mark off the coastal waters three miles from the low water mark and if there is a series of drying rocks a couple of miles off the coast that were no more than six miles apart, then a huge area of water would be affected. It just does not seem very reasonable for the fishing industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope we do not have to repeat all these things every time we get to them, because we are anticipating a lot of things that arise elsewhere in the bill, but what needs to be understood about the freehold test is that, when it is applicable, it does not deem native titleholders to have freehold or even the equivalent of freehold. It is a test of when grants can be made and it is a test of when compensation is payable. It is not a test of the quantum of compensation that is payable. It is a threshold test, a hurdle test as to whether compensation is payable when acts are done which impair the enjoyment of the native title in question. So I think, once Senator O'Chee looks at it in those terms, the notion of a heap of rampant native titleholders possessing freehold equivalent rights and exercising them to the detriment of fishermen or whatever in the areas in question, is not really an accurate characterisation of the situation.
—I do not want to prolong the proceedings. I understand what Senator Evans says about his freehold test and that goes to the scope of compensation—
—No, it goes to whether compensation is payable, not the quantum.

—Yes, that is what I meant. It goes to the scope of cases in which compensation is payable, rather than the quantum. But because it catches a whole range of activities which would not otherwise be caught—it has a fiction in here about what the scope of compensation is—that then creates a cause of action to apply for compensation. One gets less compensation, admittedly, but an increase in the total amount of compensation is likely to be payable by increasing the number of causes of action for compensation, and I think that then has a detrimental effect on the fishing industry.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators should remember who has to pay the compensation. The compensation is payable by the Commonwealth. Obviously, because of other provisions in this bill, where it is an act which is given by the state, it would appear that the state has an obligation to pay. But certainly in relation to the northern prawn fishery area, which is something that is, in part, managed by the Commonwealth, it imposes a cost on the government.

I know how this government operates. Every time we have something to do with primary industry, every time we have something to do with fishing and every time we have something to do with the resource industries, the government keeps on saying that we have to have full cost recovery. Full cost recovery has been an absolute disaster. This user-pays concept has been an absolute disaster in much of primary industry. Full cost recovery, where the Commonwealth or the state has to pay compensation for the granting of a fishing licence, is going to directly increase the cost to the industry in that area.

The state government or the federal government will say, `This is one of the costs associated with the granting of this licence, which is the payment of the compensation. We can do one of two things: either we are not going to grant the licences because that involves an additional cost on the government, or in the granting of the licences we have to recover that cost and, therefore, we put an extra burden on the fishing industry'. What concerns me is the scope for putting additional costs on industry by virtue of the application of this section. Senator Evans says that we are not talking about the quantum but about the scope of compensation claims. It is more than that, because it increases the number of cases where the issuing of a licence could be detrimentally affected by the application of a fiction as to what the rights of a native titleholder should be in bringing an action for compensation.

We have something in this bill—as far as the fishing industry, the pearling industry and the lobster industry are concerned—which artificially makes it more difficult for the industry to operate. We have to question the wisdom, even after this clause is amended, of allowing the clause to stand because of the detrimental effect that we have just established it will have over the industry. I think Senator Evans has to admit that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens have a problem with one of these amendments. We have no problem with most of the amendments that are being proposed, but amendment No. 74, which relates to a definition of water that includes the shoreline between the high water mark and low water mark, presents its problems. I would like that to be dealt with separately, please.

—As I indicated at the outset of the debate, I can have no objection at any stage to any honourable senator who wants to have the vote on any particular one of these bunch of amendments dealt with separately. I hope Senator Chamarette will change her mind because I am not sure that it is a terribly helpful thing to do. But if that is what she wants to do, I am perfectly happy to go along with it.

—I have listened to the debate between Senator O'Chee and the minister. Virtually for the sake of this bill and this bill alone, the government has set the criteria of the shoreline from the high water mark to the low water mark. This will be inconsistent with a lot of other acts, such as the submerged lands act and also the tax act. For consistency, will the minister be looking at making those other acts the same?

PARA.TAB: I cannot think why this bill and the tax act should clash right now, but I can see them clashing in time if the accepted criteria of the shoreline is taken to be the high water mark, not the low water mark. I am sure that in time there will be some conflict. This matter brings out once again the haste with which this legislation has been put together. We have been here for hours and hours talking on fine points, and we could be here for hours and hours for another week or so and still not finish.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure about what is in the tax act in this respect, but the standard definition of state and territorial boundaries is the low water mark. I thought that a good states righter like Senator Panizza would want, on the whole, the normal definition of state boundaries to be applicable in something like this.
—The tax act is a high water mark.

—It may be—I do not know—but, when we are talking about things within the jurisdiction of the states, and the land management regimes of the states, it is appropriate to apply the normal definition of a state boundary. I do not think Senator Panizza's mates in Western Australia would be too thrilled to hear him putting at any risk the suggestion that the state boundaries should be narrowed for this purpose.

PARA.TAB: Government amendments 6, 12, 61, 62, 63, 64 and 72 agreed to.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—We will now deal with government amendment 74. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to say that the Greens will not be supporting amendment No. 74 because we do not see why the definition of waters should be any different from that applying to state and territory boundaries.

—The short point is that it still counts as onshore if it is in the intertidal zone. The only question is whether it is water or land. Since we are talking about an area of land that water flushes backwards and forwards over, it seems not unreasonable to describe it as water. Precisely why the draftsmen want to describe it as water apart from that, I am unable to say because we cannot find the relevant person.

PARA.TAB: It is an integral part, as I understand it, of this set of amendments, which were designed to address the concerns expressed by the industry. I think it probably had something to do with those fishing industries that operate in the intertidal zone and the satisfaction of their particular requirements for certainty, and so on. But I am not in a position to give Senator Chamarette any better explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we have a commercial interest that is balanced against a native title concern that is a matter of justice, I believe that we should be supporting a consistent position, which is a state boundary position.
—Would Senator Chamarette explain again—I was out of the chamber—the reason for her opposition to amendment No. 74 as opposed to the others?

—As I am not an expert on these matters; I hope I will not mislead the Senate. My understanding is that if we have a definition of water, it should be a consistent one, as Senator Panizza pointed out. The usual state boundaries go to the low water mark. The implications, as I believe them, of varying this definition are, in some way, designed to possibly minimise any impact of native title on the particular shore area that is covered by water. As a matter of justice, we have to look at that. It does not mean that there is any incompatibility between practices. It simply means that if we were talking about some freehold right in relation to that water, we would also want the most just, effective and consistent way of noting it. I think there is a matter of principle involved here.

—I am now a little better advised than I was a couple of minutes ago. The basic problem is that quite a number of fishing activities take place in this intertidal zone. Pools with crabs, barramundi and things such as that occur in that zone. Fishing licences are issued, and properly so, in the interests of the industry and, indeed, the nation over that zone. The trouble is that if we define this as land and not as water, we cannot issue those sorts of licences where native title exists because we cannot issue a fishing licence over land, to put it quite succinctly and self-evidently.

PARA.TAB: The way in which the freehold test operates is that we can engage in a future activity—that is, the grant of a licence of some kind—only if that activity could take place over land held by a freeholder. While that is a perfectly sensible test to apply in the context of native title on land, it is not too smart a test to apply on water. Honourable senators might think it is because native title rights then have the capacity to completely exclude the operation of any commercial fishing licences in that area, but that is not really the sort of balance we are about. It is in everyone's interests that commercial interests be able to occur and that native title interests, to the extent that they are not inconsistent, also occur. We are not in the business, I would have thought, of stopping fishing licences altogether. The effect of the opposition's amendment by not enabling this to be defined as water will stop such licences being issued in the future in circumstances where native title is recognised.

I would have thought that the Nationals might want to think long and hard about the implications of that, just in order to keep a sensible balance in the legislation. I do not want to talk about the Liberals and Nationals. I just hope that Senator Chamarette will understand the point in issue and will not seek to obstruct the passage of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no intention from the Greens to inhibit any legitimate rights or licences if some amenable solution can be worked out. However, the problem about it applying only to native title areas is one that may be sorted out or clarified a bit further with the amendments that the Greens are putting up later. The reality is that, in many of these cases, we are talking about the extinguishment of native title rights by other activities. If that happens, it is only appropriate that the compensation should be available. If we define it such that native title rights do not exist by this legislation, we are not in any way able to give compensation to those people whose native title rights have been extinguished for a fishing licence area or some other kind of area.

—I make it absolutely clear that, the way this provision is drafted, any native titleholder whose enjoyment is impaired by virtue of a licence being granted would be entitled to compensation. The way it is drafted, one is entitled to compensation if a fishing licence were to operate in an intertidal area occupied by native title in a way that impaired the native title, and that will be made even clearer when it comes to the Greens amendments, which we are prepared to support.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that, even if the Greens pursue some notional opposition to amendment No. 74, they do not pursue that to the point of a division or—if they do pursue that to the point of a division—that some people on the other side think carefully about what is involved. We are trying to help the industry get some certainty and some balance into this area. If this amendment is not carried, there will be a continuing problem in the intertidal zone. This is not just our response to industry. This is a unanimous recommendation of the Senate committee inquiry; it cut across both sides. I would hope that there could be some reconsideration of amendment No. 74. I hope that our amendment No. 74 can be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are opposing all amendments, as we have made clear, and have so far done. Senator Gareth Evans says `if we have any interest in the industry'; of course, we do have the interests of the industry at heart, and the interests of other industries as well. That is why we believe the whole bill should be withdrawn and dealt with at a time when it has been able to receive better consideration from all of those people who are interested in it. That is what we have been talking about for the last three days.

PARA.TAB: The whole bill is ill-conceived and fundamentally flawed, and most people say so—not just industry groups, but Aboriginal groups around the country. All sorts of groups say that the bill is fundamentally flawed. We cannot correct and make good a piece of legislation that is so fundamentally flawed. I suggest to Senator Chamarette that, if she is uncertain and has amendments to other clauses of this bill that may—in her view at least—clarify the issue, perhaps we should defer dealing with these amendments as well until such time as she is able to put her amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is putting them next; they are next on the running sheet.

—Perhaps these amendments should be deferred until that time. Perhaps Senator Chamarette could talk about that. We would be happy enough to defer consideration of those amendments until those other matters have been clarified so that the Greens can be certain. All the way through this, we have said that we want it to be understood, we want it to be clear, why we have objected to the way this legislation is being dealt with all the way through. It is uncertain; it is a very complex piece of legislation. Senator Chamarette obviously does not understand the aspects of amendment No. 74. I have to say that she is not alone, and I also do not understand all aspects of all of the things we are dealing with.

PARA.TAB: If we cannot get the bill deferred until everyone concerned has had time to properly consider it and so that we can deal with it again in a much more sober and mature way in February, then we will facilitate trying to clarify it for Senator Chamarette at present. If that means agreeing with the Greens to defer a vote on this amendment at this time, we are happy to do that.
I want to digress from the amendments. Perhaps this is slightly improper, but once we deal with the amendments we will be dealing with the clause. I return to clause 16(4) of the bill which states—

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Order! We have a number of other amendments that will be moved by Senator Chamarette. We will then deal with the clause. There will be opportunity at that time for you to speak to the clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did my best to save opposition members from making dills of themselves with their own industry lobbyists by not pursuing a division that would have been manifestly against the interests of that lobby. There are only so many times that I can go to that well. I ask the opposition to think again seriously about the implications of not supporting this amendment, which is manifestly in the interests of the industries that it supports.
—We are voting against all amendments.

—The opposition is demonstrating once again how totally unconstructive, destructive and stupidly counterproductive its attitude is. If that is the way the opposition, the shadow cabinet and its leadership choose to conduct themselves, that is their business, but I do not think it will impress too many people, least of all the industry people on whose behalf those opposite have been speaking so much in the last hour. They will be very impressed to see a division list on this clause—and we will be making very sure that they do see it.

—I seek to clarify this because I was requested to do so. The Greens still maintain that they are opposed to amendment No. 74. I have clarified why. I will try to explain it as simply as I can. If we look at the high water mark, then we are classifying a lot of onshore land as water. If we look at the low water mark, we are classifying that same area as shore. From the point of view of native title claimants, they have more difficulty in trying to provide evidence of native title rights in the area of water than in the area of land. The freehold test is one of those factors that comes in at that point. Therefore, it is in the best interests of any native title claimants who have legitimate claims to those areas under consideration to have a just basis for those determinations to be made, not an artificial one that is designed to suit particular purposes.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the problem that Senator Evans raised about the issuing of fishing licences, this problem arises only where there is a legitimate native title claim. That will possibly be in very few areas. Nothing goes against an arrangement being made by which proper negotiation and compensation can overcome any difficulties. That is why we are proposing to stay with our position and oppose this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't give you a licence to fish on land.

—Senator Evans made a smart remark about giving a fishing licence on land. I could not help picking it up. We are only talking about between the high water mark and the low water mark. I am very interested in the fishing industry. I have a sister who is in the fishing industry. I would like to see her industry keep going.
—A pretty big family you have, John.

—Instead of a mining licence, perhaps people in the fishing industry could be given an extractive industry licence to operate between the high and low watermarks. Has the minister ever thought of that one?
—That is a matter for the states. We could not possibly interfere.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 16, page 10, lines 34 to 38, omit paragraph (2)(b), substitute the following paragraph:
"(b)the native title concerned is to some extent in relation to an offshore place; or".
(2)Clause 22, page 13, lines 11 to 17, omit paragraph (4)(b), substitute the following paragraph:
"(b)either:
(i)the native title concerned relates to an offshore place and the act is not a low impact future act; or
(ii)the native title concerned relates to an onshore place and the following conditions are satisfied:
(A)the act is not a low impact future act; and
(B)the similar compensable interest test is satisfied in relation to the act; and
(C)the law mentioned in section 225 (which defines `similar compensable interest test') does not provide for compensation to the native title holders for the act;"
(3)Clause 225, page 106, lines 14 to 24, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "225. The `similar compensable interest test' is satisfied in relation to a past act or a future act if:

TAB.TAB: (a)the native title concerned relates to an onshore place; and

(b)the compensation would, apart from this Act, be payable under any law for the act on the assumption that the native title holders instead held ordinary title to any land or waters concerned and to the land adjoining, or surrounding, any waters concerned.".

SPEECH.PARA: This cluster of amendments arises because there are no equivalent rights in relation to an offshore place. Discussion up this point has mainly involved onshore places. The reason these amendments are required is that offshore rights may need to be considered in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Clause 16 is devised to help ensure that compensation is payable to native titleholders in circumstances where past acts are validated but where compensation may not have been payable under the bill's previous test. In particular, clause 16 allows for compensation on offshore places without the similar compensable interest test for the purposes of determining compensation.

Clause 22 provides a fairer test for determining compensation for the impairment of native title in relation to offshore waters. Clause 225 has been amended because this amended similar compensable interest test applies to onshore places. Some native title rights to waters may have no corresponding rights or interests. It is important that compensation for interference with that native title right be available. This amendment ensures that any extinguishment or impairment of native title interests held over onshore land and waters are compensated.

I would like to explain the reason why the Greens are presenting this amendment. It is one of our responsibilities, if this bill is a native title bill and it is intended to protect the existing native title rights of Aboriginal people, to look at the situations where almost all of their native title rights have been extinguished by the land practices of the last 200 years.

There are many people in New South Wales who have had their rights almost totally extinguished apart from their water rights and rights associated with their culture. Basically there are two aspects. Water is significant within the culture and lifestyle of Aboriginal people and there may be a situation where these rights have not been fully extinguished and need to be recognised. Secondly, for many Aboriginal communities this may well provide a resource base. As we are signatories to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights we have to be aware that article 27 of this covenant obliges signatories to protect the culture of traditional peoples by protecting their resource base.

Those two elements—spirituality and culture, and the resource base—are inseparable and interrelated. This amendment seeks to ensure that we are preserving those special considerations and allowing people like the Bardi people in the north-west and the people that have a reliance within their own communities on water and fishing to have that reflected in this legislation in a more accurate fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government accepts this package of amendments. They provide for a fairer regime of compensation for native title rights offshore which are affected by government actions. As Senator Chamarette indicated, at present the bill provides that native titleholders get compensation offshore where so-called corresponding rights get compensation. The trouble is there are very few such corresponding rights. Native titleholders may have rights offshore, but the question is how we define the way in which that is going to result in compensation being payable. Without actually deciding whether there are native title rights offshore the amendment provides that if there are any such rights and they are affected by government acts, and the native titleholders receive compensation, pursuant to clause 49 the compensation is just terms for any loss of their rights.

PARA.TAB: The addition of the expression `or waters' in paragraph 225(b) initially caused us some difficulties, but I think it makes sense. It means that native titleholders will receive cooperation for impairment of onshore water rights on the basis that they held ordinary title to the waters. For all those reasons we do support these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about these amendments, particularly as I do not believe the minister has given us any indication of their economic implications. The minister is accepting that it may be, in his view, a fairer system of compensatable rights. We were given these amendments late yesterday and we have not had the appropriate opportunity to have them checked. They may well have serious unintended consequences not only for the federal budget but also for the states and territories. In effect, the elevating of native title rights offshore to something greater than other interest holders can hold does have a very significant bearing.

PARA.TAB: I think it is worth pointing out that there are examples where mining leases could well be affected and could have their benefits attacked. This whole area of compensation payable is an example of what I call a sweetheart deal that has been done between the government and the Greens, and it will have very serious major consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling has probably rightly observed that this is one area in which we seem to be gaining some support from the government. I do not regard that as a sweetheart deal. I regard it as paying attention to the issue and dealing with it in an appropriate fashion. This bill, either by error or deliberately, removes or allows to be removed native title rights to waterways and fishing. This could have a drastic impact on coastal communities, particularly those in the south and east of the country which may have only those rights remaining to them.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is a matter of justice. It is not a question of having elevated any rights for native title claimants. It is simply a recognition that native title has a much more complex and detailed interpretation than that which we would apply to land. I think that ought to be recognised by this bill and it is inappropriate that it is not. I add that, in terms of the spirituality component of water rights, there are Aboriginal communities that have no land rights left. The only rights they have are those over water, which is a very spiritual place for them. I believe that it is in the interests of justice, and justice alone, that we are supporting this.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subclause 4 of clause 16 provides that compensation is payable by the Commonwealth in relation to these acts. Could the minister indicate his estimate of the extent of compensation that will be payable? What is the government's estimate of the time during which compensation will be payable; and what new taxes has the government in place to pay any compensation that might be determined to be payable?

PARA.TAB: Is any thought being given to a special tax to pay for this compensation? I suppose the answer depends upon the minister's estimate of what the compensation this clause provides for will cost. It is very relevant to all Australians to know the extent of that compensation, how much will be paid in the current financial year, how much next financial year and so on—and how the government proposes paying for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to Senator Ian Macdonald's question is that we do not expect the Commonwealth to be paying anything under this particular clause. This clause is about validation of past invalid acts. There is only a very limited number of areas where the Commonwealth itself has engaged in acts that might impinge upon native title. There might be the odd naval base or some particular context like that but this is not a clause which covers the whole compensation field. It is Commonwealth compensation payable in the context of validation of grants of interest that were originally invalidly granted by virtue of the operation of native title and the Racial Discrimination Act, or something of that kind. As I have constantly said to the Greens in response to these validation issues, they are not likely to feature at all prominently in the Australian continent as a whole. The answer is even less so in the context of Commonwealth validation.
—Has any assessment been done? Does the minister have any idea of numbers or possibilities?

—No, for the reason that I have suggested. I cannot think of any situation—nor can the advisers—where there is a prima facie suggestion that some Commonwealth act, particularly in the post-1975 period when the RDA has been in force, is likely to have generated an invalid title being granted which subsequently has to be validated in this way. Genuinely, the estimate is almost certainly likely to be zero but, nonetheless, to the extent that there is ever any such determination, we are the ones who obviously have to carry the can.

PARA.TAB: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Progress reported.

That seems appropriate. We have extended the dinner break to allow any senator who would like to leave the building to do so. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8)Clause 19, page 12, lines 1 and 2, omit subclause (3), substitute the following subclauses:

PARA.TAB: "(3) The native title holders may recover the compensation from the State or Territory.

TAB.EMPHASIS: States or Territories may create compensation entitlement

PARA.TAB: "(4) This section does not prevent a law of a State or Territory from creating an entitlement to compensation for a past act or for the validation of a past act.
Note:Paragraph 47(b) deals with the situation where there are multiple rights to compensation under Commonwealth, State and Territory laws.".

SPEECH.PARA: (10)Clause 22, page 13, subparagraph (4)(b)(iii), line 16, after "compensation", insert "to the native title holders".
(11)Clause 22, page 13, subclause (5), line 21, omit "compensation is payable by", substitute "native title holders may recover the compensation from".
(13)Clause 23, page 15, subclause (2), line 7, omit "compensation is payable by", substitute "native title holders may recover the compensation from".
(19)Clause 43, page 25, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2) If the act took place before 1 January 1994 and is attributable to the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, the native title holders may recover the compensation from the Commonwealth, the State or the Territory, as the case requires.".

SPEECH.PARA: (22)Clause 48, page 27, lines 4 to 14, omit subclauses (3) and (4).

This bundle of amendments is referred to in the running sheet as `Compensation Rights'. These are amendments to clauses 19, 22, 23, 43 and 48, and they are amendments Nos 8, 10, 11, 13, 19 and 22. They have all been circulated and are described in the explanatory memorandum.

PARA.TAB: I believe, from Senator Alston, that these amendments are uncontroversial in that they do not raise new policy issues. They are all essentially technical in character. For example—I will not go through them all—the amendment to clause 19 simply makes clear that the states and territories can provide their own right to compensation. If they do so, the states and territories are able to give jurisdiction to a body to determine the compensation for the validation of past acts and the making of future acts.

As a result of these amendments, the states will be creating their own entitlement to compensation. They will be able to vest tribunals and courts with jurisdiction to determine the compensation. If the right were to remain only a Commonwealth right and not be vested in the states in this way, jurisdiction could be given only to a federal or state court and could not be given to a recognised state body which is not a court. That is just an example of these essentially procedural provisions. As a result, I hope we might be able to dispose of them fairly swiftly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested to hear the government say that these are only technical amendments. I would agree—the substance still remains the same. Looking at the original clause 19 in the bill, we see that it imposes a liability on the states to pay compensation. In particular, we have clause 19(3). There is a constitutional principle that the Commonwealth cannot impose an undue burden on the states. So I think that aspect needs to be looked at carefully. A general principle was stated in the case of the Queensland Electricity Commission v. Commonwealth that:

SPEECH.PARA: A general law made within an enumerated power of the Commonwealth will be invalid if it would prevent a state from continuing to exist and function as such.

I believe, for this first reason, that this is an unwarranted intrusion into the states' functions, because it is saying to the states, `You will pay compensation for an act, even if you haven't validated it'. I know the wording has changed; the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) says now that it provides a right of recovery. I will come to that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: This is where I understand the minister to say that it is only a technical amendment. The difference is that, if we apply the appropriation principle—that is where the Commonwealth says to a state, `You will pay this money', and the state then has to go to its consolidated revenue and pay it out of that—the Commonwealth is forcing the states to appropriate moneys. I suggest that that is contrary to the constitution. This amendment has come about because the government has realised that it is imposing that unconstitutional burden on the states, so it has now said that it gives a right of recovery to the native titleholder. I believe that really is the same principle but expressed differently. The minister said that it was only a technical amendment, and I believe it is just that—it is a technical amendment, it is cosmetic and does not change the subject of the clause.

An interesting point was made by Mr C.E.K. Hulme QC and Professor Colin Howard, two of the witnesses who appeared before the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. They stated that, if we did take the track of saying that compensation would be the subject of recovery by a person, that could be just the same as saying that the state shall pay compensation. One merely has to look at the expectation that is created by the Commonwealth in reversing the wording. The expectation is that the native titleholder will claim compensation and will be able to. There is no question about it.

If the Commonwealth had drafted provisions allowing native titleholders to make a claim, that might be different, but in this clause it is rather bluntly put that the native titleholder `may recover the compensation' from the state or territory. In this case, the word `may' refers to whether they want to recover, not whether they have a right to recover. It is up to them; if they wish to, they can. That amounts to forcing the states to pay compensation.

Anyone who does not appreciate the importance of these constitutional provisions might think I am saying that native titleholders should not receive any compensation and that compensation should not be covered by this bill. I am simply saying that it should be catered for in accordance with our constitutional principles—and the Commonwealth cannot place an undue burden on the states by imposing on them a liability to pay compensation without offending the appropriation principle.

If this clause is to be workable, it will need rewording because I believe it contravenes the principles espoused in the first garnishee case. It is an aspect of this bill which could expose it to constitutional challenge—and successful constitutional challenge at that. As I have stated time and time again, it is no good passing legislation with a constitutional flaw because if it is struck down by the High Court it is of no use to anyone, no matter what end of the political spectrum people come from. That is why I place my objection to proposed new clause 19 on the record. I believe that the change is merely cosmetic and in no way changes the substance and effect of the clause.

My comments also relate to clauses 22 and 23, because the same theme runs through them. The government has recognised that it cannot impose on the states to pay compensation so it has twisted the wording around to say that the titleholder `may recover' compensation from the state or territory. By using different words it is hoping to escape the appropriation principle.

If this clause were to be struck down by the High Court as being bad at law because it contravenes the constitutional principle, that would go to something so essential that the whole bill would be unworkable. In light of other Commonwealth legislation, it could also be regarded as undue interference in the legitimate exercise of land management, which has been the preserve of the states since federation. The government would face great problems in the event of a challenge to this bill.

When we review legislation in this place, those are the sorts of points we must take into consideration. It is not good enough to simply let something pass, thinking it will do the job, if it is subsequently struck down. The Bankruptcy Act is cited as a classic example of a federal parliament—particularly the Senate—making a real mess of legislation. It certainly left the people of Australia in a sorry state of affairs. It was a classic example of legislation being passed without being properly thought through. That is the basic principle to which the opposition has adhered in its consideration of this bill.

There are amendments in this bill which some could argue are reasonable, but my answer to that is that it does not cure the basic defects of what is, to my mind, incompetent legislation and that really what is required here is total surgery and not the application of a couple of bandaids. That is really what we are looking at. We have already had clause 11 deferred, which seeks to impose, retrospectively, the common law on the states. Now, only eight clauses later, we have another basic constitutional principle being challenged. These are not light matters. They are very serious indeed, and ones which we have to have regard to.

If those ideals which are set out in the preamble are to be attained, they have to be attained by lawful means. A lot of people have said that this native title strives for justice; it strives to remedy many wrongs of the past. That may be all very well, but I say to the government that unless we get this bill right in the first instance, it will be of no use to anyone. That was what we said in the dissenting report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of which I was privileged enough to be a member and to see evidence given by 149 witnesses from Brisbane, Darwin, Perth and Canberra. It was only with a short, but thorough, analysis of the bill that I came to the view that there were just too many problems for this bill to be supported.

I can tell the chamber that all sorts of industrial groups and other interest groups have indeed pressured for a change in view and, for short-term relief, see that maybe some amendment is necessary to a few clauses. I believe that it would be hypocritical of me if I were to support some bandaid provisions which helped some interest groups and did not look seriously at other provisions as well which might be headed in the right direction. I take the consistent approach that this bill should be opposed because of the essential flaws that exist throughout it. I point to clause 19 as being one of those essential flaws.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rather suspect that Senator Ellison would not mind having the opposite brief when it came to justifying some amendments along the way to improve a bit of legislation that he thought was lousy. I will not put his feet to the fire on that one. I think I would prefer to have the other brief if I were him. Let us leave it at that.
—You worry about yourself; don't worry about us.

—I have long since ceased to worry about Senator Ian Macdonald. In relation to compensation rights, the language and substance of clause 19 have been called in issue quite apart from this amendment by Senator Ellison.

PARA.TAB: As to this change in the language from `The compensations payable by the State or Territory' to `The native titleholders may recover the compensation from the State or Territory', I think that is distinction without a difference. It is essentially stylistic, rather than substantive. It is not designed to conceal anything; it is just indicating a drafting preference for expressing this in terms of the rights of Aboriginal people rather than in terms of the liability of state governments, but it does not alter the substance.

As to the substance, I think it needs to be understood that all that is happening here is we are creating a right to compensation in circumstances where the states or territories choose to set in train validation exercises of their own. It is not imposing a compensation liability upon the states; it is simply saying that if they choose to go down this particular path—and state laws provide for the validation—then, under those circumstances, compensation should be able to be recovered from the state.

Perhaps I should say at the outset that here, as elsewhere, I think we are talking more about a theoretical possibility than a likely reality. We are talking about validation exercises of past invalid grants that have been made as a result of native title, together with the Racial Discrimination Act or something of that kind. As I have said now on innumerable occasions, we do not really think there are many, if indeed any at all, such cases which are likely to cause validation problems. Nonetheless, to get certainty to exclude the possibility of concern in this respect, we are providing this validation regime. We are providing, moreover, that not only can the Commonwealth do it in relation to Commonwealth areas, but the states can and should do it in areas that are within their own domain. That is the background.

As to the question of the suggestion that it is somehow unconstitutional to impose liability upon the states, there are a couple of points to be made. Firstly, I repeat this is not an imposition exercise; it is making plain that the compensation should be payable by the state if the states themselves do the validation exercise. There is some advantage in them clarifying the law themselves in this respect. The second point is that the suggestion in the opinion of my former colleague Dr Howard that there is some necessity for liability of the compensation of the bill to fall upon the Commonwealth is simply misconceived in our judgment. Our legal judgment is that the liability for compensation arising from validations falls on the government which is doing the validating.

Dr Howard's argument amounts to an argument essentially, as I understand it, that any invalidation of a grant by the Racial Discrimination Act amounts to an acquisition of an interest by the Commonwealth and thus requires the Commonwealth to pay compensation, not any government that might subsequently do the validating. This was not the view that was taken by the High Court in Mabo No. 1, where this issue was tested, and we have difficulty in accepting the proposition that he advances. The Commonwealth and the state and territory governments have all understood this issue very well from the outset. I do not think any of this will come as any surprise to them.

In the context of another one of these clauses—it raises the same sorts of issues—the purpose of the amendment to clause 33, in case one is minded to have reference to this at some future stage, is to simply provide that any liability arising under the RDA in the past will fall upon governments rather than individuals. It does not work as such to place a new burden on the states. In situations where the states set up their own tribunals or courts, the bill will enable native titleholders to pursue claims against the states for compensation. If they do not, they will not have that option.
