The suggestion by Mr Reith the other day, in the context of quoting Dr Howard's opinion, that the offer by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for the Commonwealth to contribute to state liabilities incurred through this validation process was a sleight of hand is not a categorisation that we would accept. We regard the states as genuinely having the liability to pay compensation if it is them that goes down the validation path. It is only them that can do it when we are talking about validation of state grants, for reasons we talked about before. But the Commonwealth has said that it will be prepared to help out. The most I can say publicly in this respect as to the scale of that helping out is what has already been said publicly by the Prime Minister—that is, that we will pay at least 50 per cent. That is a subject of further discussion and negotiation between the states and that certainly does not necessarily represent a final offer so far as the Commonwealth is concerned.

With the utmost of respect to Senator Ellison—I know he is approaching this whole issue in a reasonably serious minded way; he did serve on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and has been following the technical stuff pretty closely—I really think that the foundations of his argument are a little askew because they are premised on the assumption that there is an imposition of liability here and that is simply not the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) says that the state attracts this liability if it goes down a certain path—that is, validation. I understand that the government is not seeking to amend proposed subclause 19(2)—we have been dealing with proposed subclauses (3) and (4)—which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Native title holders are entitled to compensation for the past act attributable to a State or Territory that, at the time when the claim for compensation is determined, has not been validated by the State or Territory in accordance with section 18.
Does that mean that compensation applies whether or not there has been validation and whether or not the state has gone down that particular path? Is that what that implies?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sought clarification from the advisers on that point. It is describing a situation which I believe would probably apply even in the absence of this clause. Subclause 19(2) only bites in an area where there has been an invalid grant by a state as a result of the operation of certain provisions of various laws—the combination of native title with, for example, the Racial Discrimination Act.

PARA.TAB: The short point is that if, for whatever reason, a state act is declared or determined to be invalid by a court—as might conceivably happen if the states do not go down the path of legislative validation—under those circumstances, the state could be expected to pay compensation without any effort by the Commonwealth to impose a liability upon it.

I understand the point the honourable senator is making about subclause 19(2). It does not purport to be an appropriation from a state treasury; it does state that liability will accrue in these situations. But my instinct would be to say that that liability would accrue anyway to the states, quite apart from the existence of this subclause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the minister wants more time to confer with his advisers.
—I am just asking why we put it in there.

—That is the reason why I asked my question. I will ask another question and the minister can kill two birds with one stone. It will put the minister on notice for the second question. He says that this is not an appropriation, but if subclause 19(2) does impose a liability on the states—because it says that native titleholders are entitled to compensation—surely the payment of that compensation would have to come by way of appropriation from consolidated revenue. But the minister has just said that it is not by way of appropriation. I wonder whether the minister could answer that question as well. Surely, any time that a state has to pay compensation it will have to get it from consolidated revenue by way of appropriation.

—I am scratching my head to remember the relevant constitutional law principles. I think there is a difficulty about any Commonwealth law purporting directly to appropriate money, in effect, from a state treasury and to require that money be paid. That is a little bit different from a Commonwealth law which is otherwise within a head of constitutional power imposing a liability in relation to some subject matter of Commonwealth power. I suppose the argument here would have to be that the racial power would enable a liability to be created. Whether the state actually paid up in pursuit of that liability is a constitutionally different issue.

PARA.TAB: I am reminded that the Trade Practices Act and a lot of other Commonwealth legislation create liability on the part of the states in certain instances. That happens as an incident of Commonwealth law. So there is nothing particularly unusual from that point of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am proceeding on the principle that the Commonwealth does not have the legislative power to compel a state parliament to appropriate money to satisfy entitlements created under a law of the Commonwealth. With respect, it is my submission to the Senate that that is a constitutional principle of substance and this subclause offends that.

—In answer to Senator Ellison's earlier question, I am advised that the reason for proposed section 19(2) was to anticipate a situation where there had been some invalid act bearing upon inhibiting native title. This makes it clear that, in those circumstances, there does not have to be some further demonstration of impairment of native title by way of an act of trespass or something of that kind. The mere act of invalidly interfering or purporting to extinguish native title can itself create a liability. My instinct is to think that that would probably occur as a matter of the ordinary operation of basic legal principles rather than needing a statutory crutch of this kind, but it is a belt and braces exercise, I suppose, in that respect. I missed Senator Ellison's other question while I was sorting that out.

—I put to the minister that the principle I am proceeding under is that the Commonwealth does not have the legislative power to compel a state parliament to appropriate money to satisfy entitlements under a Commonwealth law. That is what I am saying this does. It does not say it is compelling, but the substance of it is that.

—I accept the possibility of what Senator Ellison says being correct. I do not know what the current state of High Court cases is. I am not yet in a position of having to do my reading in that respect—
—Oh!

—I hope Hansard records that as a joke. There is a difference between creating a liability, whether it is under the Trade Practices Act, the Native Title Bill or anything else, and actually having a piece of legislation purporting directly to bite upon a state treasury appropriation. One of course hopes that the interests of comity and otherwise would prevail and that the state treasury would be responsive to a Commonwealth law imposed liability. But it may be that that is so much an inherent state function that it cannot be the subject of application of a direct Commonwealth law. But they are separate and distinct issues conceptually and I think my recollection of the law is reasonably clear about that distinction.

—I hope the minister remembers his comments during this debate. If ever I am lucky enough to leave this honourable place and appear in the High Court, I might remind him of those comments. I refer now to clause 22. I take it we can refer to the clause and amendments in a cognate way. Is that the preferred option?
—Order! We are dealing with clause 19 at the moment.

—We are not, with respect, Mr Temporary Chairman. We are dealing cognately with all the amendments I have moved to a whole series of clauses. We started at the commencement of debate on this whole bill in the committee stage with an agreement that we do debate cognately and put together amendments on related subject matters. It is pursuant to that resolution at the outset of the committee stage that we are acting. With respect, Senator Ellison is perfectly entitled to do that and it will much expedite our proceedings if we can debate these things together. We are debating, in other words, simultaneously these six amendments to five different clauses.
—As I understand what you have just said, we are dealing with clauses 19, 22, 23, 43 and 48.
—Correct, in so far as they are sought to be amended by amendments 8, 10, 11, 13, 19 and 22. With a bit of luck, we will be able to put them all together quite soon.
—On that basis, you can address clause 22.

—I refer to amendment No. 10. There is an amendment of `to the native titleholders'. Was the insertion of that merely to clarify that compensation is payable to native titleholders only? Was that the point? It might be asking the obvious, but I just want to clarify that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is in the explanatory memorandum. I will read what I have. The intention of this technical amendment is to make it clear that the law referred to in that subparagraph does not provide for compensation to native titleholders. The bill gives compensation rights to native titleholders where, under the current law, those rights are available to ordinary titleholders. It becomes a little clearer if one looks at the parent provision. Clause 22(4)(b)(iii) says:

SPEECH.PARA: the law mentioned in section 225 . . . does not provide for compensation for the act;

It does not provide for compensation to native titleholders; it clarifies what kind of law is being referred to. The clause is a purely technical improvement that was suggested by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel or someone, because the way in which it was drafted was thought to be slightly less than clear. No content change is involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 23, as I understand it, operates as a clearance application. That is, a non-claimant applicant, someone who does not seek to have native title vested in him or her, may apply to have the register cleared as to native title. As I see it, even if the non-claimant applicant were to apply and there was no objection within two months, the tribunal could still make a determination on native title adverse to the non-claimant applicant. I ask the minister to confirm that or otherwise.
—I am advised that I can confirm what you are saying.

—Then, as I understand it, what this clause sets out to do in principle is a good idea. It means that if a developer comes along and wants to develop an area, he will have to find out whether anyone in the area claims native title. That all seems quite reasonable. So this clause says that a clearance application can be made and, if no-one objects within two months, it goes to the tribunal—the arbitral body—but it can still make a decision against that person. That still leaves the developer in a quandary. If he goes through the process of issuing the relevant notices and does not get any objections within two months, surely at that stage he could say that that is the end of it and would have the security to proceed with the development. But the application does not end there because it still goes through the tribunal process.

PARA.TAB: Whilst this is going on, developers are unable to finance projects because they are still not sure whether the final determination will be adverse or otherwise. I recall that some evidence given before a committee from some of the mining companies showed that this could prove to be a distinct problem, and it was not the panacea or the answer that people thought it would be. At the end of the day developers could still face adverse decisions, even though they have tried to clear the slate through this process. So that means that the clause is not efficient in that manner. It does not really answer the problem, and the developer who has not got an objector—someone who is claiming native title—still has to go over another hurdle. Consequential time delays are involved in getting that application approved.

The developer also has to go through state processes such as environmental impact statements and, in Western Australia, Aboriginal heritage impact statements, as well as a whole raft of state requirements. So there is an inordinate delay from the time when the developer decides to embark on a project to the day when he can finally get on with the job and develop it. I want to touch on the procedures in other areas dealing with determination of native title and determination of compensation and how that whole process can be drawn out to the complete disadvantage of any development or progress.

I want to focus on this clause, which is supposed to clear things up and allow a developer to get on with a job when no-one objects. If there is no objector, everyone would agree that that is all fine and good. In that case, why can a developer not go ahead? Why have the subsequent determination by the tribunal? Why not just leave it at the point of saying, `Issue your notice. If there is no objection within a certain period of time, that is it, you can go ahead, because no-one objects.'? The minister might like to comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that overstates the problem of having native title around when there is a valid grant of an interest, whether it is a mining interest or some other kind of interest. People with valid grants can go off and do their thing pursuant to that grant, and the existence of native title is not going to have much to impact upon them. In the case of a mining interest, for example, a subsequent determination that there was in fact some native title simply means that that native title will revive in its force and effect and have full force and effect after the period of the grant in question.As this provision and the related provisions are constructed, if the claimant wants to go down this path and put in the relevant application and after two months no-one comes forward to lodge a native title claim, then the act of the granting of the interest can take place and it will be valid. So there is that degree of certainty.

PARA.TAB: True it is, as Senator Ellison says, that even after that initial two-month period a claimant might come along and in due course establish the existence of a native title, but it will be against the background of a valid act having occurred and an interest having been validly granted. So the native titleholder who comes along after the event will have to wait—presumably some considerable time—before the determination of the existence of the native title is of any utility.

If the developer, or the miner, or whoever, wants absolute certainty that there is no native title impacting or likely to have any relevance at all to the area in question, he can wait for the completion of all the determination processes—a longer period than two months—but it is up to him whether he chooses to wait. Most people would be delighted to proceed on the basis of a guaranteed validity of the grant in question, which they are able to do after two months on the basis of no-one coming forward to lodge a claim. I think that is a pretty reasonable balance of the interests that are involved here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the minister's point about the validity of the act, but the problem is that if people think they are out of the woods and it was safe to go back into the water, so to speak, and a claim comes along—
—That's a psychological problem; it is not an economic problem.
—Financiers are quite sensitive people and they can have quite a few psychological problems in relation to financing projects.
—You are just going to have to get a bit better educated as to what the process is.

—There was a case put to us during the Senate committee of how one developer in a project was having to report weekly to his financiers as to the state of play in relation to this whole affair of native title. The financier was so nervous because hundreds of millions of dollars were involved and, of course, he did not want to see the investment go askew.

PARA.TAB: I will not go into the McArthur River project or things of that matter; I will leave that to others. But what about the situation where there is still the possibility of a compensation claim? That is the point that I am getting at. If there is an adverse ruling and then a claimant comes along at a later stage, the person who sets out to finance the project wants to take into account the possibility of compensation. What that person would like to do is say at the outset, `I have to raise X million for that, Y million for that and then a certain amount for compensation'. The person would do that at the outset and let the financier know what the story was. It strikes me that in this process the developer could be lulled into a false sense of security thinking that it is all clear and okay, when really it is not. One might then find the venture failing, which really would not be of much use to anyone.

It was also put in the course of the Senate inquiry that, if there is to be compensation payable, one wants to make sure that the compensation is there to be paid. If there is no certainty or assurances about the compensation payable, the developer cannot raise that money. The developer does not know how much is involved; there is that uncertainty.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that there might conceivably be compensation payable in the situation where people come along later on and establish that they do in fact have native title. But it is not payable by the project or by the developers; it is payable by government. It is payable in the case of an act attributable to the Commonwealth by the Commonwealth; and payable, in the case of an act attributable to a state or territory, by the state or territory. That is a very important distinction. I think a lot of these banks, financial institutions and businesses are generally behaving in a tremulous way at the prospect of native title being further recognised and accepted. They are not sufficiently understanding of what this legislation is all about. There is nothing there that will impose additional burdens or liabilities on the project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister might be able to explain the provisions of clause 22 (5) and who pays compensation, because we are dealing with permissible future acts. A clearance application is looking at a future act; we are looking at acts which occur in the future. Could the minister explain to me the rationale of that subclause, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The compensation is payable by:
(a) if the act is attributable to the Commonwealth:

PARA.TAB: (i) if a law of the Commonwealth provides, in the case of an act consisting of the doing of any thing at the request of a person, that the person is liable to pay the compensation—the person;

SPEECH.PARA: That very clearly spells out to me that the person concerned is liable to pay compensation. I understand that it might apply to the situation where a person has the government do something that is like a compulsory acquisition for the purposes of a development. I would be interested to have the minister's comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that the provision that Senator Ellison refers to in clause 22 is one of general application, but where we go down the path of the clearance application process in clause 23 the compensation is not payable by anyone else other than the relevant government. That is one of the reasons for putting this clearance provision in place—to create a mechanism whereby some more or less instant certainty can be generated and, in particular, some instant financial certainty in circumstances where that might be doubtful. That at least meets the point about which Senator Ellison is concerned.
—Can the government make a clearance application?
—I understand so, yes.

—As I understand it, the minister is saying that, once the developer is through the notification and lack of objection stage, even if there is a determination adverse to the developer as to native title, the developer is out of the woods, completely clear, with no other liability to worry about. Is that what the minister is saying?
—That is my understanding and that is my advice.
—The payment by the government would be another instance where, conceivably, a state would have to pay from the consolidated revenue?
—We are back to the argument we had before, but there is a difference between the imposition of liability and the purported obligation to appropriate, and this is the former.
—Clause 22 is headed, `Permissible future acts'. Could the minister explain the circumstances in which a permissible future act will be invalid?

—It is a matter of applying the freehold test so described in the legislation. If the grant is made over native title land and it is not a grant that could have been made over freehold land, then it will be invalid to the extent that it purports to apply to native title. It is the freehold equivalence test, in the sense that one cannot do anything over native title land that one cannot do over land held by freehold. It is not the same thing as saying that native title is equivalent, in all other respects, to freehold. I am not saying that at all. It is just applying that freehold test. Those are the circumstances in which a future act would be invalid.

—I apologise for the lack of order; I have jumped around a bit. Clause 22(5) deals with compensation. Can the minister give the chamber some examples of where the person concerned would be liable to pay compensation? Up to now we have been talking of the state or Commonwealth government paying compensation. In a prior answer the minister gave, he said that subclause 5 was a general application, and I think that he conceded that there were cases where a person could have to pay the compensation. Can he give us an example?

—Clause 22(5)(a)(i) is in a context where the act is done at the request of a person. My understanding is that most mining acts do in fact have this kind of character, and that is an example of the most usual situation where compensation would be payable by the miner rather than by the government.

—Would that subclause cover a situation where a person wished to operate a tourist facility and needed the government to compulsorily acquire the property with a view to then leasing it to the person wanting to operate the tourist facility? The person is then asking the government to compulsorily do the act. In that case, would the person be liable for compensation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short point is that the law of the state so provides. Paragraph 22(5)(b) states:

PARA.TAB: (i) if a law of the State or Territory provides, in the case of an act consisting of the doing of any thing at the request of a person, that the person is liable to pay the compensation—

SPEECH.PARA: If the act providing for compulsory acquisition sets out—and I do not know whether any of them do—in terms of the process that Senator Ellison is talking about, that if a compulsory acquisition proceeds at the request of a person and compensation is payable, then under those circumstances, the person who makes the request pays the compensation. It is only if the state law were to be set up in that way that compensation would be payable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the same for the Commonwealth government? The minister mentioned a state, but I am just—
—I was reading from paragraph 22(5)(b). Subclause 22(5) states:

PARA.TAB: (a) if the act is attributable to the Commonwealth:
(i) if a law of the State or Territory provides, in the case of an act consisting of the doing of any thing at the request of a person, that the person is liable to pay the compensation—

SPEECH.PARA: Under those circumstances, that pay person pays the compensation. The law has to set out that chain of liability.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that, but if this subclause is of no great moment, as it would seem—perhaps I am not understanding the minister correctly—why have it there anyway? If there is very little application for it, why provide for the person paying compensation in any event?

—I did not say there was not much call for payment of compensation so far as future acts are concerned. This is one of the main contexts in the future in which compensation will be payable. The context in which I have said that not much compensation is likely to be payable is where we are talking about the validation of invalid past acts. Where we are talking about future acts that impinge upon native title, someone somewhere will have to pay some compensation. These provisions are all about working out whom.

PARA.TAB: In this provision of general application in clause 22, if the act impairing the native title is done at the request of a person—by the state or the Commonwealth, as the case may be—and if the law of the state or the Commonwealth so provides, then it is the person in question that makes that request who has to pay the compensation. This will have some general application in the future because this is what the bill is all about. The main thrust of the bill is making provision for the future. Only a very small part of the bill, although a disproportionate amount of attention has been paid to it, relates to validations of past acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the minister give us typical examples of permissible acts within the category of low impact future acts? Does he have any?

—Camping is one. I am advised that beekeeping is another. Car rallies might be another one. Sporting events and orienteering are others. There are some definitions in the bill—the relevant clause is 219—and I seem to recall that there are some examples in the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 22(6), which deals with procedural rights, states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of any act to which this section applies (other than a low impact future act or one to which Subdivision B applies), the native title holders have the same procedural rights as they would have in relation to the act on the assumption that they instead held:

PARA.TAB: (a)to the extent that the act is in relation to an onshore place—ordinary title to any land concerned and to the land adjoining both sides of, or surrounding, any waters concerned . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It then mentions offshore rights. As I understand it, that equates procedural rights to freehold rights. I understand that freehold titleholders have the right to receive written notice of any act which may be adverse to their interests, such as an acquisition of land. I have two questions. Firstly, does the minister agree that the procedure here is the same as for a freehold landowner? If it is, how does the government envisage getting over the problems with notice? I am looking at notifying groups of indigenous people, perhaps in a remote area, where they certainly would not have an address or a postcode or post box. Secondly, If the same procedure is to be applied, how does one go about notifying them?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison is right in setting up the question in the way that he did. The notice situation may well be required. But there are several ways that that is facilitated by the way the bill is constructed. One is through the creation of the register of claimants to land in question. Another is through the requirement for the establishment of a body corporate in the case of completed determinations. We will have some later provisions about bodies corporate, making clear, as I foreshadowed yesterday, that it is optional as to whether one vests the title itself in the body corporate or just has the body corporate playing an agent role. One way or another, the body corporate exists as a vehicle in this respect.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, clause 22(7) sets out ways in which notification may be given in circumstances of the kind that Senator Ellison referred to where that might be physically difficult. Notifying, in a way determined in writing by the Commonwealth minister, any representative bodies for the area concerned is one such example in subclause 7(c). There are plenty of ways that are quite practicable and feasible for that sort of notice to be given.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is proposed to amend this bill in relation to bodies corporate though, is it not?

—That amendment was meant to be circulated an hour or so ago. I do not know what has happened to its reproduction. It is quite a complicated series of amendments. There is a page of explanatory material associated with that, but the effect of it is exactly as I described yesterday—creating an option as to whether we actually vest the title itself in the body corporate or rather just have the body corporate as an agent. But that structure will be made clear in the terms of that amendment when it comes.

—The problem that I have there is that if we had the title vesting in the individuals—I think the Greens have an amendment to that effect—the body corporate would not necessarily be relevant. In some cases it would be groups of individuals, family groups, who would be claiming native title. This implies, as I understand the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), that we would be notifying bodies corporate, but that would not cover the family groups who might not have any interest in the body corporate or who might be opposed to the body corporate.

PARA.TAB: In the course of the Senate committee hearing it became apparent that a good many witnesses from the Aboriginal community were not keen on having title vested in a corporation. If the Greens' amendment were accepted, individuals could have title and, therefore, bodies corporate would be irrelevant. I feel that there is a problem here in that the minister says, `We can do it in a number of ways; we will try to cover it as best as possible because we will just notify ATSIC bodies and corporate bodies in the area'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Notifying any occupier of any land; placing notice.
—The minister did say corporate bodies and that is why I took him up on it.
—But there are other ways too.

—The question is who will determine which group gets the notice or who is entitled to get the notice. Quite legitimately, in accordance with any claim for native title, some traditional titleholders do not continuously stay in one place and could well move. If we looked in a particular area, we could find that they are not there for that period and so are overlooked. That is a real problem.

PARA.TAB: In the far north-west of Western Australia, there are some very remote areas. In those places, notice cannot be advertised or nailed on the town hall, thereby giving constructive notice, as we often do in our civil law by placing advertisements in newspapers. Recently I was up around Marble Bar, and that is pretty remote territory. It is all very well for the government to say that it will give notice, but does the Commonwealth government have a better idea as to how to put that into practice?

TALK.START.PARA: —All will be revealed when honourable senators see government amendment No. 75, which relates to the body corporate. I wish that amendment had been circulated. I thought that it had gone around an hour or two ago. I thought that it would be some time before we reached it and, therefore, there was no great urgency, but it should have been circulated. If that could be followed up, I would be very grateful.

PARA.TAB: One of the characteristic features of native title is that there are rights held by a group. The content of the group changes over time. To provide for dealings with native titleholders—native title rights—we have always believed that there is a need for a corporate body to be the contact point for dealings with native title. For that reason, there will continue to be a requirement for a corporate body to be established to represent native titleholders. What will be optional is whether titleholders will be able to have their native title rights held on trust by that body. They can make the decision as to whether they want their rights held on trust by the body corporate or whether they just want the body corporate to be an agent in effect for their dealings.

That is the process, that is the theory, that is the concept that will be set out in full in that series of amendments covered by government amendment 75. The provisions in subclause 7 of clause 22 about public notification or notification of a land council are more designed to deal with situations where, as 7B says, there has been as yet no approved determination of the native title. But, nonetheless, there is a reasonable belief that there are native titleholders out there.

We have to remember that native title does not have to wait to be enjoyed for determination. It does exist right now as a matter of common law. There may be native titleholders out there in particular remote parts of the country where miners perhaps want to establish new projects and where it is necessary for them to adopt some notification process. If we have not yet got to the stage of a body corporate being established to act as the representative or the agent of the titleholders which will make notification very easy, then we will use some of these alternative mechanisms that are set out in clause 22. I hope that is sufficiently clear at least to hold the line until we later get to the discussion of bodies corporate.
I have just been advised that, for whatever reason, the Table Office only received a few minutes ago the body corporate amendment. It will be circulated during the dinner break.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ineptitude.

—The body corporate amendment is not one that we are expected to get to—Senator Bishop is having a little frisson over there—on the present rate of progress to about next Wednesday morning. There is ample opportunity to consider it.
—Good management would be to have it deferred to February and you know it.
—Do not glare at me and carry on. Thank God Senator Bishop will be out of this place quite soon. It will be a great mercy to us all.
—Fragile little petal, aren't you.
—You come in here like a lighted match to petrol.

I will now refer to clause 21. I think it is tied up with clauses 22 and 23 and we did say that we would deal with intervening clauses as well. Are there any circumstances in which an impermissible future act can be carried out? On the face of it, that would not appear to be so.
—Do you mean carried out without any adverse consequences attached to it or whether it can be physically carried out?
—Carried out in accordance with this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Things can always be carried out but if they are carried out it will be invalid by virtue of the operation of clause 21 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to sections 23 and 24, if an act is an impermissible future act, the act is invalid to the extent that it affects native title.
Clauses 23 and 24 spell out the consequences that flow from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He got it wrong.

—I am advised that there are some exceptions to section 21 and I am trying to find out what they are. One obvious example is the one we were talking about earlier, where we get a pre-emptive application by a non-applicant. In order to clarify the situation, if there is no response to the notification within the two month time period before the act takes place, it is then valid, notwithstanding there is a native title claim which is subsequently recognised. What would otherwise be an impermissible act—that is, the granting of the interest in question—becomes permissible and becomes valid by virtue of the pre-clearance process that we previously discussed. That is a clear example because Senator Ellison was startled earlier on to realise the extent of the utility of that particular clause. That is good demonstration of it.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—The question is that clause 19, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need some clarification, Mr Temporary Chairman. In the section called clause 19 on the running sheet, there are some amendments in the Greens' section. We have agreed to drop three of the four but I did want to present amendment No. 18 which is in that section even though it relates to clause 47. I would like permission to do that. I do not know whether to do it before we consider clause 19 or after. Now is the time?
—Now is the time. It is one of the things that are being debated cognately.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 47, page 26, lines 29 and 30, omit paragraph (a), substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: "(a) compensation is only payable under this Act for damage or loss caused by an act if the damage or loss has not otherwise been compensated; and".

The government has told me that it is not planning to support this and I am not sure whether the Democrats are. Amendment No. 18, which is an amendment to clause 47A, is about the fact that there is no multiple compensation for essentially the same act. This amendment provides that compensation may only be paid for loss or damage which has not otherwise received compensation. This is a fairer test than whether or not the act giving rise to the compensation is essentially the same. The amendment conforms more closely with the general law on compensatory damages.

PARA.TAB: I will explain it. When judging whether the act is the same: if the act inflicts on a multiple number of people, somebody is going to be penalised by that, or the first person to gain the compensation will gain it and any subsequent people who suffer from the same act will not. Whereas, if we turn it around and say that compensation cannot be paid over and over again for the same act, that means that nobody is penalised. So the purpose of this amendment is as an exercise in fairness and in looking at increasing the level of fairness of compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty is that the government feels that Senator Chamarette's amendment would operate to prejudice the capacity of Aboriginal people and native titleholders in certain circumstances. I am advised to that effect. I am not entirely sure why that is so. I am in the process of sorting that out. I had not expected Senator Chamarette to move that amendment.
—That is a persuasive argument—you are advised about it, but you don't understand it.

—There are occasions in the course of this legislation when one can be taken by surprise. I had not expected this amendment to come. It is a minor drafting point but, in the way the bill is framed at the moment, it says that `compensation is only payable once for acts that are essentially the same'. That is the language of the bill. The language proposed by Senator Chamarette is that `compensation is only payable under this act for damage or loss caused by an act, if the damage or loss has not otherwise been compensated'.

PARA.TAB: We think that operates in a way that makes it possible for compensation to be restricted and not payable in circumstances in which it might otherwise be payable if our clause were to be accepted. What our clause focuses on is acts that are essentially the same. People can only be compensated once for acts that are essentially the same, but with acts that are not essentially the same, they can be compensated more than once. It is a technical drafting point.

This amendment was an attempt on the part of the Greens to improve the legislation. We do not think it does that. We are concerned that at the margin it might conceivably have a restrictive effect. I cannot put it any more clearly than that until I focus a little more carefully on it than it is possible to do while I am standing on my feet and talking. However, that is the nature of the concern that we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. It is very difficult. I do not want to present an amendment that will damage anybody, but I have not really understood the argument of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). It is our understanding that this is a fairer way by which people may be compensated because it focuses on the damages being paid only once—and, obviously, we do not want them to be repetitively paid—rather than the similarity of the act being taken into account.

PARA.TAB: I cannot see how our `acts' will impair that, whereas the government's phrasing does mean that it would be possible that no multiple compensation would be paid for essentially the same act. That could deprive people who are suffering from the same act—because there are multiple sufferers from that at different times—from gaining legitimate access to compensation. I hope I have spoken for long enough to enable advice to be given to clarify this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another example of how the government's response to amendments moved by senators, in this case by Senator Chamarette, my colleague from Western Australia, is in total disarray. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has said that he cannot respond. We understand his difficulty. He is being advised. He is doing this on the run. Again, it is a reflection on the process that we are undertaking here. The government is trying to move this through before Christmas. It is the first time we have sat on a Saturday in 34 years. The last time was when I was a six-month-old baby, and I cannot remember it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette has made a genuine attempt to try to correct the legislation. The Minister for Foreign Affairs is, as we witness, conferring hurriedly with advisers. He is not even listening to me, and he is unable to provide any sort of detailed or sensible response to Senator Chamarette's motion. It would not amaze anyone who is listening to the proceedings of the Senate or who is reading the Hansard later, that members of the opposition who wanted a select committee, who wanted this bill dealt with in February and not rushed in before Christmas, make the point yet again that this is a totally unsatisfactory process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am having the greatest difficulty, I am afraid, in understanding the difference between Senator Chamarette's amendment and the parent clause, and why Senator Chamarette thinks there is any advantage for Aboriginal people in putting the clause in the way that she does. I understand that with the way our clause is drafted—and, in particular, given the effect of (b)—there is no possible way in which people can be inhibited.
—I wish to move that we postpone this to a later stage in the committee, when the minister has had time to take advice on that, rather than waste time now in this apparent confusion.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Senator Ellison, I think it might be more appropriate if you were to suggest that after the minister has finished speaking, because he was in the middle of explaining to Senator Chamarette what the government's position is.

TALK.START.PARA: —He might wish to conclude his explanation later.

—As I realised, this is presenting a problem and, as I do not think we have got the numbers to win on this amendment in any case, I am prepared either to defer it or to let it just be voted on by voices.
—No; you have the numbers for a postponement.
—Have I? All right; I move:

PARA.TAB: That further consideration of the amendment be postponed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That clause 19, as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—I propose now to call on clauses 20 and 21.

TALK.START.PARA: —We deferred further consideration of the Greens' amendment 18, but I think it might be possible to resolve that issue now if we bring it back on—if the Greens are content with that. I ask if Senator Chamarette is happy to bring amendment 18 back on.
—Yes, I am happy to have consideration of amendment 18 resumed.

—I am sorry, I was caught a little by surprise by this amendment and it was a little bit difficult to untangle the technicalities in the time available. What it amounts to, if I can put it very succinctly, is that, under the existing clause 47 as it is presently drafted, if a native titleholder were to get compensation under a state law provision and then come to the Commonwealth tribunals, courts, seeking further compensation, then it is provided that the Commonwealth will take that into account. Commonwealth tribunals can give compensation only once for acts that are essentially the same but there is no total prohibition on giving compensation again if it has been given in a different system under a different legal regime.

PARA.TAB: So that is what we provide in the existing clause 47. What amendment No. 18 would achieve is something that really rather undercuts that. The Greens amendment provides that if compensation is obtained under a state regime, from a state tribunal, then it cannot, whatever the circumstances, be obtained at all under a Commonwealth tribunal, under the operation of Commonwealth law, even if the state compensation already received is manifestly inadequate. That is the essence of it. A dollar's compensation might be obtained under the state law and the Commonwealth tribunal might think that the compensation is worth a million dollars, but the way the Green amendment is formulated no additional compensation at all can be obtained under the Commonwealth regime if compensation has been received anywhere else in the system under any legal system.

It is because of our concern that this particular provision might operate—no doubt, in a way that was utterly unintended by the Greens—in a way that would actually prejudice Aboriginal rights that we were concerned about it. It is quite a narrow technical point and a very close reading of the clauses in question is necessary to appreciate the point in issue. But I hope it will be understood that that is the nature of our concern, and that is the reason why we think the Green amendment No. 18 ought not to be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can just clarify. I am sorry, but the aspect of the amendment the minister is referring to is section B of clause 47 and that is essentially unchanged, whether it is the Green amendment or the government's initial version of the clause, so it is not actually that that makes the difference; it is the difference between the phrase `compensation is only payable under this Act once for acts that are essentially the same' and our amendment which has: `compensation is only payable under this Act for damage or loss caused by an act if the damage or loss has not otherwise been compensated;'. It does not affect whether it is a state or a Commonwealth agency.

PARA.TAB: However, I do not think it is a big issue. I just wanted to clarify that. I have had advice that, essentially, it is a drafting problem and it could be interpreted similarly for the courts and not disadvantage anyone either way and I am not prepared to push it and delay any further. We would have liked it supported but we are happy to do it on the voices and we still support our own amendment but, as we have not got the numbers, we will leave it there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette, do you wish leave to withdraw that particular amendment? Will we just do it on the voices?
—Yes.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Clauses 20 and 21.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the minister confirm that, apart from a few minor exceptions such as offshore and low impact activities, the essential effect of clause 21, apart from once again attempting to ensure that state legislation is not able to interfere with the native title regime, is that a tribunal can effectively prevent almost any form of action with land, such as the granting of new pastoral leases, changes to freehold mining leases and lesser forms of grant, including subdivisions?

—I am not sure that anything in 21 is to do with any capacity of the tribunals to influence the course of events. What is involved is the application of the freehold principle that you cannot do to native title holders what you cannot do to freeholders. That is the principle that runs through the operation of 21 and the definition of impermissible future acts. I am not sure that I understand Senator Alston's point to operate differently from what I have just said.
—In the sense that there is very little that you can do to freehold, presumably there is very little you can do to native title land in that respect.
—There is very little you can do without paying compensation or some other—
—So the end result is that it allows the tribunal to make all the judgments about the various forms of interference with land.

It only allows the tribunal to determine what native title is, its extent and boundaries. In the case in question, certain consequences follow from that, but they are not specifically determined by the tribunal.

—We are now getting into that aspect of the act where the rights of the states are being greatly interfered with, in that the right to manage their land—as determined by the constitution—is being interfered with or taken away. I think taken away is probably the better term there. What happens in the situation where a state government wants to grant a pastoral lease or a number of new pastoral leases over vacant crown land? Can the state governments grant that, as they have done in the past, or does this part of the legislation before us stop that?
—I am not sure that I understood that question.
—The granting of pastoral leases has been the right of the various state governments. Does this clause prevent the state government from doing that?

—I think the short point is this: state governments cannot grant leases over freehold land that is occupied as such by people enjoying freehold title. To that extent, since the test is a freehold, so far as native title is concerned, state governments will not be able to grant such leases over native title because the same test will be applied. So that is an inhibition but that is something that follows from the recognition by the High Court of the proprietary interest of native titleholders.

—I think Senator Evans has just told us that the fundamental right of the states to manage their land, and the granting of titles, and what has traditionally been the situation as far as land management is concerned, has now been usurped by the Commonwealth.
—No, no, not by the Commonwealth.
—Yes, it has.
—No, by the High Court.
—This is a statute.
—This is an act of parliament. Does the Mabo 2 decision prevent the states from having the right to grant title?
—Yes.
—How?

—Where states purport to grant title over land which is occupied by people enjoying an existing common law right to native title, then the state grant that is made from now on in will be invalid to that extent, or written down to that extent. That is the effect of the High Court decision. All that this statutory scheme does is to create a framework within which these competing rights and issues can more rationally be sorted out.

—I am sorry, I think the minister is right off the beat and the beam. The fact is that a response to Mabo does not require the Commonwealth to take away its legal right to grant title and manage land, and I would like to know under what constitutional power the government is doing this and what areas of the constitution it is in conflict with.

—I suppose it is fair to say, going back a notch, that Mabo makes it clear that the states can act to extinguish native title, sure, but certain consequences flow from that as a result of the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act, including in particular the need to pay compensation. Any state going down that path from now on has to confront that inhibition, and that is as a result of the exercise of Commonwealth constitutional power, the race power that gives the Racial Discrimination Act that life, that effect.

PARA.TAB: It is also true that what we are seeking to do in this legislation, again relying on the constitutional authority the Commonwealth has to protect Aboriginal people using the 51(xxvi) race power, is to avoid a situation in the future where such extinguishment of native title can occur in a willy-nilly fashion, as it has in the past. The Commonwealth makes no apology for that. This is really what this legislation is all about, seeking to ensure that decisions of this kind that are made in the future are made with a much more sensible appreciation of their impact on native title than has occurred in the past.
There may be a policy difference between us about that basic aspect of the legislation, but there ought not to be any misunderstanding that that is what is involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has mentioned 51(xxvi), which I think he called the race power in terms of the constitution, and he is saying that the government is using that particular part of the constitution to have this act stand up. How does that relate to the constitutional rights of the states to grant and handle land title? I would question very deeply what he is saying in his answer, that one part of the constitution can override another part of the constitution. The part of the constitution that deals with the management and handling of land is specific in terms of what it can do. How does the minister expect this portion of the act to stand up against constitutional challenge, or is the government deliberately going down a course knowing full well that this is going to end up in the High Court?

—We have already debated this. The short point is this: nothing in the constitution enables the Commonwealth to legislate with respect to the subject matter of state land management as such. However, there are certain heads of Commonwealth power. The external affairs power is one of them, under which the Racial Discrimination Act was passed. The race power under 51(xxvi), which is the main support for this legislation, is another. These heads of power enable the Commonwealth to act in various ways in this context to protect native title, to protect the interests of Aboriginal people. To that extent it may have an incidental impact at the margin on the states' capacity to fully exercise their land management powers, but that is in the nature of a Commonwealth constitution which vests overriding powers in the Commonwealth. To the extent that things are within the Commonwealth's constitutional capacity, to that extent the Commonwealth can intrude in areas that are otherwise wholly the prerogative of the states.

PARA.TAB: So, as I said before, the Commonwealth, under the constitution, cannot get into the business of granting mining title; the Commonwealth cannot get into the business of granting pastoral title in the states. The Commonwealth can, however, get in the business of protecting Aboriginal interests in these particular areas and of establishing liability to pay compensation, and so on, to the extent that those interests are interfered with, or impaired. So that is the balance that is struck; but that is the balance that is within the very text of the constitution. It is not something that we are inventing for the first time in the context of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the consequence of this that a pastoral lease cannot be granted over native title, even where the native title is a lesser form—in other words, rights of hunting, foraging, traversing—so that the end result is that there is very little that can be done other than by permission of the tribunal?

—(Victoria—Minister for Foreign Affairs) (8.36 p.m.)—If the pastoral lease in question does not in terms affect the exercise of the native title, it can be granted. The problem is, the inhibition is, in granting a pastoral lease to the extent that it adversely impacts on native title. If the two are capable of living together, they can be granted conterminously in the future, and there are some kinds of pastoral lease that do not involve absolutely exclusive occupancy; there are some kinds of pastoral lease that may involve exclusive occupancy, because they carry with them some statutory reservation that might enable some enjoyment of some residual component of native title rights. That is possible. But the basic situation remains that, under the legislation, native title rights are to be construed as having the same effect in law as freeholder rights, just as, under the present law, no government can grant an interest over land that is occupied by existing freeholders. So too, under this law, native title interests cannot be overridden.

PARA.TAB: It is all a function of just whether or not honourable senators are prepared to give weight and value and substance to native title. If they are not, if they regard this as some latter day invention of the High Court in a way that is not to be taken seriously, not to be respected, not to be valued, then honourable senators will respond in the way that they are. If honourable senators regard the recognition by the High Court of native title, if they regard the overturning of terra nullius as being one of the outstanding feats in our jurisprudential history of at last giving some recognition to proprietary rights which should have been recognised in the past but have not been and now are for the first time and, if honourable senators are prepared to give weight and value and substance and respect to those proprietary rights, then they should not be prepared to argue for the cavalier overriding of those rights in a way that has been the norm in the past.

If there are inhibitions on the extent to which those rights can be overridden, honourable senators should be applauding that as for the first time getting a little bit of justice back in the system. Honourable senators should be applauding the fact that, for the future, those rights will be given weight and value and respect, whatever the injustice has been in the past, and whatever the irreversible injustice may be. We cannot unwind the past, to the extent that those rights have been overridden in the past; we simply cannot in the interests of the economy of this nation and the interests of all the other Australians who have economic interest that would otherwise be under assault under these circumstances in relation to grants that were given in total good faith in the past. We cannot overturn that; we cannot override that. But we can get it right for the future. Let us try, in a spirit of reconciliation and a spirit of understanding of the justice of the claim in question, to get it right for the future and not carp and not harp and not try to whittle away and reduce or demean the value of the rights that have been, for the first time, recognised by the High Court. That is what this is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct some questions regarding problems with the practical application to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). I will take as my first example the development at the Ord River in Western Australia, which I am sure he is familiar with. I am sure that his advisers would be well aware that this is an area which is affected greatly, in a lot of ways, by this act. Can the minister describe to us the process by which further development can occur at the Ord River with the expansion of the irrigation scheme which started 15 or so years ago there? How does the state of Western Australia get or allocate land there so that there can be economic development of that area? Of course, that development will provide jobs.

—There are at least three ways that I can think of straight off. One is by compulsory acquisition, which is clearly still provided for under this legislation. A second is by the testing by a non-claimant of the status of the proposed land in question, as to whether or not there are any claims around. If, in the absence of such a claim being asserted within two months of the notice being given, a grant is made, then that grant will be valid, come what may—a thing that we discussed earlier on. A third way in which land acquisition can occur is by way of agreement.

PARA.TAB: You will recall that in the preamble—with the encouragement of the Senate committee report which dealt with this issue and made recommendations—there was a proposal that regional agreements be entered into, to accommodate competing interests having to sort themselves out in the future. So, in at least those three ways—and maybe there are others as well—the game can be moved forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that situation, the minister suggested three ways by which it could be done. In that particular case, if the state compulsorily acquires that land for that purpose, does that extinguish native title?

—With the way in which the legislation is drafted at the moment, it does. There is an amendment that we will be dealing with later on, during this debate, which suggests that the extinguishment of native title ought not to actually be accomplished until such time as the public purpose for which the acquisition is set in train actually occurs. I have some sympathy for that amendment, and the government is currently considering its position on it. It is likely that, if the drafting makes sense, we will be to accommodate that.

PARA.TAB: This is another way of making clear that, while we perfectly respect and accept the states' rights in relation to land management to be able to compulsorily acquire land for the state for public purposes, we remain a little bit suspicious about that right being exercised in a way that operates to the detriment of Aboriginal people but does not simultaneously serve some other obvious public purpose. We are a bit opposed, and I can well understand the argument of those who worry about warehousing exercises, to employing the notion of compulsory acquisition but without any real intention or effect to convert it to the public purpose in question. So I think it might be possible for us to modify some of the rigour of the legislation in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any restrictions on the states' resumption law, and what is the definition of a compulsory acquisition act?

—What clause is Senator Crane referring to? We are talking here about compulsory acquisition of a normal, familiar kind under existing state legislation or under Commonwealth legislation. But there is a definition that puts that beyond doubt, on page 112 of the bill in the definition of clause 238.
—Can the tribunal refuse to approve a state application for acquisition in a similar situation—again, as in the Ord?

—No, it is not a matter for tribunal determination. Under the scheme of this legislation, the states will always retain the capacity to compulsorily acquire for public purposes. The only qualification of that that we are contemplating is the one that I mentioned—that the public purpose in question actually has to proceed. If it is a purported acquisition but no actual public purpose is executed, then there may be a case for putting the effect of it on hold until the public purpose is worked out.

PARA.TAB: There is also a further qualification, of which I am reminded, which follows from clause 25 and onwards, to the effect that where the compulsory acquisition is undertaken on behalf of a third party, rather than for public purposes, but for the purposes of a third party—for example, a commercial interest—then the requirements for negotiation and all the other provisions in the legislation are triggered. That is a way of moving the exercise forward but, if a particular project is to be pursued by a state in an area occupied by native title, there are certain consequences that flow from that in terms of requirement to negotiate. What is not intended is that there be any inhibition, whatsoever, of the traditional state compulsory acquisition powers to establish whether the purpose is for recreation reserves, particular state public works or for any other purpose. There ought to be no inhibition, and none is imposed by this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question relates to the use of the acquisition powers. In terms of the application, are there any different requirements with regard to a different title that might result from that—for example, freehold, perpetual lease, a normal lease as now exists in many places or even a conditional purchase lease?

—I am not sure whether the honourable senator is talking about restrictions on the nature of the title that is being acquired, or restrictions on what can be done with it when it has been acquired, if it is a state. If he is talking about the latter, there are no restrictions. Land acquired for a public purpose can be dealt with by a state for whatever purpose it chooses, in accordance with ordinary state legislation that governs this. There is quite voluminous legislation in every jurisdiction. But there is no particular inhibition on the kinds of titles, in turn, that can be granted by the state once it has acquired the land for the legitimate purpose in question.

—So I have it absolutely clear: with the situation where the land is acquired, the state then has the absolute right to determine whether that becomes leasehold, perpetual lease or freehold. There is no restriction, whatsoever?
—That is my understanding of the way in which the law operates in every state at the moment. There is no intent, whatsoever, to inhibit that.

—I would like to ascertain from the minister, under the principles that he has just enunciated with regard to acquisition, if they apply equally and consistently with the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory?
—That is my understanding, yes.

—I have a question on temporary pastoral leases, which do occur. Western Australia has the highest percentage of vacant crown land—about 40 per cent. In years of extreme drought, which we hope do not come round too often, the state government issues temporary pastoral leases to get over the very bad period—they may last only six months. If I can remember, from my local government days, they were issued for six months. They would then be looked at the next year and when the lease expired, the stock came off.
—You are talking about otherwise vacant crown land?
—Yes, that is on vacant crown land, otherwise it would not be available, would it?
—No, that is right.

—Okay. In this situation there are prescribed criteria to go through to be able to take land, and people would not know whether it was going to be a native title claim or not. Can the minister tell me whether the drought situation could be over before the temporary pastoral lease was even granted?

—Let me inform Senator Panizza that the big problem is that now what was previously vacant ground land might conceivably turn out to be occupied by native titleholders. That is a new phenomenon which states have got to come to grips with. That is the problem. The old terra nullius thing has been swept away and we now have got the possibility, for the first time, there might just turn out to be some native titleholders hanging around. So that has got to be taken into account before any interests of this kind might be granted. If it is a very temporary pastoral lease, maybe this will be a low impact act—a bit like beekeeping or camping or an extended picnic or a car rally or one of those things. That might be a very reasonable way of interpreting something of that kind. The land in question is not being permanently dealt with, as I understand it, it is being used as a buffer zone for a particular period. That might well be an appropriate way of characterising it.

PARA.TAB: If, as often happens, temporary things turn out to have a greater degree of permanence about them and interests of native titleholders are thereby being impaired in some really significant way, I think we would be forced into going down one or other of the routes that I mentioned before. Those routes are compulsory acquisition or testing the waters with this claimant procedure—although that obviously would not be very practical in a situation where we wanted to act quickly in a drought—or the agreement route that I set out. But I actually think there would be a very strong argument that this would count as a low impact exercise, temporary, transient, for an obviously useful purpose, and as such it would not attract any of these other problems. That is something we would be very happy to have a look at because I know it is a particular problem that arises, but I do not think the legislation needs to be changed to take that into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the minister can assure me that, using the low impact idea, these could be granted fairly quickly. As far as the idea that it may turn into something permanent goes: that is not correct, not the way the WA lands department does things. From my knowledge, at the end of the six months people are off. They can apply for an extension but one is very seldom granted. They are off and that is it.

PARA.TAB: The minister mentioned beekeepers; they would be virtually unrestricted. The minister has got no idea about those remote areas that I am talking about. They are areas where there might be one or two people. Of course, there is mineral exploration now and that makes it a bit different, otherwise it is totally uninhabited. They might see a white man or anyone else once a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to Senator Panizza, I do have a bit of an idea because I was minister for resources and energy for three or four years—he might recall—from 1984 to 1987.
—You visited Kalgoorlie.
—I travelled over more of this country over that period than most members of the Senate put together. I have got—
—He did. He flew backwards and forwards to Perth all the time.

—Maybe I have not travelled more than the honourable senators of Western Australia, but I know what they are talking about and that is the truth of the matter. If it is any help for me to have said so on the public record, in the Hansard, if it ever comes to a matter of interpreting the definition of a low impact future act under clause 219 of this bill, I think it is probably the case and there is a very good argument that temporary leases—which would probably not be leases at all but licences, I would imagine, as a matter of technical law—would count as low-impact future acts for the purposes of the legislation. I hope my future brethren on the court will read it that way.
—Perhaps the Minister would like to indicate what other forms of lease would be regarded as low impact acts?

—I do not think any other form of a lease, properly and technically so called, could come within that category because of the way—Senator Alston will no doubt be very familiar with the terms of the bill—that low impact acts actually exclude various forms of leasehold. I do not know, and I am unable to find out in the time available whether these temporary things that Senator Panizza talks about are actually leases, but I would be much more inclined to think that rather being a form of short-term lease they are a form of licence that is granted.
—There is no definitional difference. The licence is issued to lease the land for 12 months.
—Senator Crichton-Browne might choose to put it in those terms, but legally there is a bit of a difference.
—You may tell us about that, then.
—Is the honourable senator not supposed to be in the chair rather than bellowing away from the sidelines? Should he not keep himself neutral and nice?
—You are trying to neuter me.
—Not before time. A few of the honourable senator's colleagues would like to do that too, I think.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—I believe the minister has the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —A formal lease cannot be carried out under the terms of clause 219 and still have a low impact application, but if it is a question of some other form of activity probably conducted under some form of licence then there is every reason to believe that that would be a legitimate ground for exemption.

—Having regard to clause 227 where a lease is effectively expressed to include anything that a state declares or describes to be a lease and putting that together with clause 219B, in effect, a temporary pastoral lease could not be granted in the future, is that right, without the Crown actually compulsorily acquiring the land and having to pay compensation and then making it available for a short period of time?

—I would like to see from Senator Alston some formal legal description of what the nature of these interests is. Common terminology, common usage, is often very different from legal usage and I think that the particular provision to which he refers, clause 227, is probably not likely to be applicable in this instance.
—It is anything described as a lease.
—In the Minister's earlier comments in answer to one of my questions he made reference to an amendment from the Greens. Could he tell us which amendment he was looking at.
—I referred to a number of such amendments. Which one is the honourable senator asking about, the body corporate one?
—No, it was with regard to acquisition. I asked whether or not it extinguished—

—It is Green amendment No. 6, or maybe now No. 6A, because I think it has been circulated in redrafted form, and I think we get to that next after we have dealt with this particular item. I think it is next on the running sheet because it arises under clause 22.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—There is an amendment No. 6B to be moved by the Greens on the line below 22.
Question put:
That clauses 20 and 21 be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clause 22.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 22, page 13, after subclause (3), insert the following note:
``Note:Subdivision B (which deals with the right to negotiate0 applies to some acquisitions under Compulsory Acquisition Acts.''.
Clause 37, page 21, paragraph (1)(b), lines 24 to 26, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
``(b)any assessment of the efect of the proposed act on the natural environment of the land or waters concerned:

TAB.TAB: (i)made by a court or tribunal; or
(ii)made, or commissioned, by the Crown in any capacity or by a statutory authority;''.

PARA.TAB: Clause 38, page 22, at end of clause, add the following subclause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Leave only if material change in circumstances

PARA.TAB: ``(2) The arbitral body may only grant leave under subsection (1) if there has been a material change in the circumstances relating to the issue.''.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments relate to clauses 22, 37, and 38. I do not pursue amendments 15 and 16 relating to clause 25. These amendments are essentially technical in character. They are designed to clarify aspects of the legislation, but they are not designed to change any of it substantively.

PARA.TAB: The amendment to clause 22 involves the insertion of a note. Notes are relatively new in statutes. They are designed as an aid to interpretation. They are a little bit more substantial than traditional marginal notes, but fall short of incorporation in the statute itself. The note that it is proposed be included in clause 22 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Subdivision B (which deals with the right to negotiate) applies to some acquisitions under Compulsory Acquisitions Acts.

It has been suggested to us that the wording of clause 22(3) does not make it clear that, by expressly permitting the compulsory acquisition of native title, the native titleholder is nevertheless entitled to negotiate in relation to the proposed acquisition under subdivision B. This note removes any doubt about that.

PARA.TAB: The amendment to clause 37, amendment No. 17, was suggested by the states. Their concern was that, as presently drafted, the provision would require the arbitral body to look at all environmental impact assessments, including privately commissioned assessments which might have little or no credibility. The amendment does not prevent the arbitral body from using its powers under the relevant paragraph to look at a privately prepared environmental impact statement if the arbitral body considers that it is relevant to the particular case, but it does not require it to do so. The states seemed to think that would be helpful. I hope it will be acknowledged as such.

The amendment to clause 38, amendment No. 18, is premised on the government's acceptance that there is a need to provide for the greatest degree of confidence in the land management regime applicable to native title. As a result, the amendment is intended to deal, in particular, with sequential dealings in land—exploration and mining, for example—associated with resources development.

The amendment would limit the capacity of the tribunal to reopen issues previously dealt with in circumstances where there had been a material change in the relevant circumstances, thereby providing companies with greater security. They would know that once matters were settled they could only be revisited in any further deliberations by the arbitral body if, for example, one of the premises on which the matter had been settled changed or proved to be wrong. These are all technical amendments, but they are designed to improve the procedures under the legislation and to remove possible doubt about the application of various provisions. I commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just so that we know where we are going, in this heading entitled `Right to Negotiate' we will not deal with 24, we will leave that to the next heading, as in the running sheet. I have already covered clause 22 in previous debate. But I wish to turn to clause 25—
—Clause 25 is not part of this sequence of amendments. Senator Ellison may not have heard me, but I said that we were not going to proceed with amendments 15 and 16 to clause 25.
—What about the clause itself, though?
—We will have an opportunity to get to that when we come to it. That is on the running sheet, page 5.
—Amendments 15 and 16 that Senator Gareth Evans refers to relate to clause 25, and they are the only amendments that do relate to clause 25 in that section.

—We are not proceeding with those amendments, but if you have got any other issues to raise about clause 25, the place to do it is when we get to clause 25 in the normal course of things, which is over the page, on page 5 of the running sheet.

—Very well. I will refer to clauses 37 and 38 and thereby amendments 17 and 18. Clause 37 deals with the tribunal and the criteria in relation to determinations. I notice that the government moved to clear up the query concerning clause 37, subclause (1)(b), wherein the tribunal could take notice of the findings of any other body that had made an assessment of the effect of the proposed act on the natural environment of the land or waters concerned. Of course, there was some problem in relation to what exactly a body was. The government seems to have attempted to tighten this up so that the body was defined. Amendment 17 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Any assessment of the effect of the proposed act on the natural environment of the land or waters concerned:
(i) made by a court or tribunal; or
(ii) made, or commissioned, by the Crown in any capacity or by a statutory authority;
