That part of it may be okay, but the problem is that we still have clause 37(1)(f), which means the tribunal can take note of any matter that it considers relevant. It can also take note, in (a)(vi), of:
The natural environment of the land or waters concerned.

So what it means is that the arbitral body really has a wide discretion, and really it should stick to matters pertaining to native title. My query is, what qualification will the arbitral body have to look at the natural environment of the land or waters concerned and how far can the arbitral body go in taking into account any other matter? I also note in passing that (1)(d) in clause 37 brings in matters of economic or other significance of the proposed act to Australia and to the state or territory concerned.

PARA.TAB: My second query to the minister is that surely an arbitral body in this instance should not be taking note of those matters. That should be left to other bodies. The arbitral body really is only concerned with matters of native title. It does not set itself up as an economic expert, or an environmental expert, or an expert as to what is significant for the state or the country. I would suggest to the minister that those aspects, those criteria, are irrelevant in this area. It has to be remembered that, in any process for development, there has to be an environmental impact study; there have to be other considerations taken into account and these other matters could well have been canvassed by other competent authorities. So, really, the amendment in 17 is only shifting the deck chairs on the Titanic, so to speak. It might tighten up the definition of body, but it still leaves open ends for the arbitral body to consider economic, environment and any other matter of significance it sees fit. I would like to hear the minister's comments in relation to that and as to what qualification the arbitral body has to take those matters into account and judge them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, under first principles of administrative law, a tribunal of this kind can only take into account things which are relevant to the determination of the native title issue that is before it. It cannot use one or other of these heads set out in clause 37 to go off on some frolic of its own and just have regard to environmental considerations, or whatever, in the abstract. There have to be considerations about natural environment, in so far as they impact on, are relevant to, the enjoyment of native title. If they were to do it on any other basis, they would be subject, I guess, to some discipline by court proceedings in the way that I have described under the basic principles of administrative law.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, the open-ended reference—or apparently open-ended reference—in 1(f) to `any other matter that the arbitral body considers relevant' is, again, not an open invitation to think about, or apply, any consideration at all. As a matter of administrative law, it could only be things which have some objective relevance to the exercise that is in question. Might I draw Senator Ellison's attention to 1(d), for example, which refers to the economic, or other significance, of the proposed act to Australia and to the state or territory concerned. That was a particular criterion that was suggested to us by the states—and perhaps by industry as well, certainly by the states—as an appropriate thing for arbitral bodies to take into account. One might well be led by that to ask: what sort of economic qualifications have they got? Do they have to have a PhD from the ANU, or something, in order to pass upon economic considerations? Of course, they do not. They just have to apply, in a commonsense fashion, criteria that are in fact relevant in the various ways that are here set out to their determination. That is a responsibility that all sorts of arbitral, or other administrative bodies have—quasi-judicial bodies—in a whole variety of contexts in Australia. This one is no different.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the first principles of administrative law are that they should not concern themselves with other matters, why not tighten up the legislation to state specifically what they can have regard to? For instance, if it is going to be the environment, the environment is stated only in so far as it impacts on the native title consideration. Or, if it is going to be economic, state the obvious: that it is only economic matters pertaining to native title that could be considered. In fact, in the High Court judgment, I do not think those matters were really covered.

—If the honourable senator is prepared to draft and move something along those lines, we would certainly be prepared to consider it. I think that is the intent of the legislation. I am sure that is the way in which the legislation would be read down. It is probably unnecessary to go that far but, if the honourable senator wants to make a constructive contribution to this process, rather than simply make reasonable points and then vote against clauses, he might reconsider the way in which he is approaching this legislative debate. The honourable senator's contributions have been thoughtful and helpful, but they are not being followed through with any constructive action.
—Well, you can pick up his good points.

—It might not be a bad idea, if the honourable senator wanted to develop a bit of credibility, to put some of these thoughts in writing and move them by way of amendments. We would be delighted to give them exactly the same consideration we have given the equally thoughtful amendments, some of which we have accepted and some of which we have not, coming to us from the Democrats and others, the Greens, in this place. I just offer the honourable senator that invitation. If he wants to make a constructive contribution, he can.

—Mr Chairman, I would like to deal with that pious humbug. I think the minister understands well that we are not in the business of seeking to improve a clause which we think is inappropriate in an area which is even more inappropriate.
—But you are not very persuasive.

—Senator Evans should wait a moment. What we are concerned to ascertain is the basis on which those opposite put forward propositions which will go into law. Assuming they have support from other parties, we will have no capacity to stop these clauses being put into law and therefore the obligation is on those who put them forward to explain what they mean. Does `economic or other significance' mean economic or non-economic significance? If it does, why do those opposite not simply say `significance'. Let me take (f) for example. It says `any other matter that the arbitral body considers relevant'. Accepting the government's proposition that people are not allowed to wander off whimsically and have regard to the last Ginger Meggs comic they read, the fact is that we still have to take into account certain principles. Presumably the whole of clause 37, under the heading of `Criteria', is an attempt to set out what the parliament regards as proper principles.

PARA.TAB: If the government has done its best to spell out, one after another, those criteria which are relevant, what is the point of saying at the end `and anything else you think might be relevant as well'? Surely that negates the whole exercise. Unless there is some ulterior motive, do we simply put it down to sloppy drafting?

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it is a fair while since Senator Alston has actually practised in the courts. I know it is a fair while since Senator Alston has actually looked at any legislation. I know it is a fair while since he has ever actually argued any legislative interpretation—
—More recently than you.

—That is perfectly true, but if Senator Alston turned his mind back to lists of criteria that govern administrative or quasi-judicial decisions, I doubt very much if he could think of one single list of criteria anywhere that has not had some kind of clause like `any other matter considered relevant' or `any other matter that is relevant' at its tailpiece. It is a very familiar piece of drafting. It is one that is testable by a criterion of relevance, as Senator Alston and I would both acknowledge, and both have acknowledged. If we are in the business of pious humbug, I think two can play at that particular game. Let us hear no more of that particular brand of nonsense that Senator Alston has just uttered.

—Mr Chairman, on the same issue, could I ask the minister to clarify the way in which this clause would impact on the operation of state and territory authorities in the particular area of the environmental impact process. For example, would the various state and territory environmental impact processes be embraced by this particular clause and legislation, and picked up as the appropriate gauging bodies, or would there be a requirement for these new procedures to be adopted to overtake or override those provisions of state and territory environmental impact processes? It would appear that the government amendment does not fix the problem or clarify it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the contrary, subclause (b), as now amended, says that the arbitral body must take into account:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any assessment of the effect of the proposed act on the natural environment of the land or waters concerned:
(i)made by a court or a tribunal; or
(ii)made, or commissioned by, the Crown in any capacity or by a statutory authority.
The proper, formal, official environmental impact statements that are made by state or territory authorities not only should, but must, be taken into account by the tribunal in question.

PARA.TAB: Our amendment was simply designed to make clear that tribunals did not have to take into account any assessment at all that was made by any body at all, including perhaps some privately commissioned body or privately commissioned research of a very self-interested kind. Tribunals still retain the capacity to take that into account if they want to—it is not excluded—but they do not have to take it into account. However, a proper, serious EIS or something of that kind commissioned by a state or territory, or statutory authority, must be taken into account. I think that ought to satisfy Senator Tambling's concerns and those of the territory and states in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very peculiar day, indeed. The government had indicated to the mining industry that it was going to move an amendment in response to the mining industry's request for certainty. The government has just refused to move that amendment, which is amendment 15.
—You are not right.
—Amendment 15 is not before the chair.
—As I understand it, the minister indicated that he was not going to move that amendment, at all. Is that the case?

—I am not going to move amendment 15; I am going to move amendment 14, when we get to it, which essentially covers the same territory and makes 15 unnecessary. We will talk about that when we get to 14, but now is not the time.
—Mr Chairman, that is a peculiar situation because I am not sure that it works that way.
—Are you waiting for your big moment to cross the floor?

—It is a matter that will be discussed in a moment or two, I am sure. As honourable senators would be aware, Senator McGauran, Senator Sandy Macdonald and I will be supporting amendment 18. This is because we believe that that amendment adds to the certainty of processes for mineral exploration and, accordingly, we would ask that that amendment be taken separately from the others.

—As I have indicated previously, I think any time there is a request from a senator for a particular amendment to be taken separately that that ought to be honoured in accordance with the arrangements we previously agreed.
—I just have a point of clarification, Mr Chairman. We are dealing with amendments 9 and 17 now and, as I understand it, 18 is being dealt with separately. Amendment 9—
—We are debating them at length but we will vote separately.

—I understand that. I want clarification about when I should raise my amendment No. 6 because it relates to clause 22. We have already dealt with clause 22, to a certain extent, because we will be voting on it. I want to make sure that I do not miss the opportunity to raise my amendment. Do I do it now?
—Senator Evans may have a different view from this, and no doubt he will tell me about it, but I was proposing to put his amendments first, followed by yours.

—I am indebted to you, Mr Chairman. I suggest that we deal with my amendments—9, 17 and 18. Then perhaps we should deal with the Democrat amendment No. 9A, which I understand is also on the same subject matter of the right to negotiate. I understand that the other Democrat amendments may not be pursued, but that is a matter for the Democrats to indicate. After we have dealt with that line relating to the right to negotiate, we then move onto the next line of the running sheet, which is also triggered by clause 22, which relates to compulsory acquisition. We can deal with the Greens' amendment then.
—Yes, that was my intention. The question is that government amendments 9 and 17 be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that government amendment 18 be agreed to. Those of that opinion say `aye', to the contrary `no', I think the ayes have it.
—The noes have it.
—Is a division required?
—I heard only one voice. There was only one voice.
—The committee will proceed to consider Democrat amendment—
—I seek clarification, Mr Chairman. I thought we were just voting on amendment 18.
—Yes, we were.
—I voted no, and so did my colleague. We called for a division.
—I didn't hear you call for a division.

—We did. We were told that we had misunderstood, and that what was being voted on was whether the two votes should be done separately and that is why we remained silent. But when we moved on I realised that we had been correct in our understanding.

—All right, Senator Chamarette. I have to say two things. The first is that what you understood is not the question I put before the Senate and the other thing is that I heard but one voice and no request to divide, notwithstanding my asking twice. But perhaps we might overcome that problem if you would seek leave to have both voices, as you call them, for the noes recorded, to save a division.
—It will record the Greens' opposition.
—It has the same effect; it is recorded in the journals.
—No, I am sorry; we are calling for a division.

—I suggest to Senator Chamarette that she follow the course proposed by the Chairman. She has made it clear that she is opposed; it is in the Hansard that her voice and that of Senator Margetts opposed this. That has exactly the same effect as a division, and it would save us about 15 minutes, because it takes a long time to count all the other votes with just two on one side. Senator Chamarette has made her point.

—I am not sure whether we are making the same point. I understand we are voting on amendment 18, relating to clause 38, and that some of us have expressed our vote on that and requested a division. I understand we are entitled to it. I am not sure why we are not having a division in response to that request.
—Because it was not called for.
—We did not miss the boat. I seek leave—

—If Senator Chamarette resumes her seat, I will put a proposition which I hope is acceptable. I have actually put the question and it has been resolved. But in the normal course of events, if you ask for a division you are entitled to one, and it is my view that if you insist on a division you are entitled to one.
—I do insist. We both insist.
—I hope it does not offend anybody else in the committee, but it seems to me a reasonable proposition.

—Mr Chairman, can I simply direct your attention to the sequence of events? Senator Kernot wanted to make it very clear that she was voting no, and at one stage there was discussion about whether there should be a division. You clarified that by saying that no, it was not necessary. Everyone had ample opportunity to digest what was going on and you proceeded to deal with the matter accordingly.

PARA.TAB: Now, unless we are simply concerned about grandstanding, for the purposes of people shuffling around in their seats for the next 10 minutes, the only possible anxiety that the Greens can have is that they do not want to have their votes incorrectly recorded. Your previous solution, an offer to them, was to ensure that they are on the record as having voted no. That is as far as you ought to go. Going beyond that is an indulgence that can be extended to senators by leave if someone wants to re-open a matter. It is not able to be done as of right. I would have thought that if we are demonstrating our bona fides, if we are not simply wanting to put on a bit of a performance, then we would accept the offer made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unaware that this is such a problem, Mr Chairman. I do not assume that only two people will vote no in this division. I have a question as to whether it may be a majority or at least whether the vote might be able to be negated, and in that instance I think it is a question of democracy rather than simply grandstanding or a matter of principle. If honourable senators wish, I will speak to this amendment and say why the Greens oppose it.
—Order! It is my strong view that if there is a misunderstanding about the Greens' request for a division, there ought to be a division.

—Mr Chairman, I am not opposed to that. I think there was clearly a misunderstanding. It would save us a lot of time if we did not have a division, but clearly there was a misunderstanding at the relevant time, and under those circumstances I think your approach to this ought to be accepted.

—Order! It is the convention. To do otherwise would be to break the convention which I am simply restating. I think it would be wrong for me not to allow a division. A division is being called. I propose to allow a division.

—On a point of order, Mr Chairman, right throughout this year we have made concessions to the Greens on their procedures and the way they carry on. It cannot go on forever. The procedures have been followed and it has all been done correctly. You have made your ruling and I cannot see why we should keep conceding. It takes all of us a bit of time to learn, but we cannot keep doing this, particularly when there is no point in it. I do not know what the grandstanding is about, but I urge you, Mr Chairman, to carry on as you have proceeded.

—I think it is perfectly proper to allow a reconsideration of a matter where otherwise injustice would occur. That ought to be the principle that guides you, Mr Chairman. If, for example, there was any risk that otherwise the Greens might go down in history as having voted yes when they intended to vote no, then quite clearly you should allow them to record their position. But, long after the event and long after the matter was given careful and slow consideration, for them to rise and ask for a division is nothing more than seeking to unnecessarily delay the affairs of the chamber, purely for the purpose of making some abstruse political point, which escapes me—
—Are you going to apply this principle over the next few hours and days?

—I do not wish to say any more. I am just saying, by all means let us never be unfair in our treatment of people, particularly where there might have been a misunderstanding, but there could be no misunderstanding here, only grandstanding.

—Mr Chairman, I would like to support you in the ruling you made. I did hear the conversation; there was a clear misunderstanding. We thought it was just about the separation of clauses and not the substance of the clause. It was a clear misunderstanding, and I would like to support the call for a division as well.

—I must say that mistakes are not confined to the Greens. The convention is that when misunderstandings occur in the chamber in respect of the calling of a division, a great deal of patience and goodwill is invariably extended by the Chairman or the President. I intend to maintain that practice and I am going to call for the bells to be rung. There is a division to be had.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that clause 22, as amended, be agreed to.
—As I understand it, it is time for the Australian Democrats to move their amendment to this cluster. The relevant amendment is No. 9A. After that, the Greens should move their amendment No. 6A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: No. 1—Clause 41, page 24, after paragraph (2)(d), insert the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: ``(da)make provision on similar terms to section 29 and contain time limits similar to those applicable under this Subdivision; and''.

PARA.TAB: No. 2—Clause 41, page 25, paragraph (2)(h), lines 7 and 8, omit ``overruled on grounds of State or Territory interest or of national interest'', substitute ``overruled in the State or Territory interest or in the national interest on grounds that are consistent with the Preamble.''.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment consists of two parts. I am moving them together. We will debate them together, but I will seek leave to have the vote taken separately on the two parts. The first amendment simply makes the provision that the time limits that are being used should be similar to those applicable under the subdivision. I move the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the decision made previously, Senator Spindler, you are entitled to have the question split without leave. I do not have the amendment in front of me, but if you would like to proceed you are very welcome.

—The second part of that particular amendment suggests that overruling on the grounds of a state or territory or national interest should be done in a manner that is consistent with the preamble. In other words, the principles enunciated in the preamble should be taken into account when national or state interest is being taken into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's position is that we are perfectly happy to support the first of the two amendments that have been moved—amendment to clause 41, which is as Senator Spindler described it—for the reasons that Senator Spindler spelt out. The difficulty we have about the second amendment to clause 41 is that it introduces into the body of the bill itself, and the future act itself, a reference to the preamble in so far as it says:

SPEECH.PARA: overruled in the State or Territory interest or in the national interest on grounds that are consistent with the Preamble.

As we see it, the difficulty is that this introduces an element of uncertainty into the construction of this particular clause. It is one thing to have a preamble to an act as a general guide to the intentions of parliament and as an aid to interpretation. That is something that is increasingly happening in legislation. It is a very good thing, and it is very helpful to the courts.

PARA.TAB: However, it is another thing to incorporate the text of the preamble by reference into the body of the legislation itself because, necessarily, preamble language is looser, more general and of a different character to ordinary statutory language. It is not susceptible to interpretation in the same way as the formally, carefully and precisely drafted statutory language is. We see it as opening up quite a difficult process of interpretation. It is introducing an element of uncertainty in an area where it is important that there be maximum certainty. Accordingly, we will vote against the second part of Senator Spindler's amendment. While not disagreeing with the sentiments that underlie it in any way, we do not think the drafting technique that has been employed is helpful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it difficult to agree with the Minister for Foreign Afairs (Senator Gareth Evans) on this point. The preamble spells out very clearly why this act is being enacted by the government and what its objectives are. I would have thought that when we talk about national interest we should take into account notions such as justice to the indigenous peoples of Australia. If that is the minister's objection, I find it difficult to see how—
—I am not objecting to the concept. You know that.
—Perhaps the minister could help me by defining the national interest. What would it be if the preamble is excluded?

—Would that I had time enough! It is one thing to talk in these terms in describing the general intent of the legislation and the direction a court should go in construing other more specific provisions: it is quite another thing to import that kind of language into the actual provisions that the court has to apply. I think the point I am making is well understood. There are some countries—the United States, for example—where they use this language all over the place. It creates nightmarish jurisprudence as a result. We are much more cautiously Anglo-Saxon in our approach to legislative drafting, and may we remain thus for the foreseeable future.

—If I may pursue it one step further, could the minister tell me whether he would suggest that the national interest is financial and economic only, or does it also include cultural and social matters?

—Senator Spindler keeps on asking vulgar and self-serving questions! Of course, I am prepared to concede that the national interest extends to those other interests as well. I simply make the point that it does not help awfully much in terms of the construction of formal statutory provisions to import those sorts of notions, however credible and attractive they may be.

—I wish to say that it is another of these amendments which we have learned to expect from the Democrats. They want to go even further than does the centralist government we have got. So there is just no way that we can even contemplate supporting this type of amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surprisingly enough, the Greens wish to indicate that we support this amendment. We believe that it is in the best interests of native titleholders. Mr Temporary Chairman, while we appreciate that a division may take time and you may not want to call it, we still would register our support for that amendment.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—The question is that the first part of Senator Spindler's amendment 9A be agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the second part of amendment 9A moved by Senator Spindler be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette, you have an amendment at this stage?
—Yes. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 8.Clause 33, page 20, line 2, after "party", insert "who has negotiated in good faith".
9.Clause 36, pages 20 and 21, line 35 (page 20) to line 5 (page 21) omit subclause (2).

Looking at the running sheet, the Greens have now moved amendments Nos 8 and 9 on their list that was circulated in the chamber. I explain that amendment No. 8 refers to clause 33 and simply inserts the phrase `who has negotiated in good faith'. I think that is a right and proper requirement to have in the circumstances. We seek to omit clause 36(2) under `Profit-sharing conditions not to be determined'. We want to omit the following:
The arbitral body must not determine a condition under paragraph (1)(c) that has the effect that native title parties are to be entitled to payments worked out by reference to:

PARA.TAB: (a) the amount of profits made; or
(b) any income derived; or
(c) any things produced;

SPEECH.PARA: by any grantee party as a result of doing anything in relation to the land or waters concerned after the act is done.
It is fairly obvious to us that this is a discriminatory clause which actually seeks to undermine the economic resource base of native titleholders, and we are opposed to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I indicate the government's opposition to those amendments. While the first one is no doubt intended to provide protection for Aboriginal people, we do see a couple of difficulties with the proposed incorporation in the clause of a reference to negotiation in good faith. For a start, it adds another subjective element to the process and it is not—
—You put that stuff in your IR bill.

—It is not, in this particular context—whatever might be appropriate in other contexts—something that we think helps add to the general certainty of the environment that we think it is important to create.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, we are not at all sure that this would always work in practice to the advantage of Aboriginal people. For example, if they wanted to go ahead with a particular development which the government did not favour, the government could stall progress on that simply by refusing to negotiate or by negotiating in a way that might give rise to an allegation of acting in bad faith. That might sound like an excessively cynical response, but I think that some of us know from long experience that those sorts of responses are possible from governments on occasion.

As to amendment No. 9, we simply do not believe that approvals for mining grants and other resource uses of the land should depend upon the arbitration of claims for profit related payments. Although it would be possible for such claims to be made in the course of negotiations, the existing subclause 2 provides that the arbitral body shall not be able to require such payments.

Obviously, the community as a whole should benefit from the profits from mining operations. It does so through general taxation and, in some cases, through specific mining royalty schemes. How far native titleholders should in general terms benefit additionally from mining operations on their land or whether funds specifically derived from mining should play a larger part in benefiting Aboriginal people are questions which will need to be considered really as part of the next phase of this whole reconciliation exercise, which will go to questions of social justice and the land acquisition fund.

I repeat that the government does not believe that the arbitral body should be able to impose profit related payments as a condition for approval of mining grants and, accordingly, we do not agree with this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister to explain how we are to be expected to understand this clause in the way he has explained it to us when in the Northern Territory there already is an arrangement whereby people can derive some benefits from the royalties that flow out of mining endeavours on native title land. This clause basically puts in place a situation that is much lower than a current existing situation within Australia. I challenge the minister on the fact that, if we pass this clause into this bill, it is not setting a precedent for a retrograde step in relation to the kind of economic resource available to native titleholders.
—If the minister gets up, I will sit down again. I take it from Senator Chamarette's amendment that this amendment is attempting to get around the royalty system.
—Yes, it is.

—I heard the honourable senator on that one. If this amendment looked like getting any support, except from the Greens over there, it would be the first move to get around the fact that all royalties belong to the Crown. That is still enshrined in legislation but this bill specifically excludes native titleholders getting the right of royalties. It also positively discriminates against everyone else in Australia that holds freehold land.
—Not everyone.

—Just a minute: I am on my feet now; other honourable senators can get up when I sit down. It positively discriminates against anyone who has got freehold land. Honourable senators can shake their heads as much as they like because I know what I am talking about. With freehold land, royalties, of course, still belong to the Crown. I cannot work out compensation with a mining company on the basis of royalties; I just cannot do it. Why should any other group get it—

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts can scream as much as she likes; I know what I am talking about. I am not able to do it on freehold land. I am not going to support and, as far as I am concerned, I am going to make sure no-one supports the idea of giving rights to a group that the rest of Australians have not got. As I have already said, I cannot do a deal on the basis of royalties with a mining company on my own freehold land. All I can do is get some compensation for the loss of use of that ground and the loss of use of the income. They basically work it out over the next 50 years and discount it to the present day rate. That is how it works, not on royalties.

PARA.TAB: Agreements between land-holders and mining companies have got to be registered in the warden's court. Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette are from Western Australia and they should know; agreements have got to be registered. If any agreement is attempted to be registered in the warden's court on that line it is struck down. So if honourable senators know how the law of royalties works, I do not see why they should get up, except as a political stunt to play to the grandstand, or whatever they play to. That is the only reason they are moving it because it is exactly contrary to the present law of royalties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to Senator Panizza and point out that is not at all what I was saying. All I am saying is that this clause should be omitted because it is discriminatory and it should be left open. The point I am making is that actually to include it and to deprive someone of that possibility is the discriminatory law. If Senator Panizza had a law that was written about him in this way and it did not apply to other people, he might have the same concerns that I do. The point the Greens are making is not that we are writing in any profit-sharing conditions, we are objecting to a clause that is deliberately striking them out.

—Can I just say the amendment is only striking out the capacity to apply that as one of the conditions in the arbitration; it is not striking out a negotiated royalty arrangement that is reached as a result of agreement between the parties. It is also, of course, not striking out a compensation payment which would continue to be applicable under clause 22. It is not a matter of denying an opportunity for financial recompense; it is just a matter of denying an obligation or a capacity on the part of the arbitral body to require a payment in the nature of a profit-related royalty. The reasons for that are those that I spelt out. It is again a matter of policy judgment.

PARA.TAB: What we are trying to do in this particular context is work out what is appropriate for rights that are already there. They are not newly created rights; they are rights that are already there. We think under those circumstances the kind of compensation regime that is here involved, together with the capacity to negotiate an agreement if circumstances make that possible, is sufficient and appropriate recompense in all the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is quite extraordinary that we are being criticised for our knowledge of Western Australia. It seems that both Labor and Liberal governments in Western Australia have been prepared to be negotiable on royalty rates. Currently it appears that, for mineral sands companies in Western Australia, the mining companies themselves have the ability to negotiate on royalty rates. That means it is not crown royalties; it is negotiation by state governments. I think it is quite extraordinary to say there is one rule for everybody else. It seems there is one rule for some industries, and perhaps not the same kinds of negotiating rights for other people like Aboriginals.

—I do not want to prolong this, but Senator Margetts is totally wrong. The mining companies in Western Australia negotiate with the government. They operate on a mining lease. They are not operating it as freehold ground. It is totally wrong to come out with that argument. It is simply that people who have some sort of title—it is a native title in this case—can negotiate with that. In other words, they are getting another sort of income to let a mining crowd operate on the native title. If I am on freehold land, I can do deals with a mining company. Anyone who has freehold land can do that. It has got nothing whatsoever to do with royalties. All governments in Australia work the same, as far as royalties go. It is time Senator Margetts found this out. She purports to talk for the Pilbara region of Western Australia; she should find out about the royalty laws.

—I will not prolong the debate. To my knowledge, there are at least two precedents where native title owners obtained some kind of profit sharing conditions. It is appropriate to determine those. It is done in America and Canada. There is also the case where a property in Western Australia, Hampton, does not pay any royalties to the government. The government of Western Australia ceded total rights to that particular mining area. I think it is proper to strike the statement from this bill that deprives native titleholders of negotiating something like this. We are not pressing the point. We realise we do not have the numbers. I just want the record to show that we are opposed to the inclusion of this clause.

—Just so the Senate is not misled, either purposely or accidentally, the truth about the Hampton lease to which Senator Chamarette referred—she said rights were ceded—is that royalties were paid in that case because the mineral rights were reserved by the owners. When that lease was granted it was pre-federation and it was at a time when mineral rights were not vested in the Crown. We need to understand that the Crown did not cede its mineral rights. It did not own them.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments 5 and 6 put by the Australian Democrat address the same provisions. We have listened to the debate, and we realise where the numbers are, so we shall not proceed with them. At the same time, I wish to advise that we will not be proceeding with Democrat amendments 7 and 8 relating to preamble matters. That argument has also been run in the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 22, page 13, lines 1 to 3, omit paragraph (3)(a), substitute the following paragraphs:

SPEECH.PARA: "(a)the non-extinguishment principle applies to the acquisition; and
(aa)nothing in this Act prevents any act that is done in giving effect to the purpose of the acquisition from extinguishing the native title rights and interests; and".

This amendment relates to the non-extinguishment principle applying to acquisitions. While the phrasing may be somewhat difficult to understand, it does indicate that the compulsory acquisition powers of the state are available but without extinguishment of native title, until the point at which the land is used for the purpose for which it has been acquired and only to the extent that that purpose is inconsistent with native title rights. It is simply a way of ensuring that the power of compulsory acquisition is used in an appropriate way in relation to public works. To the extent of cancelling native title, it relates to the proper purpose for which the compulsory acquisition has been asserted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder if I could ask Senator Chamarette: is the whole point of compulsory acquisition not to ensure that there are no impediments on the title that is compulsorily acquired? If that is the case, what is the effect of the amendment?

—As I understand this, Senator Alston, it is simply a precaution that prevents states from compulsorily acquiring at a long distance ahead of any usage to which they might put the land. I have got an example at the moment where, in the Northern Territory, the people of Borroloola are unable to actually claim their middle island dreaming site because there is a town lease placed over that island. There is nothing on that island and nothing has ever been there except a legitimate area for native titleholders. However, because it has been classified as a town lease, it becomes unavailable. The amendment that I am proposing does nothing to assist the state to gain or lose any security of tenure over the area. It just provides some security to native titleholders that compulsory acquisition powers cannot be used in inappropriate ways that simply extinguish native title without actually being used for the purpose for which they have been stated. It has no effect whatsoever on the value of the land; it simply prevents extinguishment where it is not necessary.

—Might I indicate from the government perspective that we are prepared to support Green amendment 6A, essentially for the reasons that Senator Chamarette has just stated. The amendment makes it clear that, in the case of compulsory acquisition, the non-extinguishment principle will apply. What all this means in practice is that, in the first place, native title rights will be able to be exercised to the extent that they are not inconsistent with the acquisition or, in particular, with acts done pursuant to the acquisition. If an act done in giving effect to the purpose of the acquisition—for example, the building of a road or a hospital—would at common law have the effect of extinguishing native title, then it would extinguish native title. This does not inhibit that occurring, but we have got to wait until the act is done.

PARA.TAB: The amendment avoids the situation of land being acquired for some purported public purpose, but then nothing actually being done to advance that public purpose. It is important, I believe, and the government believes, that native title not actually be extinguished until such time as the relevant public purpose is actually implemented. There have been too many cases in the past, and there may—let us face it, suspicious people that we are—be more such cases in the future. The compulsory acquisition power might be employed to avoid native title being able to be exercised under some purported pursuit of a public purpose, but then nothing actually occurring. It is a bit of a risky task for the states because they are in the business of having to pay compensation but even so, of course, the states are not bound by just terms provisions as we are at the Commonwealth level because of the constitutional amendment that was opposed, among other things, by the opposition at various stages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Allowed by this bill.
—Allowed by this bill. They are not bound by the constitution, though.
—I think that referendum question got about 35 per cent, did it not?

—Yes, with a bit of help from the very sophisticated and civilised way in which the arguments were advanced by that large bald headed person on the honourable senator's side of the equation. He ought to be ashamed of himself for his contribution to public policy in this country, but that is another question for another day.
—I wrote the No case.
—The honourable senator wrote the No case; he ought to be ashamed of himself too.
—Thank you very much, Gareth.
—You should have a haircut too.
—Order! Can we have the remarks addressed through the chair, please.
—One of the less happy periods in the history of this country, I think.
—Have a look behind you. There are some bald fellows there too.

—Democracy at work; one can always appeal to vulgar popular sentiment. Anyway, back to being more high-minded. As we are now in the pursuit of this particular legislation, we do not think the extinguishment should actually occur until some act is done pursuant to the acquisition. Extinguishments are a pretty substantial thing to happen; they are a pretty draconian thing to happen to native title. We are prepared to accept that it can happen if a proper compulsory acquisition takes place for a proper public purpose, and some act is actually done to advance that particular purpose, but not otherwise. That is what this amendment does. We support it.

—The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment and welcome the government's support for it. It is quite clear that without this amendment there was a very significant loophole in the bill, allowing state governments to simply slap a reservation over large areas of land without actually using it for the purpose or, for that matter, ever using it for the purpose. They could very often change the purpose and simply use this mechanism to keep land out of the hands of native titleholders. I think the amendment is extremely necessary and urgent, and we had one formulated in the same terms, as Senator Kernot is reminding me. In this particular case, we withdrew ours to allow the Greens to move this one.

—Given that the government seems to be happy to be associated with this amendment, perhaps I could ask the minister whether he accepts that the effect of this amendment is that an acquisition will not extinguish native title. Is it right that a compulsory acquisition will not extinguish native title in the circumstances where the government regards it as necessary and therefore a freehold title will not be able to be granted in those circumstances?

—No, the acquisition will accomplish extinguishment of title when some act is done to implement the purpose for which the acquisition is made. Under every state and territory compulsory acquisition law and under Commonwealth compulsory acquisition law that I am aware of, a specific purpose has to be identified and—
—You mean you have to express it in the compulsory acquisition?

—Yes, that is true. Some of them are quite broad in terms. The point is that you do have to state a purpose and, since the acquisition without this amendment would result ipso facto in extinguishment as soon as the acquisition is accomplished and since that is a draconian impact on native title and since it is perfectly possible that nothing further would happen for the indefinitely foreseeable future and that would be a doubly unfortunate result, we are just supporting the introduction of a precautionary measure which will ensure that the actual extinguishment does not occur until such time as some act is done in pursuit of the particular purpose for which the acquisition is made.

PARA.TAB: That means that there is absolutely no problem at all from a state, territory or Commonwealth point of view if the acquisition is done for legitimate purpose and that purpose is advanced—whether it is building a road, a hospital, a defence establishment or anything else. But if an acquisition takes place just for the conceivable purpose, perhaps, of locking up and denying a continued role in relation to that land by native titleholders and, perhaps, with the government in question being prepared to pay some amount of compensation under a just terms provision in order to secure that result, we do not think that should by itself be good enough to secure extinguishment. That extinguishment should have to await some step being taken to the implementation of the purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if a compensation acquisition notice specifies a good and proper reason you would not then extinguish native title at that point; you would wait until it actually translates. What activates the extinguishment of native title? Is it a purely discretionary matter?
—No, as the terms of the clause say: `when an act is done in giving effect to the purpose of the acquisition'.
—What stage is that then?
—I suppose if it were ever tested in the courts—
—Is it when the first sod is turned or when the hospital is opened or what?
—Quite possibly, when a form of service—
—So it is a matter of discretion then? At some stage someone makes a judgment?

—It is not a matter of discretion. The act is done in giving effect to the acquisition. It is a matter of judgment, by any court that may be called upon to make that judgment at some stage, as to whether that is a purely notional or cosmetic act and not a serious one to advance the particular purpose, or whether it is a significant first step in the implementation purpose. The point is that if an acquisition is made for some purpose—to build a road, a hospital, a defence establishment or anything else—and steps are taken to implement that purpose, then extinguishment is accomplished and it is out of the way.

PARA.TAB: The only twilight zone will be if nothing happens—or possibly if something early and ambiguous happens—until something more happens further down the track. That is the only circumstance. There is no public interest that is inhibited by the existence of this cautionary provision, but there is certainly a public interest that is advanced, and that is the public interest of ensuring that extinguishment does not occur unless there is just and sufficient reason for it to occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still do not understand whether the minister is saying that there will be some event that will automatically trigger extinguishment, or whether it is simply going to be a matter of some bureaucrat at some stage certifying that in his or her judgment a sufficient degree of the act has occurred as to justify it or as to trigger it automatically. Or will it require some sort of application to be made and then some order? If it is dependent upon some sort of formal order being made, surely we could have a situation where no-one bothered. It just does not have to be a hospital or a public park: presumably it can be any form of grant of lease, yet that could continue to have native title attached to it, which presumably could surface at an inconvenient time at some later stage.
—I would like to suggest to Senator Alston that there are a whole range of things which could trigger it. It could be something as simple as the signing of a contract or the turning of the first sod.
—But who decides that?
—It depends on the project.
—The point that I am making is whether there is something that one can say will automatically trigger it.
—It is the beginning; whatever is the physical beginning of the project.

—How does that then transmit? The whole point is this: the Western Australian legislation effectively says that you have traditional usage rights and you do not need to apply to a court; whereas, under this bill, every man and his dog has to go along and apply and get a right established. In the same way, here, if there is nothing that automatically triggers it, so that native title is extinguished and you have a clear title, then presumably there will be interminable arguments or else nothing will happen. At some later stage, someone could come along and say, `Native title was never extinguished. Maybe it should have been; maybe there was a sufficient act that justified it; but, because some bureaucrat did not give it the tick, it did not happen'. That is the problem that I am raising: uncertainty.
—But who suffers from that problem?

—Presumably, if there is a reason sufficient to extinguish native title—which is to give certainty of title subsequently—then the lack of extinguishment gives rise to future uncertainty. Otherwise, you would not bother extinguishing it. The only purpose of extinguishment is to ensure that you have got a clear title, is it not?

—Yes, but if the Commonwealth or a state acquires land for some purpose and then does nothing with it, what does it matter to anybody that native title is not extinguished? Let us face it: in some states, the purpose of a compulsory acquisition can be pretty broadly expressed, and in some states land can be acquired for the purpose of letting it out again by way of lease to private commercial interest. That is one of the things that one can do with a compulsory acquisition in some states.

PARA.TAB: If the Commonwealth or state or territory then does something with the acquired land for a public purpose, and that is consistent with the law of compulsory acquisition of the state in question, that would be a step taken for the implementation of the purpose of the acquisition, and so the title would be extinguished and clear title would be taken by the lessee. The title would be extinguished anyway by the grant of a lease under first principles, we guess, of common law.

So there is not likely to be any problem for anybody. The only problem is for native titleholders who get their title extinguished for a purpose that is not in fact implemented. That is bad news for them, when there is no redeeming public interest advanced in extinguishing title before something actually happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not an impermissible act—unless you have extinguished native title—to grant the new title?

—The granting of the new title would itself constitute an act being done to give effect to the purposes of the acquisition and would as such accomplish the extinguishment. So there is no inconsistency there.
—But it is an impermissible act and it cannot be done unless native title is extinguished.

—Nothing in this act prevents any act that is done in giving effect to the purpose of the acquisition from extinguishing the native title rights and interests. So any concern of that kind is met by the explicit language of the drafting in the second part of the Greens' amendment. For the Greens to acknowledge that anything is capable of extinguishing anything is a bit of a triumph and ought to be acknowledged as such. But there it is, it spells it out and deals with the particular issue that there is worry about.

—I appreciate Senator Evans's comments on that. I want to point out that the purpose of this amendment has nothing to do with certainty of title. That is not the issue here. The concern is a very relevant one to those of us from Western Australia, because often the federal legislation has been provided as the solution to the problem in Western Australia of the state legislation, which has already extinguished all native title. The problem that the Greens WA have expressed over and over again about the federal legislation is that, where there is a lack of good political will on the part of a state, the powers of compulsory acquisition that are available to the states via this legislation actually allow them to do on a bit by bit basis exactly what the Premier of Western Australia was able to do with one stroke of legislation.

PARA.TAB: Without this particular amendment that the Greens WA are proposing, this bill allows state or Commonwealth governments to compulsorily acquire land and pass it on to third parties at a later time. This effectively allows for governments to extinguish all native title by stealth if they are of that bad political will, and we are hoping they are not. However, we should not leave any loopholes. The Swan brewery in Western Australia is a good example of how this can be done. The brewery was purchased by the Western Australian government in 1985—a Labor government, as Western Australian senators will know—supposedly so that it could be presented as a gift to the Aboriginal people in the bicentennial year. Instead, some time later it was given to a property developer.

There is nothing in this bill, without this amendment, to stop that kind of process being repeated by an unsympathetic state government, until no native title land is left. The bill therefore needs to be amended in this way to prevent governments acting in bad faith when compulsorily acquiring native title, and it is in the public interest that that should be so. The public purpose for which the land is acquired, when it is demonstrated and reaches a point where it is inconsistent with the existence of native title, is the appropriate time for native title to be extinguished. There may be times when the states wish to compulsorily acquire land and have native title on that land for very beneficial reasons. There may be other times when the use is incompatible, and that is allowed for within the phrasing of this amendment. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pose a question to the minister about the support for this amendment, because I can see it causing more problems than it will solve. In terms of a state government acquiring the land, for whatever the purpose might be, if it extinguishes native title, presumably compensation has to be paid. What is the status and timing of the paying of that compensation?

PARA.TAB: Would it be relevant to a pastoral lease or even to freehold land? I refer to the Johnston Lake country in the south-east of Western Australia. That has been identified in a number of reports as being an area that is suitable for agriculture. So many questions are unanswered in terms of planning the structure of that, including surveying, planning for roads and town sites and the whole range of things that are required when developing the economic and social structure required for farms. Those questions were not satisfactorily dealt with in answer to Senator Alston's question. Could the minister please address some of the points I have raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under clause 22 of the bill, compensation has to be payable on acquisition, but the quantum of the compensation that would be payable would depend on the extent to which the interference with native title had occurred. So if there is simply an acquisition in relation to which no steps have been taken to implement the public purpose and there has been, as a result, no extinguishment of the native title, the amount of compensation payable would be, presumably to that extent, much less.

PARA.TAB: It might conceivably be that there would be a two-stage exercise: an application for compensation at the time of the acquisition and then, if the thing were in a sense warehoused, and nothing happened pursuant to the acquisition for some time, and there had been no extinguishment of the native title in question, there might be a compensation determination which would be quite limited in scope.

Then, if some act were taken to implement the acquisition to apply it for some appropriate purpose which then resulted in the extinguishment of the native title, under those circumstances an appropriately larger quantum of compensation would be payable. In that particular context, I do not think a second bite is excluded by the legislation as it presently stands.

In practice one would envisage that the usual situation, particularly with the incentives now provided by this clause, would be that an acquisition would only take place in circumstances where it is proposed to use the land for some purpose pursuant to the acquisition. As a result, the compensation payment could be determined in one go, reflecting the fact of the extinguishment that has occurred thereby.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever there has been law making on the run, I have just witnessed it! On a number of occasions I have seen the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) lean over the dispatch box to confer with the Clerks. Where is it spelt out in the bill that there can be instalments in terms of compensation being paid? I would like to put the reverse case.

PARA.TAB: For example, with the Newlands development in Western Australia, there was a program over about 20 years when it was well known that that land was going to be released. The state has made that decision. It is going to proceed with that and extinguish the native title. What if the community or individuals or whoever it might be turned around and said, `We know that is being turned in these cases into conditional purchase land. We would rather get our compensation and, for example, buy up a couple of those blocks and go into farming'.

The government is creating one hell of a situation. It is typical of the approach to this bill. There have been so many amendments, so many changes. I have lost track with the 6s and 6As, 9s and 9As, 33s and 33As and running through this whole process. It is about time the minister woke up to himself, postponed this bill and dealt with it properly. However, I know the minister is not going to do that.

It is an absolute disgrace the way this is being done. We have just seen another typical example. The honourable senator did not have a clue about what was going on then. I sat here and watched him and I saw decision making on the run. This process once again has not been thought through properly. This is going to have ramifications for a whole host of people, not the least being those people in that situation where a compulsory acquisition is made, the Aboriginals themselves. I have to say that the honourable senator has not thought this through.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is a little bit unfair from Senator Crane. Earlier on we were debating clause 47 and, no doubt, the honourable senator retains a very clear recollection of what the clause says. What it says, among other things, is that compensation is only payable under this act once for acts that are essentially the same. When an act is not essentially the same but consists of two quite distinct component parts, namely, a fact of acquisition and then the taking of a step pursuant to that acquisition, it is only the taking of the step that has consequences for the extinguishment. There are, in effect, two successive acts that are linked but are by no means the same.

PARA.TAB: I am just drawing out the logical consequences of this particular legislation. There is a consistency of principle that lies behind this, and I think that should be perfectly evident. In the kind of compulsory acquisition for conditional purchase scheme of the kind that honourable senators are referring to, it is perfectly appropriate to contemplate a situation where the acquisition occurs and then the conditional purchase sales of the land underneath it is set in train in the way that is being talked about. You survey the land; you mark it up; you subdivide it and you start selling it, and that would constitute a step taken for the purpose of implementing the stated purpose of the acquisition. Under those circumstances, the whole thing would work in the way that honourable senators opposite seem to think would be inhibited.

Just because honourable senators are putting questions to us that I have to take advice on and contemplate with my adviser to make sure that I am saying the right thing does not mean that we are making it up as we go along. It is perfectly true that I am turning my mind to a number of these issues for the first time. Honourable senators would be surprised how many of them I am addressing for the first time as I deal with them in the course of this debate—in fact, they would not be surprised at all. It is probably pretty self-evident. The point is that there are answers to all these questions that are being put to us.

This is not a slaphappy approach to legislation. It is a complex legislative task, but honourable senators ought not be too confused by the bits of paper. I could lend honourable senators some coloured folders. That might help for a start. They could keep the different amendments in those and have a master sheet for each of the three parties and one for supplementary things. The only amendments that we are taking any notice of are the ones with a notation on the top right-hand corner. They are the ones that are all referred to in the running sheet, with only a couple of exceptions. Really, there is no justification for Senator Crane's confusion. If he is confused, he should not blame others for that particular congenital state.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit to being confused. I just walked in on this one. The Minister spoke about compensation for acquisition and then it was mentioned for subdivision, I think. Surely, if acquisition is paid for, unless I have missed something, that is it. It seems to me that that is it. I would like an explanation as to why that is not right, if it is not right.

—I have already given one explanation. I think Senator Panizza was out doing something, no doubt very important, when I did. The compensation that is payable is not confined, under the legislation, to one bite. You can only get one bite for the same act but if there are different acts that occur, you are able to come back and get successive compensation for each of them. If the acquisition by itself does not succeed in accomplishing the extinguishment of your title, you can make a claim for compensation. But if you can go on fully enjoying your title as a practical matter and it is not extinguished as a legal matter, you are not likely to get very much compensation. However, if the effect of the acquisition plus the act which is taken pursuant to the acquisition is to actually extinguish your title, then you really do deserve a decent whack of compensation and you can come back and get it. In the normal course of events you would expect those two stages to be collapsed together into one, but it is possible to envisage a circumstance where they are spread out over time. If this operates as a disincentive to compulsory acquisitions that do not result in actual action being taken, that is no bad thing.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette has referred a number of times to acquisitions by the states. I want it understood that this is not a clause in any way confined to acquisitions by the states; it does apply equally to compulsory acquisitions by the Commonwealth. So, if there is any constraint imposed upon complete freedom of action by governments, it is one that we are also imposing upon ourselves, not just upon the states, and I think that ought to be understood, in fairness.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have another question for the minister in light of his previous answer, and I will use the same example: at what point in the process of compulsory acquisition would extinguishment occur? Would it be when surveying started, or would it be when the block was allocated, or a farm was allocated? At what point in time does this click into gear?
—Your memory might be better than mine, but I seem to recall you asking me that question about 25 minutes ago.
—No.

—Maybe I do you an injustice; maybe it was someone else. The truth of the matter is that that cannot be identified with absolute precision. It is just an act done pursuant to the acquisition, an act done to actually put into effect the public purpose. It is a matter for judgment, and ultimately, I guess, it is a matter for the courts, if it is contested, as to what constitutes such an act. All I am saying is that an act done in good faith to advance the purpose of the acquisition and which takes us down that particular path would be one sufficient to, I believe, accomplish the extinguishment. If it is just some notional, cosmetic thing like pegging out a site and pretending that one has done something for the implementation of the purpose, and nothing is done thereafter—
—I said survey.

—Commission a survey, or something. By itself, if that was not followed up by further action, if it was just a little bit of an exercise to tuck the acquisition into bed and secure the extinguishment but with no real intention of going any further than that, that might not be enough. I cannot add anything to that. It is just a matter for determination on all the facts of the particular case.

—Maybe I could address the same question to Senator Chamarette, in view of the fact that it is her amendment. Perhaps she could enlighten us as to what her intention was in terms of when public land was acquired—I will just use that example, and we are not going to have an argument about the release of new land, are we, because I am using it as an example. When would Senator Chamarette see it clicking into gear, and in this particular case, if the particular people wished to take all the compensation in the first instance rather than having it staggered, would she have a problem with that?
—I will endeavour to answer. It is a hypothetical question, but the amendment that we have proposed—
—No, it's not.

—It is hypothetical because it will be different in every case. If a government compulsorily acquires some land that happens to be native title land, it depends what the purpose is, and how quickly it is intending to act on it, how soon or late the native title may be extinguished. The compensation will only be paid to the extent that native title is impaired or extinguished and at the point at which it is impaired or extinguished, and presumably the government is perfectly capable of negotiating that with the native titleholders.

—I am trying to come to terms with this amendment and I might just address the minister in the first instance. With this amendment, would it not be necessary for there to be any development, in the case of crown land where there is native title, that the Crown would firstly acquire the land for the purposes of a third party and thereby would extinguish native title—
—In some jurisdictions it is permissible for a third party.

—For a third party, and that is the problem. That is what I am getting at. Can we just take this through: if the Crown wants to provide a piece of land to a third party for development and it is crown land and there is native title, it acquires the land and there is a procedure in the bill for that. That extinguishes native title and it goes through a procedure and that allows the third party to develop the land. But is not this amendment thwarting that process by the application of the non-extinguishment principle? Could the minister answer that?
—What was the last question?
—What I am saying is that, where there is vacant crown land which is subject to native title, the Crown—
—For public purposes.
—Say, it is crown land and it is subject to native title and the Crown wants to make that available to a third party for a development—
—It is not every jurisdiction in which you could do that.

—Right. By the compulsory acquisition it extinguishes native title, but we will leave aside arguments about compensation. There is a process, of course, involved in that and I think the bill provides for that. And then the development proceeds. With this amendment, does the inclusion of the non-extinguishment principle not thwart that process? The non-extinguishment principle is that the native title subsists whilst the act is occurring. Could the minister answer that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not thwart it because the proposed amendment, subparagraph (aa), says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . nothing in this Act prevents any act that is done in giving effect to the purpose of the acquisition from extinguishing the native title rights and interests . . .

There are some jurisdictions where a compulsory acquisition can be made for third party property development purposes. That is not the case in every jurisdiction in Australia; some jurisdictions confine compulsory acquisition strictly to public purposes, although that is sometimes rather loosely defined as well. In those parts of the country where one can compulsorily acquire crown land for the purpose of investing it in third persons—for property development or commercial development or other reasons—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Local government is another context again. As I understand the operation of this amendment, where one is compulsorily acquiring some land for those sorts of purposes—where that is permissible under state or territory or Commonwealth legislation—what would happen is that the acquisition itself would not secure the extinguishment of the native title. As soon as the legitimate purpose to which the land is to be put—albeit that it was for the purpose of private development; if the state law in question allows that then it is a legitimate purpose of the acquisition—is implemented by the vesting of the title in question in the third person, at that point that would be an act done to give effect to the purpose of the acquisition. At that point and at that point only, the extinguishment would occur.

PARA.TAB: Again, the principle applies that, if one acquires the land for an acceptable purpose under the state legislation in question and one does nothing about implementing that purpose, the extinguishment does not occur; but if one does do something about implementing that purpose, extinguishment occurs. It would occur, in my perception, at that time of the vesting of the title in the other person.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is then saying, at the time of the acquisition, non-extinguishment applies; at the time of the vesting, there is an extinguishment of native title because that is (aa). Is that the position, before I proceed?
—Yes.

—In between those two points there is a situation where native title subsists for the purposes of the non-extinguishment principle. Where is the benefit to the native titleholder, in view of the fact that as soon as the vesting occurs it will be extinguished anyway? The native titleholder cannot do anything.

—The benefit is that that then attracts, certainly the compensation provisions; and it would be a reasonable whack of compensation that would be payable if the title in question that exists is extinguished. Can I just make it clear that this legislation is not designed to inhibit compulsory acquisition for legitimate purposes, particularly for public purposes. That is my idea of what is a legitimate compulsory acquisition. But in some jurisdictions, compulsory acquisition can take place for private property development purposes as well. I guess that occurred a lot of times in the history of this country and we cannot gainsay that; it is still occurring in some places.

PARA.TAB: If a compulsory acquisition strategy is adopted then there is nothing that the native titleholder can do about it except, of course, be reasonably compensated. That is a new thing that has occurred as a result of Mabo and as a result of the recognition of native title; and as a result of the statutory regime we are putting in place to make sure it all works in practice and that people do not go off and have to litigate by themselves in the courts without any statutory framework to help them. That is what we are doing. But, at the end of the day, this is one of the balances that is involved.

Compulsory acquisition can occur and, provided things happen under that, then native title is lost. That is unfortunate from the native titleholder's point of view, but there it is. They are the other interests that have to be taken into account. The extra benefit that is being conferred by this amendment is to make clear that, if compulsory acquisition is going to occur, at least it should occur for the purported purpose and not just be some device in order to lock up native title land and, in effect, put some very big cloud over the native title land in question. At least it has succeeded in doing that, albeit that if one does go down that track the title in question is lost at the end of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Flowing from that, would it not then mean that the native titleholder, during that period of the non-extinguishment principle, gets the compensation? The government then applies it for another purpose for which it was acquired, thereby coming squarely within this provision. By virtue of paragraph (aa), the native title would be revived, would it not, because it was not acquired for the purpose? The vesting did not occur. So the native titleholder would then have a revival of native title plus the compensation.

—On a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman: it is a Greens' amendment and, as I understand it, it is referring to clause 22, which is compulsory acquisition for public purposes only. It is clause 25 that refers to compulsory acquisition for a third party, so the discussion is not relevant to this particular point.
—It is just the point that in some jurisdictions under the compulsory acquisition legislation it can be done for third party purposes.
—In clause 25.

—But this is in clause 22 as well which speaks of a compulsory acquisition act. What I am saying is that it is possible in some jurisdictions that that can be done, not only for public works, but for vesting in third parties. I thought the government had agreed with that.
—It can in this, too, but it is in clause 25.

—Clause 25 is the main thrust for acquiring property for third parties but, in this particular one, I believe that third parties can be included in some jurisdictions as well. That is where I understood the government was in agreement with that interpretation.

—I think Senator Ellison is right in that respect. Clause 25 is about the third person acquisition situations, but clause 22 is about both. It is generally expressed; it covers public purposes and other forms of compulsory acquisition as well. That is just the way the thing is drafted at the moment. There is still quite a lot achieved by the Democrats' amendment, and it is achieved also in the context of acquisition for third party purposes in those situations where that is permissible. But, certainly, clause 22 is applicable to both situations, as we read it. One would want it applicable to both situations, and one would want the non-extinguishment principle to apply to the last possible minute in those jurisdictions where acquisition is made for third persons. He ought not to resist too much the notion that it is applicable to a section 25 situation.

—I want to go back to the point I was making earlier when Senator Chamarette made the point of clarification. During that non-extinguishment period, between the acquisition and the vesting, the native titleholder gets compensation. If the government then uses the land for a different purpose, the native title is revived. That is triggered because the vesting did not occur: it was not the vesting for the purpose for which it was acquired. So the native titleholder could end up with the full native title, plus the compensation. I think this is a problem and I would like an answer on it.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—We will have to wait until the minister comes back. He is consulting widely at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should address my question to Senator Chamarette. I raise this in a manner that is not critical of compensation in any way: that is clearly recognised by the High Court. The question is whether it sets out to do what it sets out to do. In relation to that point on acquisition, the non-extinguishment principle applies and compensation is then available to the native titleholder. The government is then able to pull a swiftie, and use it for a purpose other than that for which it was acquired and the non-extinguishment principle then applies. The native title is then revived because (aa) states that only the act for which it was acquired extinguishes the native title. So if a third person, say, public works, uses it then it extinguishes native title. This amendment is being brought in to safeguard against governments acquiring properties for a specific purpose, sorting out the native title question and then using it for something else.

PARA.TAB: Whilst it is used for nothing, there is no problem. The native titleholder has the compensation. The non-extinguishment principle applies and native title subsists. But, as soon as anything is done with the land, which is not the acquired purpose, then native title is fully revived.
