Therefore, the native titleholder could conceivably get the best of both worlds: the native title and the compensation. I do not know whether that was the intention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this exposes the problem that this legislation has in terms of the freedom it gives to states to compulsorily acquire. There may be some flaws in the way in which states take up that power. However, if they are in a situation where they have extinguished native title, and paid compensation, and they do not use it appropriately, it is appropriate for it to be challenged. I am sure there is no way in which that challenge, and the revival of native title, will not be able to take into consideration that some compensation has already been paid. It is simply a matter for the state or federal government which handled the compulsory acquisition to account for their behaviour and respond appropriately. Senator Ellison says that the native titleholder may gain twice. I believe it will only be appropriate for them to gain twice if there has been a genuine need for them to gain twice. That can be determined on a case by case basis.

—The state could acquire the land for a public purpose, say, a school, and then decide that it was not feasible to have this school. A developer might come along and want to build a university on that land. The state could decide that it is in the best interests of the community to build that university there and the developer then pays for it. In that situation, the native title would be revived as soon as they did anything that was not the purpose for which the land was acquired. Would that not be the case? That is what (aa) says.

—I believe paragraph (aa) says that no native title would be extinguished if it were acquired for the purpose of a school, no school was built, but a university was. At the point where the university expanded to such a degree that it was incompatible with whatever the existing native title right was, compensation would be paid for the extinguishment of the native title.

—As a follow-up to the example that my colleague Senator Ellison gave, and from what I understood of Senator Chamarette's answer, she does not see the school and the university as being incompatible in terms of development. These are legitimate questions, and I ask the honourable senator not to screw up her face like that. I am just trying to establish in point of fact what this means.

PARA.TAB: To give another example, if some land were acquired by the state which was designated for housing, and some time later down the track it was decided that it was not suitable or it was not required for housing, or whatever the reason might be, and it was decided that it be rezoned for five-acre urban/rural farms, would that be compatible or would it have to go further? Where would the line be drawn in terms of what is compatible and what is not compatible?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is going to vary from case to case. The main point of the amendment is that at the point where it becomes incompatible, it becomes incompatible, the native title is extinguished and compensation is paid. There is no prior definition or plan required for that. It is simply to the point where, whatever the activity is for which the land has been compulsorily acquired, it becomes inconsistent with the continuation of native title, then that is the point at which it would be extinguished.

—This is a classic example of making legislation on the run. The whole issue has not been thought through. There is no clear idea about what precisely it means. We have not been able to establish that. We have been told some maybes. With regard to the land act and pastoral leases, I understand from the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to a question from Senator Ellison that it could well extend to that.

PARA.TAB: Acquisition or resumption powers exist in terms of conservation. I am only familiar with those that exist in Western Australia with the land act and the soil conservation act. If, for a particular reason such as drought, a portion of a pastoral lease could be reclaimed and closed up or resumed for conservation reasons, for example, could that revert under this clause?

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Extinguishment means extinguishment. If the effect of the granting of the lease has been to accomplish the extinguishment, as it certainly would be if it was granted pursuant to a compulsory acquisition strategy of the kind that we are talking about here, that would certainly be the statutory effect. The granting of the lease would achieve an extinguishment, if there was a subsequent resumption or reclamation of part or all of that lease. It would not help the native titleholders. Their interests would have been extinguished by the initial step.

—Senator Alston raised some very valid points earlier on. I do not think the minister has answered them fully to convince us, or to convince me, that double-dipping cannot occur. Surely, if compensation is paid for extinguishment under acquisition of native title, how can anyone come back for a second go?
—Have a look at clause 47.
—All right.

—That answers the honourable senator's question. Compensation is only payable under this act once for acts that are essentially the same. If the act in question, the acquisition and the subsequent extinguishment run together, constitute the same thing at the same time, there will be only one compensation payable. If the acquisition occurs and then subsequently extinguishment occurs, it is certainly arguable that that would constitute two separate acts for two successive stages of two successive events. One cannot imagine that the compensation would be the same in each case. As I said, a reasonably large sum of compensation could be expected at the point of the extinguishment of the title, but not much compensation could be at all for a mere acquisition that did not interfere with the enjoyment of the native title in question.
—And the second one would be only an increment?
—It would be only in the nature of an increment. Yes, I think that is the point.

—Before we close debate on this amendment, I have to put a couple of things on the public record. The first thing that I want to put on the public record—and I say this to the government and the Greens, and anyone else who might vote for it—is that this is an outrageous attack on Western Australia in terms of its capacity to develop.
—Ha, ha!

—The honourable senator can smile smugly all she likes. I think most people know by now that Western Australia has about 40 per cent of the crown land in this country. This amendment will not only affect that development but I believe it will affect a lot of Aboriginal communities in Western Australia to their detriment. It is going to stop growth, where there is an opportunity for growth. It is going to have an impact on the mining industry. It is going to have a serious impact on the development of the Ord River. It is going to make it virtually impossible for the allocation of any more pastoral leases in Western Australia. It is going to make it almost impossible, if ever the need arose, for the development of what is known as the Johnston Lakes area in Western Australia. This has been identified as one of the few areas left in the world suitable for agriculture but it was not developed at that particular time. I have to say to the government and to Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts that they might think tonight that they are going to have a victory, but that victory will be at a cost. The cost will be the economic wellbeing of all Western Australians.
—What about the indigenous people?

—Senator Kernot can mumble all she likes. Indigenous people enjoy the development and the wealth which are created. Maybe she should go across and talk to some of the elders, as I have done in Western Australia. It might help if Senator Kernot hops down in her appropriate seat before interjecting and I see her mumbling with her hand all over her mouth.

PARA.TAB: I just want to put on the public record that this particular act done on the run tonight is going to have serious implications for the living standards of all Australians, indigenous people and others who have come later. The minister has made this decision on the run tonight. It is a decision that he will regret, and I am sure that if he had run this past his resource ministers they would not be agreeing with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a bit to what Senator Crane has said because the agriculture areas in the main wheat belt areas of Western Australia are now on average about 80 to 90 years old. There has been very little land developed in the 1980s. The big development was in the 1960s, adding on to what was done between the two world wars.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that this bill put together on the run to get it through before Christmas will prevent extension. Senator Crane is worried about the Ord River—and so am I—but I think the Ord River scheme will result in high enough producing sort of land, contrary to the expectations that were around on some sides of politics when it was developed. It is doing very well now and I believe that the Ord River will return enough for all of that compensation to be afforded in time.

The extension of the wheat belt areas of Western Australia has been put in jeopardy because, as I said, the average age is probably 80 to 100 years so we preclude their expansion by this legislation. Eternity is a long time—not from this day because this bill will not pass this day. It will not pass this side of February the way we are going and justifiably so because we are not getting enough explanations. The enactment of this bill will prevent the development of the wheat belt areas, the agricultural areas. As Senator Crane mentioned, the Johnston Lakes are certainly the only good wheat growing country left to be developed in Western Australia although he extends it to others.

We are making a very big decision, and I hope that the ones who have put it forward are the ones who are supporting it. I know Senator Chamarette was laughing a bit earlier on but I defy either of the Greens to point it out on the map, let alone to have been there and know its potential or to have read anything appropriate about it.

There has been a lot of work done by the Western Australian department of agriculture going back as far as the Teakle report in 1927 on that area. It was only for reasons of long distances from rail and other modes of transport that it was not developed in the 1960s. Of course, the non-development of the 1960s was always helped by the Labor government in the late-1950s that had its eyes closed to progress, otherwise it would have been going ahead long before now.

All those who are supporting this legislation have to look at what they are doing to the future of Western Australia because, once we put legislation into action, it is there forever and a day, as far as I am concerned, and it is going to bring a very cost not only to Western Australia but to the rest of Australia in the production it will prevent and the tax it will not raise. It will also inhibit the development of potential mining areas. I hope honourable senators will remember this when we remind them.

I do not know how long these two Green senators from Western Australia have been here—one has been here a bit longer than the other—but perhaps both of them one day may do something that is for the good of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like resign.
—The best thing that they could do for Western Australia would be to resign. I am looking forward to the day they actually do something for Western Australia instead of just vote it down.

—At the risk of traversing the same ground once too often, can I simply ask the minister whether he agrees that this amendment seeks to ensure that native title rights are not automatically extinguished by the compulsory acquisition of land but will have to await the subsequent transfer of the land by the Crown to a third party, so that it is only when it is actually transferred for the purpose for which it was acquired that the native title would be extinguished. If that is right, is it not also the fact that this bill does not allow such a grant unless native title has already been extinguished? So do we not have an impossible situation where the Crown can no longer grant various pastoral and mining leases?
—Why do you say that the bill does not allow it until the extinguishment has actually occurred?
—Because one cannot grant a lease with native title rights attached to it.

—I think, with respect, Senator Alston has mistaken the effect of (aa). The vesting of the lease in a third party would itself accomplish the extinguishment. There are varying kinds of situations in which acquisitions are made. One situation is acquisition for the purpose of vesting the land in one or more third parties. That is one situation. There are lots of other situations, public purposes and so on, where it remains vested in Crown control. But in those circumstances where it is acquired for the purpose of vesting in a third party, the act of vesting in the third party would itself accomplish the extinguishment, and that is the point of (aa) in this particular context.
—The act would constitute the extinguishment, but it depends on whether you are able to grant the act unless the title has already been extinguished, so you cannot do it contemporaneously—

—You are making that up as you go along, with respect. You have got to be able to grant a clear title but, if the fact of vesting the title in the third person is to accomplish the extinguishment, which would be achieved by the statutory provision, nothing in this act prevents any act that is done in giving effect to the purposes of this acquisition from extinguishing the native title rights and interests.
—So you accept that it would be an impermissible future act to purport to grant a lease that had native title rights attached to it?
—In the absence of (aa), yes, but (aa) makes it permissible. That is the point of (aa).

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 23, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 24.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move, in relation to clause 24—

—I believe that that is the incorrect order; it should be clause 25 next, under the running sheet, because 24 comes under a different heading. We are still on the right to negotiate, and that is, as I understand it—
—Sorry; Senator Ellison has misunderstood that. I am not pursuing the amendment to clause 25: I made that clear at the commencement of the cognate debate.
—I understood the chairman to say we were dealing with clause 24 itself.
—That is correct. We have finished clause 22, which we have just voted on, as amended. We voted on clause 23, as amended, and we are now up to clause 24. We will get to clause 25 straight after that.
—So are we only dealing with the amendment to clause 24?

—We are now dealing with the amendment to clause 24 and, when that amendment has been dealt with, we will then vote upon clause 24, as amended—just as we have been dealing with them all night. I do not know whether you want to create a new precedent procedurally, but that is what we have been doing.

—I am not trying to be difficult, but we were on 22, and suddenly we are on 24. There was so much noise in this place, with people getting up and moving around. Now I just want to raise the matter as to whether or not—
—Are you trying to avoid clause 24? Is that the purpose of this?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—I will outline what happened. We had an amendment by Senator Chamarette which was passed by the chamber, and that was to clause 22. So the question then was that clause 22, as amended, be agreed to, which was passed. Clause 23 has already been dealt with when we were dealing with clause 19, and it was amended there. So I put the question that clause 23, as amended, be agreed to. That then brought us to 24, and I said that the question now is that clause 24 stand as printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I want to take a point of order. I am not trying to be difficult. It has been a long, hard night, and we have kept our humours reasonably well through a difficult time. I find it absolutely objectionable, when I am trying to get a point of clarification of where we are at on the running sheet, that Senator Kernot starts interjecting nonsense like that. In the heat of debate, I can put up with an interjection as well as anyone can; but, when I am trying to clarify a matter with the chairman, it is totally objectionable and rude for her to do that.
—I apologise.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 24, page 15, lines 12 to 28, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Renewals and extensions of certain acts

PARA.TAB: "24.(1) If an act is a future renewal act (defined in subsections (3) and (4)):

TAB.TAB: (a)the act is valid; and
(b)the non-extinguishment principle applies to the act; and

(c)if any native title holders would be entitled to compensation under subsection 16(2) for the act on the assumption that it was a past act mentioned in that subsection—the native title holders are entitled to compensation for the act in accordance with Division 5.

PARA.TAB: "(2)The native title holders may recover the compensation from:

TAB.TAB: (a)if the act is attributable to the Commonwealth—the Crown in right of the Commonwealth; or
(b)if the act is attributable to a State or Territory—the Crown in right of the State or Territory.

PARA.TAB: "(3) A future act is a `future renewal act' for the purposes of this section if:

TAB.TAB: (a)it takes place:
(i)in exercise of a legally enforceable right created by the making, amendment or repeal of legislation before 1 July 1993 or by any other act done before 1 January 1994; or

(ii)in giving effect to, or otherwise because of, an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking made or given (other than in legislation) in good faith before 1 January 1994, and of which there is written evidence created at or about the time the offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking was made; and
(b)it is not the making, amendment or repeal of legislation.
"(4)A future act (the `later act') is also a `future renewal act' for the purposes of this section if:
(a)an act (the `earlier act') that took place before 1 January 1994 created interests in a person and the later act creates interests in:
(i)the same person; or
(ii)another person who has acquired the interests of the first person (by assignment, succession or otherwise);

SPEECH.PARA: in relation to the whole or part of the land or waters to which the earlier act relates; and

TAB.TAB: (b)the interests created by the later act take effect before or immediately after the interests created by the earlier act cease to have effect; and
(c)the interests created by the later act permit activities of a similar kind to those permitted by the earlier act.
"(5)Subsection (4) does not apply if:
(a)the earlier act was the creation of a non-proprietary interest in relation to land or waters and the later act is the creation of a proprietary interest in land or waters; or
(b)the earlier act was the creation of a proprietary interest in land or waters and the later act is the creation of a larger proprietary interest in land or waters; or
(c)if the earlier act contains a reservation or condition for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders—the later act does not contain the same reservation or condition; or
(d)the earlier act or the later act is the making, amendment or repeal of legislation.

PARA.TAB: Note 1:Because of paragraph 218(1)(c), an act that does not affect native title cannot be a future renewal act and therefore is not prevented by this Act.
Note 2:Subsections (3), (4) and (5) correspond to subsections 213(3), (4) and (6) respectively. The examples in subsections 213(5), (7) and (8) will be correspondingly applicable.".

SPEECH.PARA: This is quite an important amendment. It is all about providing certainty. We have given a clear commitment that the rights of existing property holders would be protected, and, consistent with this, this amendment will ensure that valid interests will be able to be renewed on a similar basis as invalid interests which are being validated.

PARA.TAB: The amendment makes it abundantly clear that any compensation obligations arising from the renewal of such leases will be recoverable from the relevant government. The amendment will ensure that the holders of valid interests are treated no less favourably than the holders of invalid leases which are subsequently validated.

The amendment does also provide protection to native titleholders. Clause 24, as amended by this government amendment, does not operate to extinguish native title. That is something I want to emphasise particularly to the Greens and the Democrats, who I know have some particular concerns about this amendment.

Let me just explain why that is so. To the extent that native title was extinguished by the original grant, the renewal obviously will not affect native title. Indeed, it does not, in that sense, come within the ambit of the bill at all. Note 1 to be attached to clause 24, as to be inserted by this amendment, makes that clear. Note 1 says:

SPEECH.PARA: Because of paragraph 218 (1)(c), an act that does not affect native title cannot be a future renewal act and therefore is not prevented by this Act.

However, in the event that native title rights were not extinguished by the original grant and do happen to coexist with the lease in question, say the pastoral lease, the renewal of the grant will not extinguish that native title.

PARA.TAB: I will just make that clear again for the benefit of Greens and Democrats: the renewal of the grant, to the extent that it has not previously been extinguished, will not accomplish that extinguishment. What will happen is that the statutory rights in question under the lease, or whatever is in question, will prevail for the term of the interest. The native title right will not be extinguished. It will not be able to be enjoyed to its full extent, or perhaps at all, for the duration of the renewed interest in question, but it will not be extinguished. It will be able to be effectively deployed at the conclusion of the period in question.

The key point to notice about all this, as I began by saying, is that this is all about certainty; the amendment does provide certainty to holders of valid interests who, under most credible interpretations of the High Court decision, will already have extinguished native title.

The final point is that this amendment has not just come out of nowhere; it was the product of concern expressed to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, as Senator Ellison will no doubt recall. Recommendation (c) on page 26 of that Senate committee report said that the bill should address the concern that there may be impediments to renewals or re-grants of valid leases—for example, pastoral—where the renewals or re-grants are in the same terms as the original lease.

There was a degree of anomaly felt that, while the legislation was very explicit indeed about what the status would be when renewals came up for validated grants, there was no similar precision or certainty about what would happen with renewals or extensions of valid grants. Of course, many more cases are valid grants than there are ever likely to be established of invalid ones.

The Senate committee was concerned to establish some certainty here. This is an issue about which the NFF and the mining industry have been particularly concerned. The government regards their case as a valid one. We support it and accordingly we do support this amendment. We hope and trust that those on the other side of the chamber who have hitherto been reluctant to support clear-cut provisions designed to be in the interests of industry and to achieve an appropriate balance in the overall shape of the legislation as a result will take this opportunity, even if they have not taken the other opportunities that have been presented to them today, to improve the bill from an industry perspective. I invite them to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the negotiation rights of native titleholders at the time of renewal or extension of valid grants?

—They can negotiate with the government about compensation. They can claim non-monetary compensation. That is about it. This is not something that especially helps the cause of native titleholders. That is understood. That is acknowledged. That is of concern to a number of Aboriginal groups. They would like this amendment not to proceed. I understand that that is Senator Kernot's position. I understand that that is the Green's position. I understand why. However, at the end of the day this bill has to produce an appropriate balance of all interests concerned.

PARA.TAB: What we are talking about here are not future grants in the sense of new things that will happen. By definition, we are talking about renewals or various kinds of extensions, in different contexts, which are not necessarily pursuant to a formal legal right of renewal. In the real world of business, commerce and Australian national interest, it is important that, for example, a mine that has not completed resource extraction be allowed to conclude that task.

There is a competing interest here. It is a stark and obvious competing interest. I am not pretending for a moment that native titleholders who still possess their native title rights, if they have not been extinguished, are going to be well off in this particular situation. I am not suggesting that they are going to be much better off than they are at the moment while the right continues to be enjoyed. That is something we have to acknowledge. It is pointless to try to deny or hide it.

However, the point that I put as strongly as I can on the part of the government is that there does have to be an overall balance. That has been accepted by Aboriginal leaders. It has been accepted by others in the context of the whole question of acting to remove concern about the possible invalidity of the need for validation and the extinguishment that flows from that. It is not especially palatable, but it has been accepted as part of the overall balance of interests.

There are very real national interests involved in the pastoral industry and the mining industry to ensure continuity of expectations in the future. We believe this particular legislation should address those sorts of interests, those sorts of concerns, as well as doing the job that we basically want it to do, which is to bring some justice and morality and recognition to Aboriginal people's rights for the first time in 200 years.

It is a question of a knife-edged balance of interests. The government has had to make a hard decision about this one. It is not going to be a very popular decision. I know that very well from the discussions I have had in the last few days, but that is the government's position and I have explained the reasons for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) said that the government has made a knife-edged decision and that it is looking at balancing the interests of various parties. I think the balance is too far one way. An example that has been given to me is of leases at Gove where there is a 42-year lease and a 42-year option—a total of 84 years. During that time, native titleholders will have absolutely no say in what happens on their land. They will have no entitlement to approach the mining company to seek any form of negotiation. That postpones a very important part of the whole process that we have to look at in this country in terms of sharing the land.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that requiring negotiation is anything like the right of veto. I do not believe that it provokes the uncertainty that the mining companies fear. I understand why the decision was made, but I want to put on the record the fact that it is not acceptable that these very long leases can be extended, in perpetuity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Cheryl!
—What does Senator Boswell mean by, `Come on'? I know exactly what I am talking about and it is not fair that they can be extended in perpetuity in this way.

—Is it correct that under the government's amendment a lease may be automatically renewed in this way, even though the existing lease does not have a renewal clause? In other words, any lease can be renewed in this way.

—Yes, this amendment does apply in situations where the formal, legal right of renewal has been exhausted. What we are talking about is simply a presumption of continuity. That is one of the effects of this lease. Again, that has perhaps a tough impact, and that point has been made to me very strongly by some of the Aboriginal leaders, rather in the way that Senator Kernot has just put it. When a mine has had a life of 84 years, is it not about time the Aboriginal interest came in and had its proper or legitimate say?

PARA.TAB: I understand the point. All I can say is that, when we are talking about vital national resources and interests and we are talking about a right that has not been enjoyed because of a grant that has been made in the past, this is one occasion where the balance comes down the other way. But Senator Spindler is perfectly right in reading the amendment as having that effect; I do not deny that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans told us when he withdrew government amendment No. 15 that government amendment No. 14 had the same effect. That is not the case; it is not the case for two reasons. The first is that government amendment No. 14, in so far as it is concerned in subclause (4) of the new clause 24, only applies to acts that took the original act which took place before 1 January 1994. That is not the same as the rights which were proposed under paragraph (c) of the amended clause 25 because it related to the extension of a right which could have been created after 1 January 1994. So No. 14 is a much more curtailed version, in that respect, of No. 15.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 14 is also a much more curtailed version of amendment No. 15 because, in subclause (5) of the new clause 24, paragraph (d) excludes from the operation of subsection (4) a right which arose out of an earlier act or a later act which was `the making, amendment or repeal of legislation'. That is different from paragraph (c)(ii) of amendment No. 15, where `an option or a right of extension or renewal was created by the lease, contract or other thing whose grant or making created the right'. Under amendment No. 15, I believe it would have been possible to renew a mining right created by statute, or a right created by statute that facilitated mining, but that is not possible under amendment No. 14. I think that the government is failing quite substantially.

There are other reasons why amendment No. 14 to clause 24 is beneficial. They relate to the renewal of valid pastoral leases where co-existence may occur. For those reasons, I indicate to the chamber that Senator McGauran, Senator Sandy Macdonald and I will be supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of comments on what Senator O'Chee has just said. Subclause (3) of the government's amendment clause says, first of all, that this clause covers `a legally enforceable right created by the making, amendment or repeal of legislation before 1 July 1993'. So that statutory rights created are caught by that provision and can be renewed.

PARA.TAB: Further, in the next subsection it does not mention the term `lease'. The minister has used the word `lease', but it does not say that. It says, `an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking made or given'. I cannot think of another provision in law that is as widely drawn as that. It virtually includes any written document, including the back of an envelope on which someone has scribbled a brief agreement, and they can renew it under this particular section. Does the minister have any comment on that?

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I will respond to Senator O'Chee's question. I will then respond to what Senator Spindler has said. The first thing to appreciate is that, under amendment No. 15, clause 25(2)(c)(ii), which we are no longer proceeding with, the subject matter is effectively preserved in clause 25(2)(c). So whatever was substantively achieved by the amendment, subparagraph (c)(ii) is still there in the existing paragraph (c) of clause 25.

PARA.TAB: As to the reference to the rights existing on 1 January 1994, that is to be compared with the language of amendment No. 14 which mentions in clause 24(4)(a) acts taking place before 1 January 1994. For all practical purposes, that amounts to pretty much the same thing. Rights existing as at 1 January 1994 are pursuant to the reference in the proposed new clause 24(4)(a) to acts taking place before 1 January 1994. In terms of Senator O'Chee's concern about the abandonment of amendment No. 15, the points I made earlier about the substance of that proposed amendment being sufficiently incorporated in the proposed new clause 24 still hold.

As to Senator Spindler's point about the particular business of options, to the extent that he was concerned about the provision in subclause 3(a)(ii) about offers, commitments, arrangements or undertakings made or given other than in legislation in good faith before 1 January 1994, and of which there is written evidence and so on, let me frankly say that I understand that concern. That is a rather widely drawn provision. It is important that in practice it be construed and applied by the courts in a way that reflects commercial reality and not sham transactions, but I believe that the courts would be perfectly capable and willing to so construe it.

The courts will be assisted in that respect by the reference to `in good faith' in terms of the subparagraph in question. I think that will be construed to reflect commercial reality. What this whole amendment is about is reflecting and protecting commercial reality. It is expressly designed to serve an industry or a national interest purpose in this respect. It does not particularly help Aboriginal native titleholders, but nor does it hinder their interests. I go back to the point I made in introducing the clause: whatever else this clause does that people do not like, it certainly does not do anything to extinguish native title rights. To that extent, we believe we have preserved and maintained the balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that, in terms of the clause that it replaces, the subsection is entitled `Renewal under pre-1 January 1994 right to renew', and it basically covers or endeavours to cover pastoral leases. Could the minister explain to the Senate what leases it covers and what leases it does not cover, and why, in particular, the government has chosen to exclude some lease situations which are not covered?

—My understanding is that the clause is not limited in the way that Senator Crane suggests, so accordingly the question does not arise. It is not limited to leases or any particular class of lease, it is appropriate to interests generally in land. If Senator Crane reads the clause carefully, I think he will see that.

—I believe that in the amendment there is in fact a restriction, in the sense that, for those states whose leasehold is covered by legislation which has to be amended or renewed, there is no provision to cover those particular states. Is that not correct?
—Sorry, could you repeat that last bit, please?
—I believe that in those states where the leaseholds have to be renewed by amending an act or creating a new act, they are not covered, and there is no provision for rollover of those leases.

—I think the criticism that others are advancing is that the clause is so wide that it will in fact enable the rollover of all sorts of interests, including leases, in respect of which there is no explicit provision legally for their renewal. Far from that being the concern, the concern that I am hearing more often is that the clause is too wide in its reach. I am sorry, I do not think that reading is correct. I do not think there is any such limitation.

—Mr Chairman, I am just going to make one more comment on this and then I will sit down so that we can vote on it before we get up. I want to say to the minister that this is a most vicious attack on Western Australia—
—But you said that about the last clause and the one before that.

—Maybe I did, but the rollover provision does not apply to them, because there has to be the making of an amendment or the repeal of the legislation. It is a deliberately vindictive action against pastoralists in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Gareth Evans's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
